column2: Tile' FAG. Bearings Corporation has appointed Heinz I{leinhenz as vice president, manufactt/ring. He succeeds Austin J. Rine!la, who has resigned beciuse of ill health.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- A Federal district judge upheld today the Democratic Credentials Committee's actions in depriving Senator George McGovern of 151 of the delegates he won in California and in unseating Mayor Richard J. Daley and 58 other Chicago delegates.

The League of Voluntary Hospitals, backing a restraint order received last month, filed a contempt of-court show-cause order against Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Union yesterday in an attempt to head off a strike threatened for 6 A.M. Thursday.
Sales of seven of New York's largest department stores rose slightly in June from the same month last year, but excessive rain was blamed for about 10 days of erratic business.

BALTIMORE, July 3 -- A former British intelligence officer disputed today the tradition that Francis Scott Key saw the Star Spangled Banner "wave" over Fort McHenry and that someone other than Key had discovered that the English drinking tune, "To Anacreon in Heaven," would fit the words.
Another Independence Day, the calendar year just past its mid-point, the solar year just past its zenith. It is summer.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 3 (AP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman was reported to be cheerful and in satisfactory condition today at the Research Medical Center as his doctor began what was described as routine testing.
Seldom, if ever, has Count Basie's orchestra been cut twice in the same evening. But that has been his fate at the Newport Jazz Festival.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- The Justice Department today filed a civil antitrust suit to stop the Converse Rubber Corporation from leasing, with an option to purchase, the rubber -canvas footwear operations of the B. F. Goodrich Company of Akron, Ohio.

FREEPORT, L. I., July 2 -Fishing captains at this Long Island angling retreat have had the distress flag fluttering since the early spring. Although there have been sufficient flounders, fluke and bluefish about, continued foul weather has been keeping the customers away.
ROME -- A new Communist-run supermarket on the eastern edge of Rome is becoming a political hot potato.

Environmental groups are taking a second look at a new door-to-door money-raising plan that has brought them a fresh source of funds but has run into opposition from some homeowners and government officials over its aggressive tactics.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 3 -- A senior officer here describes Gen. Frederick C. Weyand as a chairman-ofthe-board type. Another officer says he is a diplomatic type.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 3 (AP) -- Marshal Lon Nol swore himself in as the Cambodian Republic's first elected president today and pledged to devote "all my strength and all of my soul" to serve his nation.
The Port of Baltimore, one of New York's leading competitors, has started a $23-million project to expand its container-handling facilities.

The Times' June 23 editorial "In the Face of the Storm" reminds us that although "man can split the atom -- or rocket a crew to the moon and back -- he still can't tame the weather." True, but he can, if he wishes, eliminate war, which is a thousand times more destructive than hurricane Agnes.
PARIS, July 3 -- The West German Central Bank had to acquire dollars today for the first time since the June 23 dollar flood into Frankfurt following the British decision to float the pound.
The St. Louis Cardinals, baseball's hottest team, won their seventh straight game and 14th in their last 15 by topping the Cincinnati Reds, 4-2, last night at Cincinnati.
Revenues and earnings of the Chesapeake Ohio-Baltimore Ohio Railway system in the second quarter and first half this year were lower than in the year-earlier periods, the report showed yesterday.
For centuries it was sold only by apothecaries who measured the granules out by the ounce. Only the rich could afford it and even they couldn't splurge because the supply was so short.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Two former high-ranking officials of the Johnson Administration said today that Robert S. McNamara, while Secretary of Defense, specifically ordered the Air Force to stop all rainmaking late in 1967, well before its first use in North Nietnam.

The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum will present a month-long summer arts festival of dance, film and music starting July 26. The event has been made possible through the support of the New York State Council on the Arts.
The stock market offered a study in slow motion yesterday as volume on the New York Stock Exchange contracted to 8.14 million shares -- by far the lowest turnover of 1972.

The Sony Corporation said yesterday in Tokyo that it was establishing a subsidiary to market in Japan products made in the United States. A spokesman said Sony had received more than 1,000 applications from American companies seeking Sony assistance in marketing their products. The applications were in response to advertisements Sony ran in selected United States newspapers.

STONY BROOK, L. I., July 3 -- Dr. Irving Ribner, a Shakespearian scholar and professor of English at the State University campus here, died yesterday apparently by a heart attack, at his home, Beach Road, Belle Terre, Port Jefferson, L.I. He was 50 years old.

GAINESVILLE, Ga., July 3 (UPI) -- Mark Donohue's Porsche came apart on the back straightaway of Road Atlanta today in private practice and hurtled off the course at 160 miles an hour. But Donohue was not seriously injured.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 3 -- Billie Jean King, Rosie Casals and Chris Evert, America's three top-ranked girls, were in the semifinals of the Wimbledon tennis tournament today, and with them was the defending champion, Evonne Goolagong, who casually came back from the brink to take two long deuce sets from Francoise Durr.

DETROIT, July 3 -- For the first time in recent history, the United States Supreme Court has been counted among the enemies of civil rights by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
OSSABAW ISLAND, Ga. -Nature resolves its problems on the United States coastline as ruthlessly as man; yet it kills with a grace beyond the craft of a bulldozer or dragline.

Three lines of heavy thunderstorms that stretched from New England across Pennsylvania rolled through several suburban and upstate counties yesterday, knocking out power lines, flooding roads and basements and raining hailstones in several areas.
In an era when unemployment is high, jobs -- many of them well-paying -- are going begging in the food-service industry, one of the fastest growing businesses in the country.

The state police reported yesterday that they had seized almost a half a ton of what appeared to be marijuana in Woodstock on Sunday after firemen extinguishing a blaze in a home there became suspicious about large quantities of dry vegetable material in the kitchen.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- It is two and one-half years since President Nixon signed the National Environmental Policy Act with the statement that "it is literally now or never" to begin the task of "reclaiming" the environment.

Over the past decade a new term, geophysical warfare, has begun creeping into discussions of future types of military capability. A rough definition of the concept would be an act or acts of environmental engineering designed to change the flow of air and water in order to damage one side in a conflict and benefit the other.

The Small Business Administration disclosed yesterday that it might have to ask Congress for additional funds to handle the large number of disaster -loan applications coming in from flood victims of tropical storm Agnes.

It is my sincere hope that the Madison Avenue Mall, an absurd project, is not going to be foisted upon us without serious protest. The traffic chaos in a congested area would patently be irreparable. This was recently proven by the tie-ups caused by the closing of only one side street during a commercial promotion.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 2 -- In Europe the Arts Festival has become a way of summer. Sometimes these events have a natural theme -- Mozart for Salzburg or Shakespeare for Stratfordon-Avon. Other festivals, such as Edinburgh's, are diverse grab bags of cultural goodies.
DETROIT, July 3 -- The General Motors Corporation recalled its small Vega cars again today to correct a safety defect that could lead to a rear axle and wheel falling off.

CLEVELAND, July 3 (AP) -David Graham, a 26-year-old tour rookie from Australia, sank a 10-foot putt for a birdie on the second hole of a suddendeath playoff today to win the $150,000 Cleveland open championship.

MIAMI, July 3 (AP) -- Federal District Court Judge C. Clyde Atkins temporarily enjoined the City of Miami Beach today from enforcing a parade control law that had been attacked in court by leaders of groups planning demonstrations during this summer's political conventions.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 3 -- A controversial day camp called Camporific, Inc., is scheduled to open in New Rochelle on Wednesday for a group of Brooklyn children, despite that city's refusal to grant the federally funded program a certificate of residency, Joseph W. Halper, the New York City Recreation Commissioner, said today.

Barring a cataclysm, long dresses will maintain their reign during fall evenings. "I went to a cocktail party in Oklahoma a month ago and all the men were in business suits and all the women in ball gowns," Oscar de la Renta remarked the other day. "Even Oklahoma." Of course, ball gowns aren't the big issue. Long skirts topped with sweaters, shirts or both are. So are long coat dresses, shirt dresses and jumpers.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The United States tonight welcomed the news of the high-level contacts between North and South Korea and said that they could have "a salutary impact on prospects for peace and stability on the Korean peninsula."

Trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday was the slowest since last November, with only 2,150,750 shares changing hands. Although many stock traders apparently were taking the long four-day Fourth of July weekend, the traders left behind managed to push prices ahead, with the Amex index closing at 27.32, up 0.08.
EUGENE, Ore., July 3 -Milt Sonsky celebrated his 31st birthday yesterday by winning a berth on the United States Olympic track and field team.
If countries competing in the recent World Team Olympiad in Miami Beach had been ranked according to size like boxers, there is little doubt that Turkey would have won the flyweight class.

The Offtrack Betting Corporation, required by law to pay off at the same prices as Roosevelt Raceway, yesterday figured it had lost about $7,000 because of the track's computer breakdown last Saturday night.

President Eisenhower was speaking of only one major segment of the political economy -- the sector he christened "the military-industrial complex" -- when he said that its "total influence -- economic, political, even spiritual -- is felt in every city, every statehouse, every office of the Federal Government. . . . Our toil, resources, and livelihood are all involved; so is the very structure of our society."
We asked one of our favorite stock brokers the other day how to make money in the stock market.
BUFFALO, July 3 -- Six priests of the Roman Catholic diocese of Buffalo have been suspended from their duties by Bishop James A. McNulty.

A long-time member of the United Nations Secretariat is reported as saying [news story June 10] that the United Nations should be "a truly international body concerned with the good of the entire world." This it is becoming and this is striking progress.
WALTHAM, Mass., July 3 -Alex Orban captured his fourth successive national men's saber crown and his fifth title since 1965 tonight at Bentley College.
We asked one of our favorite stock brokers the other day how to make money in the stock market.
DURHAM, N. C. -- A high school classmate came by the other day. He was making the rounds, saying goodby before he left Durham for Atlanta to accept a Federal job down there.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Diplomatic and intelligence reports have persuaded some key Administration officials that China will probably send engineer batallions to northern parts of North Vietnam to aid in the reconstruction of bombed-out railroad links to China.
A 16-year-old former state mental patient working as a porter in Brooklyn was arrested yesterday and charged with the murder of a 32-year-old woman in the Bay Ridge Towers apartment complex.

" Video is an art unto itself, with its own reality, visual language and its own conception of time and space," says Woody Vasulka, one of the increasing tribe of "video artists" who maintain that their medium is as much an art form as painting, sculpture and film.
SILVER SPRING, Md., July 3 (AP) -- Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama left Holy Cross Hospital today for a four-hour outing to eat an early dinner at his physician's home in nearby Bethesda, Md.
CHICAGO, July 3 -- George R. Cain, chairman of Abbott Laboratories since 1962, died in his sleep last night at his home in Winnetka, Ill. He was 61 years old.

With an exchange of quiet hellos on a dusty road in a refugee camp in South Vietnam, a search suffused with travail and romance came to an end after taking 24-yearold Steve Menta halfway around the world from his home in Jackson Heights, Queens. Mr. Menta, a former marine, returned last week to Vietnam to search for the young woman he knew as Leenie, 21-year-old Thai Thi Thiet.

DANBURY, Conn., July 3 -- A Federal plan calling for the revival of Candlewood Lake -- Connecticut's largest lake -- as a summer spa for weekend vacationers from New York City, Hartford and New Haven is meeting angry opposition from local residents who say Candlewood is already overused.

A South Vietnamese student identified as the man who was killed in Saigon Sunday while attempting to hijack a Pan American jet to Hanoi apparently wrote an open letter to President Nixon on the day he boarded the plane.
Four years ago the roster of the New York delegation to the Democratic National Convention read like a "Who's Who" in the state party.

Again our visibility is being obscured by the smog of a political campaign. Innuendos, accusations and rebuttals, false assertions and futile promises, all the old familiar obfuscation by the parties, the press and the public are dimming the light.

LAHORE, Pakistan, July 3 -President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto said here today that the National Assembly would meet in Islamabad next Monday to vote on ratification of the Indian - Pakistani agreement signed in Simla, India, last night.
NEW DELHI, July 3 -- The Indian-Pakistani agreement has been generally acclaimed by Indians.

Australian jazz, memories of Bessie Smith and a soprano saxophone version of Louis Armstrong's famous trumpet solo on "Struttin' With Some Barbecue" were some of the tidbits offered at the Newport Jazz Festival's second. Connoisseur Concert at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon.
BONN, July 3 -- President Georges Pompidou met here today with Chancellor Willy Brandt in a conference dominated by the monetary crisis.

ROATAN ISLAND, Honduras, June 29 -- Michael Johnston stood on the deck of his converted World War II minesweeper, ran his fingers through his beard and looked out across the glittering emerald green and blue water of Port Royal.
Steel production at midyear reached its lowest level since mid-February, according to weekly statistics released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 (AP) -- Bud Melges of Zenda, Wis., was the winning skipper today in the fourth race of the United States Soling Class Olympic trials as the fleet raced under ideal conditions for the first time in the series.
Two Consolidated Edison Company workmen were killed yesterday afternoon when they were trapped while working inside a huge transformer at a power substation at 110th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 3 -- Mr. and Mrs. David Larr, by 1 minute 52 seconds and close to 200 yards with their Etchells22, Rapscallion, and A. Shawhan Fox, by 1:37 and nearly as much distance with Fury in the Shields Class, were winners of 12. 1-mile Gold Cup races on Long Island Sound today.
The summer doldrums arrived in Wall Street yesterday, but hardly anybody was there to notice.

TOKYO, July 3 (Reuters) -The Japanese Government will start working out new measures for reducing the nation's trade surplus as soon as a new Cabinet is sworn in later this week, Japanese monetary officials said today.

ATHENS, July 4 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers, arriving today against a background of protest by the political opposition, pointedly stressed the role of ancient Greece as "the school of individual liberty and democracy."

LONDON, July 4 -- Promptly at 10 A.M. a chauffeur-driven Rolls-Royce glides to a halt at a building in the shadow of St. Paul's Cathedral. The car door opens and Jim Slater, a lean, dapper figure steps out quickly to move into a waiting elevator that takes him to his office round of phone calls -- to bankers in Hong Kong, Industrialists in South Africa, investors in Aus tralia and, to chess experts in London.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 4 -- A feeling is growing within South Vietnam's small educated elite that national morale has so collapsed that only a total revolution in the whole social structure offers hope of redemption.

"This is the worst stretch I've seen like this in my experience,'' said Walter Alston, who took over as manager of the Dodgers in 1954. His team, which moved to Los Angeles from Brooklyn in 1958, lost its fifth game in a row, 7-3, last night at Montreal for its longest losing streak of the season.
With her frilly white underpants peeking out from her pink dress, Sarah Lynn Seaver scampered across the locker room toward her mother.
A group of New York lawyers and legal scholars has indicted the American system of criminal law on the ground that "if the main purpose of the criminal law is to reduce crime, it has failed."

STAMFORD, July 4 -- With nearly half the fleet of 46 outboards knocked out of contentation by rough water, Stamford's first Harbor Festival marathon was halted today after one hour of a scheduled two-hour race.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 4 -- President Nixon issued today what he called an "unprecedented invitation to the world" to visit the United States four years from now as part of the festivities marking the 200th anniversary of the nation's independence.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 4 -- Art Nagle whistled the "Battle Hymn of the Republic" as the Junior Thunderers marching band swung down Main Street in the bright morning sun.
NEW HOPE, Pa., July 4 -- Taxi Light, a 5-year-old chestnut gelding, captured two championships today at the Peacefield Farm's horse show in his second appearance of the year.

Financial institutions, which have increasingly dominated the trading on the New York Stock Exchange in recent years, are expected to increase their share of total volume in the balance of the present decade.

ALBANY, July 4 (AP) -- Two men from Little Falls have been appointed by Governor Rockefeller as members of the board of commissioners of Herkimer House, the original home of Gen. Nicholas Herkimer, a Revolutionary War leader.

The decision of the Vatican to appoint Polish bishops for the areas of present-day Poland that once belonged to Germany is of considerable political importance in that it represents the Pope's acceptance of Poland's Western borders. This move was only made possible by West Germany's ratification of the treaty with Warsaw in which Bonn finally recognized the Oder-Neisse line.
Miles Davis, the jazz trumpeter, did not perform last night at Carnegie Hall as had been advertised by the Newport Jazz Festival.
WALTHAM, Mass., July 4 -- Ruth White, a New York University senior,; tonight became the first woman to capture two national fencing championships before her 21st birthday.
LONDON, July 4 (Reuters) -- Britain's reserves of gold, dollars and other foreign currencies have dropped to $6.965-billion, the lowest they have been this year, the Treasury announced today.

Howard S. Stein, an official of the Human Resources Administration, has been appointed deputy commissioner in the Housing and Development Administration's Office of Code Enforcement, which includes the controversial Emergency Repair Program.

BREMEN, West Germany, July 4 -- The leadership of one of the world's largest and most diverse research establishments has been assumed by a dynamic figure whose scientific career began as the consequence of a depth-charge attack by two American destroyers.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 5 -- Fourteen of Saigon's daily newspapers, including both English-language dailies, were confiscated by the Government last night, and the Interior Ministry announced today that they would be prosecuted for violation of the press laws.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 4 (AP) -- A Federal judge has struck down 23 sets of mine safety regulations, delaying the prosecution of a coal company in connection with a 1970 explosion that killed 38 miners.
Senator George McGovern recently joined in the sponsorship of legislation which would materially discourage private philanthropy to many worthy educational, religious and charitable causes.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The surprise agreement by South Korea and North Korea to undertake unification talks has produced an enthusiastic initial response in the Nixon Administration. Some senior officials even speculated today that the latest development might bring pressure on Hanoi to negotiate an end to the Vietnam war.
Slides projected on the facade of the New York Cultural Center will publicize cultural events throughout the summer in the New York area.

The American Ballet Theater swung into its summer season at the New York State Theater last night with a triple bill consisting of Alvin Ailey's "The River," Birgit Cullberg's "Miss Julie" and Harald Lander's "Etudes." It offered the company at its expansive, confident and eclectic best.

There's a fashion calm around furriers' showrooms these days. Their Seventh Avenue neighbors to the north, who deal with cloth and set the fashion pace, have stopped their shenanigans with hemlines and waistlines and have gone back to the classics.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 4 (AP) -- A Superior Court jury has awarded $170,000 to a former university coed from San Jose for injuries suffered in a 13-hour therapy session with a psychologist.

A Gallup poll released yesterday by the Scott Commission, a body created last year by Governor Rockefeller to investigate the quality of the city's government, found that 60 per cent of 709 people interviewed felt that the Lindsay administration was doing a "poor" job.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (AP) Calumet Farms' Eastern Fleet, guided by Angel Cordero, caught pace-setting Leematt in the upper stretch and went on to post a 1 1/2-length victory today in the $58,050 Firecracker Handicap at Liberty Bell.

Every now and then a performer, an audience and a location come together in a perfect meeting of spirit and place. Sonny Cher's opening at the Westbury (L.I.) Music Fair Monday night was a prime example: a slick, young, television-oriented entertainment team playing before a suburban middle-class audience in a theater in the round.
EUGENE, Ore., July 4 -- Their names are Jeff Bannister and Jeff Bennett, and if they sound unfamiliar, well, that could change in Munich this summer.

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 5 -- Kakuei Tanaka, 54-year-old Minister for International Trade and Industry, was this morning elected president of the governing Liberal-Democratic party at a special party caucus. Because of the party's majority position in the Parliament, he is assured of becoming Japan's next Premier.

LONDON -- Sometimes a nation is like its prophets who, the New Testament contends, are not without honor save in their own country. It is comforting to learn there are some people here who find moral value in the United States -- and rather more, indeed, than many Americans find.
Here the flood waters are receding and the sun is shining again, but the real impact of the human tragedy is just beginning to be felt. The response of the community has been wonderful.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Mrs. Fanie Abney was pleased as she was escorted into a doctor's office at the Shaw Comprehensive Medical Center here after having waited only eight minutes. Two days before, she said, she and her son waited four hours at a hospital to see a doctor.

Bronx detectives arrested yesterday a 21-year-old man they believe committed a series of robberies and sexual assaults on eight women in the last two months in the Morris Heights and Highbridge sections.

HANOI, North Vietnam, July 4 (Agence France-Presse) -- Nguyen Huu Tho, president of the South Vietnamese National Liberation Front, said today that the Vietnam war could have ended if President Nixon had responded seriously to its seven-point peace plan aimed at creating an "independent and neutral South Vietnam."

A study of seven years' acceptance rates of welfare family applications here shows "wide and unexplained" variations among the city's 43 welfare centers, Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein charged yesterday in asking for an investigation by the State Controller.
The police said yesterday that they were "very close to a solution" in the murder of Anthony Bower, the art dealer who was found shot Monday morning in his East Side apartment.
Hopes brightened yesterday for averting a strike threatened for tomorrow by 42,000 workers in 66 voluntary and municipal hospitals here.
This week's accord between South and North Korea is a historic development of the utmost importance for improving the political atmosphere in Asia and the world.

Led by Premier Golda Meir, virtually the entire Israeli Cabinet and military and judicial establshment appeared at the official residence of the United States Ambassador in Tel Aviv for a sentimental tribute on Walworth Barbour's 12th -- and probably final -- Independence Day there.

GRANBY, Colo., July 4 -- Standing in line for breakfast at "love kitchen," one could not mistake the form on the side of the mountain. It was snow in the shape of a white buffalo, a good omen, some said, meaning they had come to the right place at the right time and were a pleasure in the sight of God.
Some ad agencies have taken moves to formalize what to an outsider at least seems to be a well-established tradition -- the early slide on the eve of summer weekends.
HORICON, Wis., Smack in front of Horicon's public library is a neat redwood sign pointing eastward and stating: "Our Sister City, Senonches, France, 4,494 miles."

The Newport Jazz Festival made one kind of history this year when it moved to New York City. I suspect it will make another, and equally important, kind of history with its premiere of a major work for orchestra and jazz quartet called 'The Skies of America," written by Ornette Coleman.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 5 -- South Vietnamese paratroops and marines were reported to have moved into Quangtri city yesterday as Government forces continued their drive to retake the northernmost province, which fell to the Communists in May.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., July 4 (AP) -- J. D. Morrison, a veteran jet pilot flying cross-country in an open-cockpit plane like the one in which he learned to fly in 40 years ago, was killed today when the craft crashed near Napier, Mo., about 40 miles north of here, the Highway Patrol said.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Two Californians with White House backgrounds, Frederic V. Malek and Jeb S. Magruder, were named yesterday as deputy directors of President Nixon's reelection campaign.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 4 -- An hour after agreeing to end their long, bitter antagonism and start working together for peaceful reunification, North and South Korea began taking steps today to put their agreement into action.
CALDWELL, N. J., July 4 -- A school nurse who saw what a thoughtless word can do to children has begun a campaign to eliminate the phrase "color blind" from the language.

If you want to win, you should waste no time on guilt, recrimination or lamentation. If you reach a hopeless contract, as South did on the diagramed deal from the recent World Team Olmpiad, there is no point in regretting your own bidding, criticizing your partner, or bemoaning the fates.

There was bluegrass country music performed by a troupe from New Jersey and crash courses were given in the hora and in Greek folk dance in the Wall Street area yesterday as several thousand tourists joined in a daylong attempt to transform the nation's financial center into the "bustling village" it was 196 years ago.
A 33-year-old woman was charged with stabbing her nine-year-old son to death yesterday with a five-inch kitchen knife in a wooded section of Cunningham Park, in the Fresh Meadows section of Queens.

The South Korean official who secretly visited North Korea on a Kissinger - style mission in May is a chief adviser to President Park Chung Hee on national security affairs and one of the most influential men in Seoul.

TUCKAHOE, N. J., July 4 -- Thousands of Atlantic brant, small sea geese that have crowded the Atlantic flyway in flocks totaling 200,000 birds in recent years, are missing, and nobody is quite sure why.

SOLOMONS ISLAND, Md. -- "It's a better design," said Dr. Joseph A. Mihursky as he stood on the rolling deck of the research vessel Aquarius and peered at the Calvert Cliffs nuclear power plant on the shore, "but is it good enough?"

Prior to 1969, Warren Brown, a black electrical contractor for 30 years in Buffalo, seldom obtained construction jobs amounting to more than $10,000, and the number of blacks working on those projects at any given time was never more than three or four journeymen.

PARIS -- The idea, taken for granted a few months ago, that President Nixon would be automatically re-elected in 1972, could only stem from the illusion that no basic changes had affected America during the sixties. Last fall, and even in early spring this year, it was generally admitted that all the "movements" born after 1960 had just faded away.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie who once expected to be the Presidential nominee of a reasonably united Democratic party now finds himself at the center of a storm which is tearing his party apart.

His eye lights upon it, and like a kid who has cracked a stuffed piggybank, he's into it. Politics, power, celebrities. A tangle of business affairs, which means scurrying about town in his $36,000, chauffeur-driven, tan Rolls-Royce.

The chief North Korean representative in the recent secret talks with South Korea is generally regarded as the second-ranking leader in the North even though he is listed officially as No. 6 in the Communist hierarchy.

The construction industry in this city has long been a jungle of graft. A survey by this newspaper demonstrated afresh last week that every element in this multi-billion-dollar business, from the contractor through the municipal building inspector, is involved in an institutionalized system of payoffs. Not much has changed from the days of Sam Parks and the Tweed ring.
"We've been talking to ourselves too much," said Carl H. Hageman, a vice president of the Union Carbide Corporation and a leading exponent of labor law reform.
An action charging 15 major plumbing supply companies and their trade association with violation of antitrust laws has resulted in a settlement of $91,500.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 4 -- The world championship chess match, moved thousands of miles, postponed and then postponed again because of the protests of Bobby Fischer, was delayed once more today -- this time because the Russian titleholder refused to play.

LIMA, Peru, July 4 (UPI) -- One person was killed and five injured in the southeastern city of Puno after a group of striking leftist students and workers tried to disarm a truck full of policemen, a spokesman for the prefect of Puno said today.

Life in America is changing. School is becoming freer, community is replacing isolation, marriage is becoming less of an enslavement, openness is taking over from superficiality, black is becoming beautiful. But the changes aren't happening fast enough, nor for enough people, and there are always those who would block them and even turn back the clock if they could.
The small -- and large -- investor is constantly poring over financial data in an effort to find some undiscovered investment medium in which he can make a substantial profit.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Some officials of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. are warning that the labor federation may remain neutral in a Presidential race between Senator George McGovern and President Nixon.

LYONS, France, July 4 -- France and the United States have agreed on a three-year plan for submarine exploration of the cavernous mid-Atlantic rift valleys almost a mile and a half beneath the ocean surface. It is a venture that conjures up images from Jules Verne.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 4 (AP) -- Bill Shoemaker broke a personal stakes victory drought today when he guided Buzkashi to victory in the $83,300 American Handicap at Hollywood Park.

The producers of the Newport Jazz Festival got a strong hint of how to run a jazz festival yesterday when they took their audiences for a ferryboat ride on the Hudson: Pull the festival out of the concert halls and float the whole shebang on the river.

Freeze before drying. That is the way to salvage the books damaged by the recent floodwaters in the East, according to Mrs. Carolyn Horton, a leading book and print conservator, and that is what the Corning Glass Center in upstate New York is doing to save nearly 6,000 volumes on the history, design and craft of glass.
The first real effects of a strike by 65,000 building-trades workers is expected to be felt today when work resumes on $2-billion worth of construction projects in the city.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 4 -- Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, warned nations today against restricting the entry of long-range investment capital while controlling the inflow of speculative funds.
DALLAS, July 4 (AP) -- The Lutheran Church in America approved today a major overhaul in its operational machinery.

GENEVA, July 4 -- Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations, welcoming the agreement reached by North and South Korea, disclosed today he had played a role as intermediary in their secret talks.

Wall Street and much of the business community are in a state of confusion and alarm over Senator George McGovern's economic proposals. If the South Dakotan wins the Democratic nomination for the Presidency at Miami Beach next week, business anxiety will intensity.

EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., July 4 (AP) -- More than 50 black unemployed men who occupied City Hall here for six days said today that they had agreed to an offer of jobs by Mayor James E. Williams and would leave the building.

Nine policemen were injured and 14 stores and two police cars were damaged in three hours of intermittent street disturbances in Harlem yesterday, the police reported. Twenty-three persons were arrested.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 4 -- The United States Ambassador, Nathaniel Davis, said today that American businessmen in Chile must feel that these are like the Conestoga wagon days when, surrounded in the desert by hostile Indians, "one saw friends dropping to left and to right."

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The fate of Senator George McGovern's candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination may well turn on a series of procedural questions at the party's national convention next week.

DANBURY, Conn., July 4 -- "Remember, whenever you see the word "Greetings" on a letter from your local board, you know you've been drafted," said Guillermo Muniz, winding up his explanation of the Selective Service system to the small group of Puerto Rican youths and their parents who gathered recently in Danbury's Young Men's Christian Association building.

GENEVA, July 4 -- The Swiss Government erected new ramparts today to repel an invasion of foreign capital in a determined bid to prevent demand for the Swiss franc from upsetting the nation's monetary balance.

ZGORZELEC, Poland, June 26 -- Germans are pouring across the Polish border again, but as tourists in sputtering Trabant and Wartburg cars rather than as soldiers in the armored vehicles of a Panzer division.
LONDON, July 4 -- Control of Watney Mann, Ltd., the big brewers, has been won by Grand Metropolitan Hotels, the hotel, catering and entertainment giant.

PHUDUONG, South Vietnam, June 29 -- They had lived for nearly two months under North Vietnamese occupation, but, they say, it was the constant pounding by American bombs and shells, not Communist rule, that finally drove them to desperation and to escape.

BOSTON, July 4 -- It was 23 years ago that a major literary uproar erupted when the Bollingen Prize was awarded to Ezra Pound, the expatriate poet whose Fascist leanings and anti-Semitism made his name anathema to a generation of American intellectuals.

Shoes and furniture from Brazil and Greece . . . men's clothing from Spain . . . bathing suits from France . . . jewelry from Finland . . . everything from artificial flowers to pocket computers and TV sets from Japan, Hong Kong and points in between.

Free heroin clinics are doomed to failure. One can only view this as an inhumane, experimental attempt to safeguard the rest of the population by destroying all hope of recovery for thousands of unfortunate sick people.

The Free Libertarian party, a new poltical party stressing opposition to "big government, big spending and government bureaucracy," made its debut in New York State yesterday by presenting candidates for one Congressional and two Assembly seats.

Plans to consolidate all city drug programs under the Addiction Services Agency, which in turn would come under the wing of the Health Services Administration, were announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 4 -- Summer Guest, leading 3-year-old filly in the East, won the $56,500 Monmouth Oaks at 1 1 1/8 miles today.

BONN, July 4 (Reuters) -- Economics and Finance Minister Karl Schiller has asked to be relieved of his post in protest against monetary control measures decided on by the West German Cabinet against his will, government sources said tonight.

Two Chinatown teen-agers were wounded, one critically, in a shooting incident last night in a small playground at Bayard and Chrystie Streets near the Manhattan Bridge. The police said the person or persons who did the shooting were apparently waiting in ambush in the park.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The Supreme Court's decision to delay its ruling on two abortion appeals until the next term has led to frictions within the Court and suggestions that Chief Justice Warren E. Burger has overstepped his authority to pick which Justices will write which majority opinions.

NKROFUL, Ghana, June 29 -- Mrs. Elizabeth Nyaniba is a small woman of "somewhere over a hundred" years who has lost her sight but retains a clear voice and a sharp memory. For weeks now she has had a growing fear that she may "never again touch my son before I die."

Big Spruce took to the turf with great gusto, winning the $57,900 Lexington Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday by two lengths. The event, for 3-year-olds at 13-16 miles on the grass, attracted 11 starters and Big Spruce, carrying the Elmendorf silks, scored by two lengths over the Greentree Stable's Ruritania.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI) -- The chairman of the House Democratic Study Group said yesterday that a staff analysis showed that Senator George McGovern, if he were the Democratic Presidential nominee, would help rather than hurt the party's chances to retain control of the House.

LOS ANGELES, July 4 (AP) -- Three young men were arrested early today in the slaying of a four-year-old girl. The child was playing in her front yard when sloe was hit by a shotgun blast fired from a passing car.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia reserved its decision tonight on two cases involving the political composition of the Democratic National Convention, which opens next Monday in Miami Beach. A ruling is expected tomorrow.
MOSCOW, July 4 -- The United States and the Soviet Union, expanding their joint research on cancer, have agreed on a program of exchanges of experimental drugs for tests in each other's laboratories.

WINDSOR, Conn., July 4 (UPI) -- For the second time in two weeks a body has been found in the Connecticut River. Both were those of murder victims, the police said today.

One of the nation's leading mathematical economists has charged that an implementation of Senator George McGovern's economic program -- at least in the form that he believes it would be most likely to pass Congress -- would lead to a recession in 1974 and an unemployment rate of 7 per cent.
MOSCOW, July 4 -- Ambassador Jacob D. Beam of the United States had a meeting with the Soviet Defense Minister today, and the news appeared to throw Tass, the official press agency, into confusion.

Although a sign in the lobby of Carnegie Hall confirmed reports that Miles Davis would not play at the Newport Jazz Festival concerts at 5 and 9 P.M. yesterday for which he had been advertised, only 60 persons asked for a refund at the first performance.
DENVER, July 4 (UPI) -- A blasting cap bomb blew up today in the faces of three policemen trying to dismantle it. The policemen, members of the department's bomb squad, were injured critically.

Recent editorials in The Times have indicated your continuing opposition to the proposed trans-Alaska pipeline, a subject of vast interest to the native peoples of Alaska. Our interest is basic -- we will be the most directly affected by the pipeline and subsequent oil production on the North Slope.

"We were a cultural desert," said Donald Manes, the Queens Borough President. "We had no single permanent home for cultural activities." But the desert is beginning to bloom. Today, Mr. Manes will announce that Queens finally has a showcase for the visual and performing arts, the Queens County Art and Cultural Center.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 4 -- Stan Smith and three Europeans are in the semifinals at the Wimbledon tennis tournament, and the big fellow is becoming recognizable.

LOS ANGELES, July 4 -- Joel B. Honey, the Santa Barbara County Sheriff's captain who was dismissed for alleged misconduct as commander of police forces in the 1970 Isla Vista riots, is back on duty after being reinstated by the county Civil Service Commission.

The latest word from Indianapolis is that the United States Auto Club and Pocono International Raceway "are still negotiating" a rescheduling of the Schaefer 500, second segment of USAC's triple crown of 500-mile races, which was to have run Sunday.

BONN, July 4 -- President Georges Pompidou of France and West German Chancellor Willy Brandt concluded today two days of talks that failed to narrow the gap between the positions of the two countries on the world monetary crisis and the character of the expanded European Economic Community and its relations with the United States.

DETROIT, July 4 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People adopted today a stinging resolution that reiterated the association's opposition to the Nixon Administration's busing and integration policies.
SHERBORNE, England, Wednesday, July 5 (Reuters) -- At least 31 people were killed when a fire swept through a mental hospital in this town in southwest England early today.

King Olav V of Norway couldn't take his cup and go home yesterday because Ernest Fay of New York skippered Sudance to victory in the third and final race of the King Olav Cup competition for 5.5-Meter yachts at Hankoe, Norway.

This is Grand Circuit week in Goshen, N. Y., when the trotters and pacers come back to the peaceful little seat of Orange County and find it much the same as it was when Messenger, the gray progenitor of America's light harness horse, stood at stud there 171 years ago, or when Messenger's prepotent descendant, Hambletonian 10, was foaled in 1849.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 4 -- Faced with criticism abroad and questioning at home, President Emilio G. Medici declared last night that Brazil would retain her curbs on civil liberties.

LONDON, July 4 (Reuters) -- Britain's sole computer company, International Computers, Ltd., which has aroused takeover interest from a United States rival, the Burroughs Corporation, has won Government support.

OAKLAND, Calif. July 4 -- The New York Yankees' five-game winning streak ended shortly after they arrived in the West tonight when the Oakland Athletics defeated Mel Stottlemyre, 4-2, on a grand-slam homer by Sal Bando.
SAN QUENTIN, Calif., July 4 -- Five huge tiers inhabited only by birds that roost in the rafters are all that are left of what was once the biggest prison cell block in the world.
A peaceful demonstration by dogs and their owners opposing Mayor Lindsay's call for legislation against dog litter was briefly disrupted when a rabbit happened by yesterday.

Leron Lee's ninth-inning single in the first game prevented Tom Seaver from pitching a no-hitter, and Derrel Thomas's ninth-inning single in the second game prevented the Mets from sweeping the double-header yesterday.
LEADVILLE, Colo., -- The growing water problems of the arid Southwest states were the uninvited guests in a recent ceremony in a high mountain valley 10 miles west of here.

ABERDEEN, Miss., July 1 -- Hearings have ended in an environmental suit seeking to halt construction of the Tennessee Tombigbee Waterway, an extensive United States Corps of Engineers project designed to link the highly developed Tennessee River with the Tombigbee River in Alabama to form a navigation system to the eastern Gulf Coast.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 4 -- David Pearson, continuing his brilliant comeback in stock car racing, won the Firecracker 400 today for his fourth super-speedway victory of the season. The Firecracker, run in 96-degree heat, also represented the sixth victory in 10 races for the Wood brothers' red and gold Purolator Mercury.

A tidal wave of Dixieland jazz rolled up the Hudson River yesterday and nearly 6,000 jazz lovers were swept along with it. It carried most of them exactly where they wanted to go -- to shores of ecstasy or isles of euphoria.
BERLIN, July 4 -- Pier Paolo Pasolini's "Canterbury Tales" -- an adaptation of the Chaucer classic -- today won the Golden Bear best film award at Berlin's 22d International Film Festival.
Employe savings plans are becoming a widespread and popular feature of American industrial life, the Bankers Trust Company said yesterday.

PARIS, July 4 -- The dollar was buffeted today in Frankfurt, Zurich, Paris and other money centers of Continental Europe, and central banks intervened on a large scale to prevent their currencies from rising above fixed upper limits.
The Small Business Administration may soon ask Congress for as much as $1-billion in emergency loan funds for flood relief to businessmen and homeowners.

A key group of operations experts from the securities industry has raised some two dozen questions about a rule proposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission to regulate the safekeeping of customers' securities by brokerage firms.

Traders were back in force yesterday, bidding up stocks on the American Stock Exchange to 27.37, up 0.05, as measured by the index. Volume zoomed to 4,616,000 shares, compared with a holiday volume lag of only 2,150,000 shares on Monday, the day before July 4.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled today that the Democratic Credentials Committee had been "arbitrary and unconstitutional" in depriving Senator George McGovern of 151 California delegates to the party's national convention.

MIAMI BEACH July 5 (AP) -- The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy said tonight that if the Democratic party refused to accept 750 poor people as national convention delegates they would crash the gathering and take the seats.
CHICAGO, July 5 (UPI) -- The trial of Cook County State's Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan and 13 co-defendants was postponed for five days today so that a defense attorney could take a vacation.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- In air-conditioned rooms off a brightly painted corridor, 60 young men were ranged along the walls, each seated in a learning cubicle with his name printed above it and his books or tape recorder in front of him.
WARSAW, July 5 -- Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations arrived here today to begin a series of talks with Polish officials.

FORT ERIE, Ontario, July 5 -- The "old" Lee Trevino is at full physical and jocular strength to defend his title in the Canadian open golf tournament, which begins tomorrow. It's his first tournament since he played in the United States Open at Pebble Beach, Calf., three weeks ago.

EUGENE, Ore., July 5 (UPI) -- Cliff Buck, president of the United States Olympic Committee, said today during a break in the United States track and field trials that opening up the Olympics to professionals would spell the end of the movement.
Theater '73, the producing company of Richard Barr and Charles Woodward, has signed Julie Harris to star in "The Last of Mrs. Lincoln," a new play by James Prideaux, opening here Jan. 11.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he would not support any Presidential ticket that included Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama.

TRENTON, July 5 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that criminal defendants may not challenge the accuracy of information contained in police affidavits or upon which search warrants are based.
American experience has always included the quest for radical novelty while retaining at the same time a quality of nostalgia for the values of its past.

MOSCOW, July 5 (AP) -- Dissident sources reported today that a Lithuanian worker doused himself with gasoline last month and burned himself to death to protest Soviet occupation, the third immolation in the Lithuanian Republic in seven weeks.
PARIS, July 5 -- The dollar and the pound strengthened today in Europe, but markets remained nervous and traders expressed doubt that any real recovery had set in.

The Mojave and Colorado deserts in southern California may finally receive the protection they have long deserved. After years of rapidly increasing desecration by littering, indiscriminate road building, mineral prospecting, speculative real estate ventures, and hordes of motorcycles and other off-road vehicles, the Federal Government now seems ready to save some of what still remains of the fragile, awesome desert landscapes.

KIEV, U.S.S.R., July 5 (AP) -- Zhores Medvedev, the eminent biologist who disappeared Sunday after being barred from an international conference hem, told an American scientist today that . the authorities forced him to return home.

Rain forced a one-day postponement last night of the Mets' final home game with the San Diego Padres this season, giving the Mets' ill and injured another day to recuperate. Tickets that were marked for last night's game will be good tonight.

ROME, July 5 -- A few casual-sounding words by a French layman have revived serious speculation that the Roman Catholic Church is about to enact a radical change in the age-old way of choosing the Pope.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 5 (UPI) -- President Nixon accepted today with regret the resignation of G. Harrold Carswell, his unsuccessful nominee for the Supreme Court, from a special advisory post on government administration.

While New York stomps to the syncopated beat of the transplanted Newport Jazz Festival, its poor relation -- the Newport Folk Festival -- is holding a pair of benefit concerts at Carnegie Hall tomorrow night to pay off the creditors of other years.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- After Jerome Morris obtained his Master of Law degree, he could have returned to a rewarding practice in some comfortable office, but he went to work instead for the Federal Legal Services program in a crumbling storefront here.

Unionized workers in 140 hotels in the city have voted 16,713 to 986 to authorize a strike to back up their demands for a $125 weekly minimum wage and a $100 monthly pension. Maids now start at $91.75 a week and their pension is $60 a month.

The membership of the New York Stock Exchange voted into office yesterday a new 20-member board of directors that had been proposed last month by a nominating committee. The new board replaces the old 33-man board of governors.
Interest rates continued to trace an indecisive pattern yesterday in light post-holiday activity.

The Hamburg Savings Bank, Brooklyn, has appointed Joseph L. Werner chief executive officer, succeeding Joseph G. WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI) -- Senators George McGovern and Hubert H. Humphrey promised today that if they became President they would consult with Congress at least 24 hours before sending American forces into action against another country.

RUTLAND, Vt., July 5 -Bernie Lawrence, who operates a busy little automobile body shop on State Street, is convinced he's doing something wrong. An ardent angler, who as a 6-year-old captured trout with a string and a safety pin, Lawrence is sure fish are conspiring to avoid him.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The National Endowment for the Arts and the Office of Education announced a $2.5-million program today that will place professional artists in elementary and secondary classrooms in all 50 states.
The title of the Plaza Hotel has been acquired by the Sonesta International Hotels Corporation, it was disclosed yesterday. The price of the purchase could not be ascertained.
MADRID, July 5 -- Women won a battle of nearly a century in Madrid last night with a decision by a committee of parliament to reduce the legal age of adulthood for women from 23 to 21.
BRIDGEWATER, N. J., July 5 -- A 50-year-old junk dealer was charged here today with murdering a wealthy developer to whom he owed money.

PARIS, July 5 -- President Pompidou accepted his Government's resignation today and chose a tough, orthodox Gaullist, Pierre Messmer, as his new Premier. Mr. Messmer's main job will be to help Mr. Pompidou's party in the coming elections.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 5 -- Lebanon and Syria today requested a meeting of the Security Council because of "Israeli defiance" of a Council resolution that asked for the release "in the shortest possible time" of one Lebanese and five Syrian army officers.

DETROIT, July 5 -- The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, a former aide to the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., called today for a summit conference of black leaders to formulate solutions to the problems of blacks.
DETROIT, July 5 -- The Chrysler Corporation today asked the Price Commission for an average increase of 5 per cent, or $180, in the prices of its 1973 cars and trucks.
BLACK MOUNTAIN, N. C. July 5 (UPI) -- The Rev. Billy Graham called today for thousands of young Christians to flock to both political conventions at Miami Beach to withess for Christ.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Senator George McGovern has all but abandoned his hope of enticing Senator Edward M. Kennedy to join him on the Democratic ticket.

The Sperry Rand Corporation announced yesterday the election of J. Paul Lyet as chairman and chief executive officer.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, July 6 -- South Vietnamese troops continued to close in on the heart of Quangtri city yesterday, as Saigon's counteroffensive to retake the country's northernmost province entered its second week, still making slow but steady gains.

TOKYO, July 5 -- While he was still in his teens, Kakuei Tanaka, who was chosen today as Japan's next Premier, thought of becoming a naval officer. He took the examination and came in 10th among 13,000 applicants. He never accepted the appointment.

Net income of the Security National Bank, Huntington, L.I., declined 15 per cent in the first half of 1972 to $6.6-million, or $1.49 a share, from $7.8-million, or $1.76 a share, in the corresponding period last year. Platinum futures, rising steadily for some time, reached new highs for the life of contract yesterday and all months except the nearby October. The October option, nevertheless, rose by $9.20 an ounce. Trading was active with 1,255 lots involved.

WAYNE, N. J., July 5 -- New Jersey today became the first state to begin routine inspection of automobile exhaust systems in an effort to reduce the levels of carbon monoxide and hydrocarbons in the atmosphere.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- A group at the Department of Health, Education and Welfare has been searching for a fresh word to replace what they believe is a worn out and much abused term: welfare.

TRIPOLI, Libya -- Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, Libya's strongman, is being pushed toward ever more extreme positions at home and abroad. And the force pushing him, foreign diplomats here believe, is frustration.

DETROIT, July 4 -- The General Motors Corporation today reported record car sales in June, 450,872 deliveries, a 7 per cent increase from 422,409 the year before. The American Motors Corporation reported 28,818 June sales, its best June in eight years, up 23 per cent from 23,496 deliveries the year before.

Today they are measured best on the ground, at street level, where new urban patterns are emerging that are in the process of making the city a vastly different place.

HOUSTON, July 5 (UPI)--United States space officials will propose that the American spacecraft be launched 16 to 40 hours ahead of the Russian vehicle in the joint United States-Soviet rendezvous flight in 1975, the United States project director said today.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 5 -- A Nassau County rackets grand jury indicted nine persons today, including a reputed captain in the crime family of Joseph Colombo, in connection with the alleged underworld take-over of a Lake Success, L. I., restaurant and nightclub.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 5 -- F.B.I. agents shot and killed two armed hijackers who had held 86 persons aboard a jet airliner at San Francisco International Airport today while they waited for an $800,000 ransom.
MIAMI BEACH, July 5 -- The Miami Beach City Council, acting on a recommendation of the police, voted today to grant campsites to "non-delegates" for the Democratic National Convention.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 5 -- Premier Kim Jong Pil said today that he saw little possibility of a meeting between the top government leaders of North and South Korea in the near future despite the dramatic Seoul-Pyongyang agreement to work for better relations.

WAYNE, N.J., July 5 -- Chris Blair of Maplewood, an amateur, shot a one-under-par 38, 33 -- 71 today to take the medal in the northern section qualifying round of the 52d New Jersey open golf championship over the 6,584-yard, par 72 Preakness Hills Country Club course.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 6 -- Kakuei Tanaka, Japan's new Premier to be, promised vigorous action yesterday to deal with Japan's domestic ills and outlined a foreign policy encompassing continued close ties with the United States, improved relations with the Soviet Union and the establishment of diplomatic relations with China.
Price reductions for copper initiated by major United States producers spread to Canada yesterday.

ALBANY, July 5 -- New York Republicans completed the selection today of an 88-member delegation to the Republican National Convention that was described by Governor Rockefeller as "broadly representational."

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Clark MacGregor, President Nixon's new political campaign manager, said today that he detected some overconfidence in the Nixon camp but that he intended to dispel it.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., July 5 -- Miss Jane Dart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Justin W. Dart of Los Angeles and Pebble Beach, and John Campbell, an assistant to John D. Ehrlichmann, President Nixon's assistant for domestic affairs, were married here Saturday in the chapel of the Robert Louis Stevenson School, a boy's private preparatory school.

The 12-member jury that will decide the state's murder case against Patrolman William R. Phillips was completed here yesterday, four days and nearly 100 potential veniremen after jury selection began.

Glamour stocks, the group that repeatedly has revived a sluggish stock market over the last two years, performed the honors again yesterday. The Dow-Jones industrial average moved ahead 4.81 to 933.47.

The "Public Access Celebration" began yesterday at noon on cable television. It will continue today and Saturday, running each day from noon to around midnight. As a retrospective of videotape programing that has appeared on cable channels C and D during the first year of the first "public access" experiment in operation anywhere, the celebration is not entirely a celebration, even to many active participants.

The 1970 conviction of Dr. Leslie A. Fiedler, the author and literary critic, and his wife on charges of allowing their children and others to smoke marijuana in their home in Buffalo was struck down yesterday by the New York Court of Appeals.

HANOVER, N. H., July 6 -- Six Harvard alumni, including two pairs of brothers, were named to the United States eight-oared crew for the Olympics today, ending a long and arduous selection process. Harry Parker, the Hazard coach in charge of the Olympic team, made the announcement of the eight plus six backup oarsmen, four of whom will row in the four-oared-with-coxswain event.

Six United States golfers, including Tommy Aaron, withdrew from the British Open championship, scheduled to start at Muirfield, Scotland, Wednesday. These late scratches were supposed to compete with 500 other golfers today and tomorrow for the 90 spots available to nonexempt players.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 6 -- During most of the Wimbledon matches today, there was boredom. In the second set of Stan Smith's victory over Jan Kodes, spectators in the center court enclosure were yawnings. And at least on ewas sleeping.
BRETTON WOODS, N. H., July 6 (AP) -- Top-seeded Rod Laver, the host pro, rallied in the third set today to advance to the quarterfinals of the $25,000 Bretton Woods international tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission will no longer accept new-issue prospectuses that deal with important matters in unrevealing "stock phrases," the agency's chairman said today.

Making only two hits in 14 innings, the New York Mets lost a 1-0 decision to the San Diego Padres last night by minimum margins with maximum frustration. Among other things, the winning run scored on a walk with the bases full, and the final out of the game was a spectacular tag play at home plate on what would have been the tying run.
Twenty years ago today the liner United States steamed into Le Havre, a broom lashed to her towering mast, to proclaim that she had established a new trans-Atlantic speed record on her maiden voyage.

MIAMI BEACH, July 6 (UPI) -- As part of their "new look," the Democrats will publish their own daily convention newspaper next week, starting with a 64-page Sunday edition put together by a 30-member staff, most of them volunteers.

The city has lost a minimum of $250-million in Federal welfare funds, unclaimed by the state since 1969 because of "bureaucratic lethargy" tantamount to "gross negligence," Mayor Lindsay's Commission on State-City Relations charged yesterday.

A three-year study of 720 regular users of hashish, the concentrated resin of the marijuana plant, has shown that persons who smoke moderate amounts, equivalent to three or four marijuana cigarettes a day, suffered few mental or physical ill-effects other than a mild respiratory ailment known as "hash throat."

WAVERLY, Minn., July 6 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, who has campaigned for the Presidency for 12 years, is reluctantly resolved to fight to the finish for the Democratic nomination even if that fight poses the risk of widening the party rifts that plagued his own race against Richard M. Nixon four years ago.

I have a large Currier Ives print that I would like to step into as Alice stepped into the mirror. It is called "The Season of Blossom" and in it every tree and bush is in bloom around a handsome old house on a hill, which is set back about 100 feet from a dirt road. A young woman holding a baby stands by a picket fence.
Acting as if he had just finished a dual course with Amy Vanderbilt and Dale Carnegie, Muhammad Ali signed yesterday for a 12-round fight with Floyd Patterson at Madison Square Garden, Aug. 28.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Although Senator George McGovern is still tantalizingly short of the marginal votes needed to make him certain of the Presidential nomination, political discussion has already turned to his selection of a running mate.
NEW DELHI, July 6 -- Kenneth B. Keating announced today that he would resign as Ambassador to India and return to the United States to campaign for the re-election of President Nixon.

One of 13 striking building trades unions -- Glaziers Local 1087 -- reached a tentative agreement yesterday with the Building Trades Employers Association that increases pay and benefits by 21 per cent over three years.
DETROIT, July 6 -- New-car and truck sales this year are headed toward 13 million, auto industry executives said after counting record first-half sales.

FORT ERIE, Ont., July 6 -- George (Bunky) Henry of Atlanta scored a 65 in the first round today to lead the Canadian open golf championship. The 28-year-old professional, a former stellar placekicker for Georgia Tech's football team and winner of the Canadian amateur golf title in 1965, as a collegian, held a one-stroke edge with his six-under-par round, a record for the redesigned Cherry Hill Golf Club course.
The first recommendation of the United Nations Conference on the Human Environment to be tested in the international marketplace has now been unconscionably, though not unexpectedly, rejected.
Mayor Lindsay had to be escorted by policemen last night through dozens of screaming pickets who denounced him for trying to build a low-income housing project in the Forest Hills section of Queens.

Yesterday was special in New York. It didn't rain. So the secretaries who brought their lunch to Bryant Park, the lovers who came to smooch and the park's resident eccentrics got a treat: a parade of raincoat fashions from London Fog.

The city's Social Services Department said yesterday that a breakdown in a computer had prevented the mailing of more than 10,000 supplemental welfare checks, causing considerable confusion at seven welfare centers and three arrests for disorderly conduct.
Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy charged again yesterday that the criminal courts were lax in the handling of cases involving attempts to bribe policemen.

Signalling a new tough policy against aerial hijackers, Gen. Benjamin O. Davis Jr., the Government's aviation security chief, last month advised the aviation industry to put greater reliance on the law-enforcement expertise of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. "These agents are not trigger-happy gun-slingers," he said, referring to the F.B.I. "They are well-equipped and highly trained professionals fully capable of responding to hijack and extortion incidents as circumstances warrant."

SAN DIEGO, Friday, July 7 -- A gunman hijacked a Pacific Southwest Airlines jetliner with 57 persons aboard late yesterday, forced it to land here, collected $455,000 ransom and took off again with three crew members and two male passengers aboard as hostages.

A 37-year-old Foreign Service officer, James E. Baker, will become the first black American diplomat on permanent assignment to the United States Embassy in South Africa. Mr. Baker, who joined the State Department in 1960, is now assigned to the embassy in Tokyo as economic and commercial officer, the same post he will hold in Pretoria.

Bill Rigney played eight seasons for the New York Giants and has been a big-league manager for 17 with the Giants, California Angels and Twins. He was earning $60,000; Quilici (pronounced "Quill-is-see") reportedly will receive a $10,000 raise over his coaching salary of $15,000.

Mark Donohue, winner of the Indianapolis 500 auto race on May 27, will undergo exploratory surgery on his left knee today to determine whether he suffered cartilage or ligament damage in a crash last Monday while he was putting his Porsche-Audi through a test drive.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn. -- The Supreme Court's holding that capital punishment, as presently administered in the United States, is unconstitutional "cruel and unusual punishment," may set the stage for a conservative law-and-order legislative reaction of unparalleled intensity.

MARION, Mass., July 7 -- With only 1.7 points separating Ed Bennett, today's winner, and Louis Nady in the Finn Olympic sailing trials, the stage is set for a dramatic showdown tomorrow between the two Californians.

AGANA, Guam, Saturday, July 8 (AP) -- A United States Air Force B-52 bomber with a crew of six crashed into the Pacific today, en route from Guam to a bombing mission over Vietnam, the Air Force announced here.

Nevertheless, a major advance has been made by the White House decision. The principle has now been established that the Chinese are entitled to buy products of advanced American technology even when -- as in the case of the 707's -- these products could have ancillary military significance.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The nation's unemployment rate declined in June after a long period of essential stability, but there was another strong rise in wholesale prices, the Labor Department reported today.

A $110-million-a-year gambling and betting syndicate operating throughout Brooklyn, Queens and Nassau County was reportedly broken up last night with the arrest of 21 persons, according to a spokesman for the Nassau County District Attorney, William Cahn.
BERLIN, July 7 (AP) -- The Soviet Union and East Germany signed an additional barter-trade agreement today, the official East German news agency, ADN, announced.
MANILA, July 7 (UPI) -- More than 70 persons have been killed in the southern Philippines in the last three days by what is believed to be a band of Moslem raiders.

It took more than two hours for the Newport Jazz Festival's second midnight jam session at Radio City Music Hall, held in the small hours of Friday morning, to get itself pulled together. But, shortly after 2 A.M., the enthusiastic crowd of 6,000 that filled the Music Hall heard the kind of rewarding jam-session blowing that rarely occurs anywhere, much less before an audience of 6,000.

LOS ANGELES, July 7 (UPI) -- United States District Court Judge Matt Byrne denied defense motions today to dismiss the charges against Daniel Ellsberg and ordered that his trial for theft of the Pentagon papers begin on Monday.
GOSHEN, N. Y., July 7 -- On race days here, stablehands still lead the horses down Main Street to the only sports facility in America registered as a national historic landmark.
PARIS, July 7 -- Western Europe is going through monetary and political turbulence that seems bound to weaken her thrust toward unity.
EUGENE, Ore., July 7 -- Jim Ryun survived his second test in the 1,500-meter run tonight, and Tom Hill, Fred Newhouse and Randy Matson set the stage for a series of world-record performances.

In your June 22 news story, which reported Detective Kathleen Conlon's testimony before the House Select Committee on Crime, you quoted her allegations regarding several New York City high schools, including Springfield Gardens High School, at which "as many as 50 per cent of the students were on heroin."

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) -- The rate at which Federal meat inspectors are finding illegal residues of a cancer-causing hormone in cattle livers is still increasing, the Agriculture Department said today.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 7 -- After a week of confusion over the championship chess match between Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky, Reykjavik is returning to its normal activities.
Two of the nation's largest banking concerns reported yesterday sharply contrasting performances in earnings during the first half of the year.
BONN, July 7 -- Chancellor Willy Brandt named Defense Minister Helmut Schmidt today to serve as Minister of Economics and Finance until the next national elections, expected in November.
LONDON, July 7 -- The David Brown Corporation, a major British engineering group, has sold its tractor manufacturing interests to Tenneco, Inc., of Houston for more than $33-million.
CHICAGO, July 7 (UPI) -- Major League baseball owners voted today to increase the commissioner's powers in disputes and to streamline their Player Relations Committee.

DETROIT, July 7 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People averted today a major fight with two of its long-time allies, the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith and the American Jewish Congress.

HARTFORD, July 7 -- A Federal District judge issued an injunction today against further construction of a $200-million superhighway running north through Fairfield County because, he said, it violated Federal environmental laws.

DETROIT, July 7 -- The General Motors Corporation asked the Price Commission today to allow a $90, or 2 per cent, price increase on 1973 cars and trucks. This is half the increase sought by other car makers.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. -- What is the dirtiest word in the English language today? It's a toss-up. Wife? Mother? Both send quivers of distaste up liberated noses. Who is the enemy? Man! Particularly man as husband, forger of the diabolical fetters of motherhood.

DURHAM, Conn., July 17 -It took Nelson Groh of Poland, Ohio, 25 minutes today to select a winner at the Kenilworth Kennel Club of Connecticut show, which drew 1,177 dogs to the fairgrounds. His choice was Mrs. Peggy Westphal's silver-buff, Ch. Sagamore Toccoa from Bedford, N. Y., the top-winning cocker spaniel in America and one of the leading performers of all breeds on the show circuit.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 7 -- Mrs. Billie Jean King has won her fourth Wimbledon title. In 50 nerve-racked minutes on the center court, the bustling 28-year-old from Long Beach, Calif., won from Evonne Goolagong of Australia, 6-3, 6-3, and avenged her semifinal loss here a year ago to the 20-year-old daughter of an aboriginal sheep-shearer.

PARIS -- Ngo Cong Duc, 36 years old, is a Roman Catholic from a prominent family in South Vietnam's delta. The ranking Catholic prelate in Vietnam, Archbishop Binh, is a relative. Mr. Duc's father was assassinated in 1953 by the Communist-led revolutionaries. He has been a Saigon newspaper editor and a member of the National Assembly.

TOKYO, July 7 (Reuters) -- The new Minister of International Trade and Industry, Yaukhiro Nakasone, said today that Japan should adhere to the fixed yen-dollar exchange-rate system and avert another revaluation of the yen.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 7 -- Frank Quilici's debut as manager of the Minnesota Twins was a roaring success on two counts tonight -- 19,514 customers, the biggest crowd of the season here, went through the turnstiles and Harmon Killebrew beat the New York Yankees with a two-run homer in the seventh inning.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 7 -- The new "prophet, seer and revelator" of the world's 3,090,953 members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints drives to his office at 8 A.M. daily in a Buick, wears natty but not gaudy dark blue suits and lives in a white brick New England style home on Salt Lake City's treelined Circle Way.

Karl Sweetan, a quarterback who announced his retirement from pro football two weeks ago, was seized yesterday when he attempted to sell a Los Angeles Rams playbook to the New Orleans Saints. He has played for both teams.

FORT ERIE, Ontario, July 7 -- Dave Hill described the course as "enjoyable and demanding" after his 66 today gave him a tie with Lou Graham for the 36-hole lead in the Canadian open golf championship.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- An International Business Machines Corporation scientist was granted a patent this week for a new kind of solar cell, described as far more efficient than earlier means of converting sunlight to electricity. It is likely to be useful in satellites and space ships.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Food and Drug Administration made public today evaluations of cold remedies that cast doubt on the effectiveness of most of the products in terms of their advertised claims.

WALTHAM, Mass., July 7 -Tom Losonczy, an 18-year-old Columbia University sophomore, captured all 14 of his bouts today at Bentley College to win the national saber title for men under 19 years of age. It was his second title in the last three years.
BRUSSELS, July 7 (AP) -- As of Monday, the European Common Market Commission will re-introduce 20 per cent customs duties on imports of beef and 16 per cent on live cattle from non-member countries.

LONDON, July 7 (UPI) -Chris Evert, the 17-year-old tennis star from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., who reached the Wimbledon semifinals in her first appearance here, flew home today.

MONTREAL, July 7 (Canadian Press) -- The governing committee of the Montreal Stock Exchange suspended today the membership of Edgar Holland after finding that his brokerage firm had violated exchange regulations during 1971.

MIAMI BEACH, July 10 -Gertrude Parker is 66 years old and a widow who raises cattle on a small farm in Modesto, Calif. BEIRUT, July 10 -- The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia has warned United States oil companies that the Government "is determined to take all necessary measures" to secure participation in their concession.
