MIAMI BEACH, July 11 -Emotional in a final staff meeting and stoical in a public withdrawal of his candidacy, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota wanted more than anything today to erase two unhappy impressions of his third and probably final Presidential race.
ROOSEVELT, N. J., July 11 (AP) -- It is hard to argue with city hall here, for the public servant at the other end of the telephone is often a machine.

A group of Manhattan businessmen pressing for stricter enforcement of traffic and parking regulations surveyed 24 East Side blocks yesterday and found that 30 per cent of the 1,026 automobiles parked in the area were parked illegally.

TEL AVIV, July 11 -- A military tribunal sentenced an Israeli New Leftist and reluctant army recruit today to eight months' imprisonment for balking at signing a pledge of loyalty to the Israeli armed forces. The case of the slightly built young man in black-rimmed glasses has aroused passions in a society where draft-dodging has been uncommon.

A 26 per cent reduction in taxicab robberies and a sharp drop in driver homicides were reported yesterday by Michael J. Lazar, chairman of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission, which began functioning a year ago, Mr. Lazar said robberies dropped from 3,153 in 1970 to 2,311 in 1971.

MIAMI BEACH, Wednesday, July 12 -- The Democratic National Convention rejected by an overwhelming majority early today a move by supporters of Gov. George C. Wallace to rewrite the party's platform along conservative, antibusing, pro-military lines.
Hubert Humphrey reached the end of the Presidential trail in Miami Beach yesterday and, like so many men before him in American history, he found there only a broken dream.
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 11 -- Soviet Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin is in California and will visit President Nixon at the Western White House tomorrow.

Johnny Robinson, whose carer dates to the founding of the American Football League in 1960, announced his retirement yesterday. The Kansas City Chiefs' defensive back, 33 years old, decided to quit because he had not recovered from a groin injury received in the playoff game against Miami last Christmas. Robinson, a Louisiana State alumnus, broke into pro football with the Dallas Texans, the franchise that moved to Kansas City in 1963.

MIAMI BEACH, July 11--George McGovern's real battle is now beginning. He has mastered the intricate techniques of the state primary elections, and the power struggles of the nominating convention here in Miami Beach, but now he has to console his defeated Democratic colleagues and win the allegiance of the majority of the voters in the nation.
MIAMI BEACH, July 11 -- The votes had just been cast that cost Eugene L. Wyman his seat in the California delegation to the Democratic National Convention.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) -- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has urged the states to use local credit bureaus to find welfare cheaters and track down deserting fathers.

MIAMI BEACH, July 11 -- At the end this morning, hundreds of delegates surrendered to their emotions. Anti - McGovern delegates watched months of work go down the drain with the roll-call on seating the pro-McGovern California delegation and could contain themselves no longer.
ALBANY, July 11 (UPI) -- Tickets for the richest lottery ever held in the United States will go on sale tomorrow.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 11 (UPI) -- The Hanoi radio said tonight that Vietcong leaders had elected a provincial People's Revolutionary Committee for Quangtri last month.

ACCRA, Ghana, July 11 -The red and black cloths that are symbols of mourning here still cling to a few of bustling Accra's army of scurrying taxis. But most of Ghana has quickly returned to routine following a weekend of ceremony devoted to the burial of Kwame Nkrumah, the charismatic and controversal first President of Ghana.

Reggie Jackson, the hardhitting Oakland A's outfielder, who has known baseball glory in his six major league seasons, spoiled a similar chance last night for Marty Pattin, the Boston Red Sox's journeyman right-hander.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Federal Power Commission, acting with unusual speed and without dissent, ruled today that Congress had not empowered it to prohibit unfair employment practices by utilities.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -The El Paso Natural Gas Company requested the Federal Power Commission today to reconsider the terms of its decision last month authorizing in principle the importing of Algerian natural gas to the United States under a 25-year contract.

The Colorado Interstate Corporation said yesterday that it had asked a Federal court for an injunction against Copaco, Inc and its affiliates to prevent them from seeking control of Colorado Interstate.
HARTFORD, July 11 -- The General Electric Company has been selected to make a yearlong study of the problem of what to do with the 10,000 tons of trash that accumulates each day in Connecticut.
MOSCOW, July 11 -- The Soviet Union, facing an increasing imbalance of trade with the United States, is pressing a sales campaign to broaden the American market for its goods.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 12 -- Reliable military sources here and on the northern front reported today that the South Vietnamese were not going to try to recapture the well-defended provincial capital of Quangtri at this time.

JERUSALEM, July 11 -- A leading Israeli general admitted today that he had fraudulently promised a suicide opportunity to the lone surviving Japanese terrorist who took part in the Tel Aviv airport massacre. He said he had given the promise in return for information from the prisoner during the first hours after the raid.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 11 -- The first game of the Bobby Fischer-Boris Spassky match for the world chess championship was adjourned tonight after 40 moves.

DETROIT, July 11 (UPI) -Michigan will file "emergency" appeals of two Federal court rulings that set in motion development of the largest crossdistrict school busing program in the nation, the state's two highest elected officers said today.

The Caterpillar Tractor Company had a 45 per cent increase in earnings on a sales gain of 11.7 per cent in the second quarter, lifting the halfyear net by 26 per cent and sales by 11 per cent over the 1971 period, all setting records, the producer of earthmoving machinery, construction and materials - handling equipment reported yesterday.

Phil Jackson, a part-timer until last season's playoffs, was rewarded by the Knicks with a $35,000 contract for the coming National Basketball Association campaign. With an average salary of about $70,000 a man, the New Yorkers are one of the sport's most generous teams, topped perhaps by only the Los Angeles Lakers.

A recent issue carried a troublesome letter by Ira Glasser, the New York Civil Liberties Union executive director. His view is that the Vietnam war is illegal, immoral and criminal and that protests against the war are not being listened to. He states that less temperate people must be frustrated and, if those in power do not listen, "people will stop talking" and this will be dangerous "to the basic structure of liberty."
WASHINGTON -- The greatest test of imagination for the Nixon Administration at the present time will be for it to negotiate a settlement of the Vietnam war while it thinks it is winning.

RYE, N.Y., July 12 -- The Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club crew of Oyster Bay, L.I., captained by Mrs. W. Perry Neff, recaptured the women's Long Island Sound championship off American Yacht Club today as the 39th annual Syce Cup regatta ended.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 12 -- Bobby Fischer lost the first game of his world championship chess match with Boris Spassky tonight after staging a 35-minute walkout.

The United States Olympic basketball team, which can't find anyone to play against on the mainland during the summer months, is leaving today for Honolulu,. which is dotted with Armed Forces bases and willing competitors.

With the announcement of United States grain sales to the U.S.S.R. and the sale of Boeing 707's to the People's Republic of China I think back on the "domino theory" argument of Dean Rusk and the Johnson Administration.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 12 -- Homeowners and businessmen in a six-state area damaged last month by Tropical Storm Agnes would receive up to $5,000 each in an outright grant from the Federal Government to make repairs to their property and replace damaged belongings, under legislation proposed today by President Nixon.

BOSTON, July 12 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit ordered the Government today to file a disclaimer stating that "electronic surveillance" had not been used in its case against a 30-year-old Harvard professor who has refused to answer certain questions before a grand jury investigating the release and distribution of the Pentagon papers.
Rudi Gernreich took his time about it, but he has finally joined the parade of fashion designers who have plunged into the home furnishings field.

HAMPTON BAYS, L.I., July 12 -- Three of the Democratic members of the Suffolk County Legislature said today that they would ask the County Board of Ethics to investigate the conduct of R. The State Department of Transportation called on Congress yesterday to increase transportation outlays to the state by at least 37 per cent.
The Elmendorf Farm's Queen's Mark contributed another one of her smashing successes in the $29,050 Astoria at Aqueduct yesterday.

In her home community of Carlisle, Mass., and throughout New England, Mrs. Marguerite Grant is known as a top breeder of Siberian huskies. Her dogs have won fame both in sled-racing and in the show ring.

The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had appointed an eightmember nominating committee to pick 20 candidates for a new board of governors under a plan of reorganization that is scheduled to become effective this fall.

Bursts of selling in CurtissWright and in airline issues jolted the stock market in late trading yesterday as prices fell again amid a pickup in the trading pace. Curtiss-Wright plunged 9 7/8 to 36 1/8.
Downtown-to-downtown air service, long a dream of busy commuters, became a reality yesterday with the inauguration of hourly seaplane flights between Manhattan and downtown Philadelphia.
A slate associated with Representative Charles B. Rangel claimed a sweep in voting results yesterday that would give it control of the often-warring Haryou community corporation.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has decided to go after a slice of the rapidly developing insurance market in Japan, it was disclosed yesterday.

ANAHEIM, Calif., July 12 -The New York Yankees ended their most successful trip of the season tonight by defeating the California Angels, 5-0, and reached two short-range goals -- the .500 mark in playing percentage and their third straight series victory in the West.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 12 -Thirty people were killed in fighting between the Kurds and the Iraq Army in northern Iraq earlier this month, according to informed travelers from Baghdad.
In extremely heavy trading, silver futures rose sharply yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange.

Marine Midland Banks, Inc., a big Buffalo-based bank holding companyy, reported yesterday that its net operating earnings in the first half of the year were $21.1-million, or $1.62 a share, essentially unchanged from the first six months of 1971.

The Loews Corporation announced yesterday that it had sold a block of 1 million shares of the Franklin New York Corporation -- the parent company of the $3.3-billion Franklin National Bank -- to Fasco International Holdings, A. G., which is wholly owned by Michele Sindona, an extremely wealthy, but littleknown, Italian financier.

GUATEMALA CITY, July 12 (Reuter) -- Gunmen assasinated four leaders of Guatemala's governing National Liberation Movement today and killed the seven-year-old son of one of them, police sources said here.

The International Paper Company had a 27 per cent increase in second-quarter earnings on a sales gain of 9 per cent, lifting half-year earnings by 30 per cent and sales by 9.5 per cent, the company reported yesterday.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 12 -- Pounding drums and gripping swords and flags, nearly 100,000 men marched throughout Northern Ireland today in a vivid display of Protestant power. The day was marked by violence.

Oscar M. Lazrus, secretary of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, took the occasion of his 85th birthday yesterday to announce that he was making a gift of $100,000 for a Center for Interreligious Affairs to combat anti-Semitism and bigotry.

LONDON, July 12 -- A Government committee proposed a series of measures today to safeguard individual privacy, including a law against private use of electronic and other devices.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it was studying the proposed settlement in the case in which National Student Marketing Corporation is accused of violation of securities laws.

Rooftop parking for 1,000 cars will be provided at the new passenger ship terminal under construction on the Hudson River between 47th and 52d Streets, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday. Two contracts totalling $4.3-million have been awarded for construction of the roofs of Piers 88, 90 and 92 to hold the cars. The terminal is scheduled for completion in the spring of 1974.
LONDON, July 12 (Reuters) -- Britain's floating pound gained strength on the London foreign-exchange market today, picking up half a cent to close at 2.4465 against the dollar.

MIAMI BEACH, July 12 -Senator George McGovern and black leaders who supported him have worked out an agreement that pledges the appointment of blacks to the Supreme Court, 10 per cent of Federal job patronage within the states and money for voter registration in black areas, in return for the leaders' backing of his candidacy for the Presidential nomination.
The United States Court of Appeals here yesterday upheld a lower court's rejection of two Indian tribes' claim to land in the New York counties of Madison and Oneida.
NEW DELHI, July 12 -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today ruled out an early return of the 93,000 Pakistani prisoners held in Indian camps for more than six months.

Mrs. Martha R. Wallace, vice president and executive director of the Henry Luce Foundation, Inc., has been elected a trustee of the Bowery Savings Bank. She is the first woman to hold this post in the bank's 138-year history.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI) -- George P. Shultz, Secretary of the Treasury, predicted today that retail meat prices in the United States would level off next month and then decline as a result of increased imports from foreign suppliers.

The City Planning Commission yesterday reluctantly approved an amended development plan cutting sharply the number of low-income units in Battery Park City, the huge housing development planned for Lower Manhattan along the Hudson River.

TEL AVIV, July 12 (AP) -A military court agreed today to admit in evidence a confession by Kozo Okamoto, the surviving member of the threeman Japanese terrorist squad responsible for the Tel Aviv airport massacre on May 30.

LONDON, Thursday, July 13 -- Leonid Tarassuk, curator of the department of European and American arms and armor in the Hermitage Museum, Leningrad, has been dismissed because he applied for a visa to Israel, according to a letter in The Times of London today.
A Federal judge in Philadelphia yesterday granted trustees of the bankrupt Penn Central railroad permission to reduce freight train crews from four men to three.

The nomination of Senator George S. McGovern for the Presidency of the United States by the Democratic National Convention is much more than a remarkable personal victory for a man of proven courage, determination and political skill. RICHMOND, July 12 (UPI) -The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit refused today to lower the bond of Arthur H. Bremer, the accused assailant of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama.

PARIS, July 12 -- Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann reported today on his return from a visit to Peking that Foreign Minister Chi Peng-fei of China accepted an invitation to Paris and would probably make the trip late this year.

CINCINNATI, July 12 (AP) -A three-judge Federal panel struck down as unconstitutional today an Ohio statute requiring a year's residency to become eligible for welfare relief.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -Senator George McGovern's over-all record in public life is basically that of a conventional liberal.
The newly restructured board of directors of the New York Stock Exchange convenes this afternoon for the first time -without a new chairman and with few indications of progress toward finding one.

The General Motors Corporation sought yesterday to softpedal the adverse reaction created by published reports of its studies of the Wankel engine. The stock of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation has fallen in one week from a new high of 59 1/4 to 36 1/8 in yesterday's trading on the Big Board.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -Statistics on serious crime around the country for the first quarter of this year registered an increase of 1 per cent over the like period last year. That is the lowest percentage increase for the quarter in 11 years.

PEKING -- There is a sense of anticipation in China this summer -- anticipation that by autumn there will be an announcement or an event clarifying what might be described as the third phase of the Cultural Revolution.

The "Open Skies" plan was conceived at a time when the strategic bomber was the only method of nuclear delivery.

The air-conditioning didn't work last night at the Mayfair Theater, a comfortable basement auditorium at 235 West 46th Street. But "Safari 300" worked well indeed. Much of this show, a selfstyled "musical experience of 300 years of black culture, song and dance," works brilliantly. See it.

Following thoughtful consultations with his parents and fiancee, David Wottle, the outstanding middle distance runner, decided yesterday upon the following course of action: He will be married this weekend and he will compete in both the 800-meter and 1,500-meter races in the Olympic Games in Munich.

HOUSTON, July 12 (UPI) -Lieut. Col. Alfred M. Worden of the Air Force, reprimanded yesterday for permitting the sale of unauthorized stamped and concealed envelopes that he and two other astronauts took to the moon last July on the Apollo 15 mission, will be reassigned from the astronaut corps to another position with the space agency, NASA announced today.

MIAMI BEACH, Thursday, July 13 -- George Stanley McGovern was proclaimed the Democrats' candidate for President here early this morning to complete a stunning sweep of the party's processes and national convention.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 12 (Reuters) -- South Africa gained re-admission to the Davis Cup tennis tournament today, and the agreement between Lamar Hunt's World Championship Tennis organization and the International Lawn Tennis Federation was ratified.

The Chicago Bears will be going to their training camp at Rensselaer, Ind., tomorrow with a new coach, Abe Gibron, and without an old quarterback, Jack Concannon. The 29-year-old Concannon, with eight pro seasons behind him, has nowhere to go except to check out an assortment of business enterprises that include the three North Side suburban restaurant lounges in which he has an interest.

The Stirling Homex Corporation asked the Federal District Court in Rochester, N.Y., yesterday to appoint a trustee under Chapter X of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The company had announced on Monday that it would file under the less stringent Chapter XI and thus seek to keep operating with Chapter XI protection from creditors.

The Rockefeller Foundation has made grants totaling more than $2-million to six organizations for theater activities, four of them based in New York. The grants are the largest quarterly appropriations for theater made by the foundation since its cultural development program began in 1963.

LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- The capacity of the jurors in the Pentagon papers case to read and comprehend the voluminous secret documents became an issue today as the trial judge questioned prospective jurors for the third day.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, July 13 -- Doug Sanders stormed the 18th hole three under par, heading for a two-stroke lead halfway through the British Open golf tournament, and he blew it today. He went from tee to bunker to deep rough to rough over the green to bunker again and he was finally in the hole with a triple-bogey 7.
LONDON, July 13 -- The British Government today vetoed two take-over bids for Glaxo, the parmaceutical and chemical manufacturing company.

Bobby Fischer's attorney flew last night to Iceland to try to get chess officials to lift yesterday's forfeit against the American grandmaster. If he does not succeed, the attorney said, he will sue to force them to lift the forfeit.

MIAMI BEACH, July 13 -- The Democrats came out of their convention in fairly good order, with George McGovern crying, "Come home, America!" In McGovern and Eagleton they have a ticket that runs no farther than from Missouri to South Dakota, but at least they avoided the worst of their nightmares, and they're not deceiving themselves about the magnitude of their problems.

NEWARK, July 13 -- Superior Court Judge Erwin S. Fulop rejected a defense motion today for the acquittal of Dr. E. Wyman Garrett and two other defendants on charges of interfering with the news-gathering activities of a New York Times reporter.

For a man who has fought only twice since 1969, Pedro Agosto of Puerto Rico and Oradell, N. J., is confident he will beat Floyd Patterson tonight in their 10-round heavyweight fight at the Singer Bowl in Flushing Meadow.

PIKIT, the Philippines, July 13 (AP) -- Along the road east of Cotabato the view of the verdant landscape includes water buffalo, farmers wading in rice fields and many laughing children. The traveler also sees old women selling boiled corn along the roadside for a penny an ear.

The ownerships of the Baltimore and Los Angeles franchises of the National Football League were traded yesterday in a deal that had no precedent in major professional team sports. The players and coaches were not affected and their affiliations will remain the same but the exchange permitted Carroll Rosenbloom, the longtime owner of the Colts, to leave Baltimore and also to save $4.4-million in capital gains taxes.
MIAMI BEACH, July 13 -- Two men arrested yesterday at Senator George McGovern's hotel here were identified today by the Secret Service as Wayne Harris Foster, 32 years old, and Jessie Dixon, 33.

Your June 25 editorial "Curbing Meat Prices" recommends ending the exemption of meat and other raw agricultural products from price controls. Are the farmers and the stock growers of America really making excess profits or creating inflation?

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 13 -- Some two weeks after its glittering Stravinsky festival ended in New York's State Theater, the New York City Ballet has brought it to the pastoral calm of the Saratoga Performing Arts Center.
In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

A telegram from President Nixon complimenting the efforts of the New York City police in reducing crime here was read by Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy to all members of the force in a message broadcast over police frequencies.

The present furor about food prices is unjustified and is based on incomplete knowledge of the facts of the costs of food production. The American housewife gets a bargain every time she shops at her supermarket.

MARSHALL, Mo., July 13 -- Miss Barbara Muffley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Thomas Muffley of Rochester, was married here this afternoon to Thomas Anthony Hughes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Thomas Hughes Jr. of Bronxville, N. Y., where the bridegroom's father is serving his second term as mayor.

A new state approach to the $1.7-billion-a-year Medicaid program for the poor was announced yesterday in a plan to tighten controls on use and costs of the program and also to emphasize preventive medical care.

CLAYVILLE, N.Y. July 13 (AP) -- Mrs. Allen Sheals of Allegany, who eliminated the defending champion, Dianne Wilde, in yesterday's first round, scored a double victory today to earn a semifinal spot in the 43d annual New York State women's amateur golf tournament.
The police reported yesterday that they still had no suspects in the murder of a business association official found bludgeoned to death, apparently with a brick, in his West Side apartment Monday.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy has decided to change the command structure of the detective force in a way that will put 12 key detective commanders in somewhat closer touch with individual sections of the city, high detective officers disclosed yesterday.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 13 -- President Nixon has instructed Henry A. Kissinger, his top foreign affairs adviser, to arrange briefings on foreign policy and intelligence matters for Senator George McGovern of South Dakota, the Democratic Presidential nominee.

BOISE, Idaho, July 13 -- The Boise Cascade Corporation announced today that it is considering a special charge -- all or most of which would be extraordinary -- totaling approximately $200-million against income.

HOUSTON, July 13 -- Two hijackers, one an Ethiopian citizen, surrendered today to a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent at a small airport south of Houston about 22 hours after they had commandeered a National Airlines jet while it was going from Philadelphia to New York.

TIMMENDORFER STRAND, West Germany, July 9 -- At the entrance to a public beach near here there is a sign that says it is forbidden "to build sandcastles at a distance of less than two meters from the foot of the dune with a diameter larger than 2.5 meters or a depth of more than .30 meters."

The television network of the Columbia Broadcasting System will change its mid-morning Monday-through-Friday programing in the fall, replacing reruns of former nighttime programs such as "The Beverly Hillbillies" with three new half-hour game shows.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 13 -- Judith Todd, 29-year-old daughter of the former Rhodesian Prime Minister, Garfield Todd, was released from restriction today. She boarded a flight to London from Johannesburg, South Africa, tonight.

People usually sue first and, if disappointed, carry their case to the Supreme Court. Maryann Clifford is different. Miss Clifford, who plans to enter law school this autumn, went to the United States Supreme Court first, seeking one of the summer messenger jobs customarily made available to law students.
WAYNE, N. J., July 13 -- The rains came again yesterday in what, to people living in the low-lying areas of this predominately middle-class township, is an old familiar story.
DETROIT, July 13 -- New-car dealers today reported 168,594 sales of United States -- type cars in the first third of July, or an average of 24,085 in each of the seven selling days.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 13 -- President Nixon signed legislation today establishing somewhat increased fees for the use of national parks and recreation areas, but also providing for free or reduced-rate use of these areas by the elderly.
Stock prices sank again yesterday, posting their fourth loss of the week and carrying the market below a critical "support" zone on the charts.

MIAMI BEACH, July 13 -- The New York delegation walked off the floor of the Democratic National Convention for 40 minutes tonight to protest the postponing of party reforms and the method of electing eight new members of the state committee to an expanded national party structure.

LONDON, July 13 (UPI) -- Britain earned a surplus of $37.5-million in its visible foreign trade with the rest of the world in June, official figures showed today. Exports set a record and imports turned down.

MIAMI BEACH, July 13 -- Thomas F. Eagleton was the first man to mark his Vice-Presidential selection as a surprise. "I'm flabbergasted," the boyish Senator from Missouri said today. Yet he was spotted some time ago by colleagues and the press gallery as one of the brightest and most ambitious young stars of the Senate, and a variety of subtle balances in his political profile suggest a casting director's ideal for a running mate.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Friday, July 14 -- Amid indications that talks to restore a cease-fire had been resumed, Northern Ireland was struck by another day of violence yesterday.
MIAMI BEACH, July 13 -- Lawrence F. O'Brien said tonight that "no one could convince" him to accept another term as chairman of the Democratic National Committee.
LONDON, July 13 -- After five months of acrimonious debate, the House of Commons approved tonight legislation to take Britain into the European Economic Community.

TOKYO, July 13 -- Trade talks between United States and Japanese officials scheduled for July 25-28 took on new importance today in the light of a statement by Japan's new Premier, Kakuei Tanaka, that he would "take command" of the Japanese delegation during the talks and might attend personally.
Vegetables have provided the inspiration for much of the jewelry designed by Judith Brown, a sculptor who lives and works on a hilltop in Reading, Vt.
ROME, July 13 -- Premier Giulio Andreotti's new Government, a coalition of centrist parties, won a vote of confidence in the Senate today, 163 to 155.

James J. Needham, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was named yesterday to be the first full-time, salaried chairman and chief executive officer of the New York Stock Exchange.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 13 -- Bobby Fischer remained in his hotel room today, refusing to show up for his scheduled game with Boris Spassky. He was declared the loser by forfeit and the score of this strange world championship chess match became 2 to 0 in favor of the Soviet titleholder.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 13 -- Une de Mai of France may have to be scratched from Saturday night's 14th annual International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway. The winner of last season's race was found this morning to be "tied up" with an accumulation of lactic acid in the muscles. (Lactic acid is the residue left in muscles after energy has been burned off, producing a condition of fatigue.)
DETROIT, July 13 -- The Chrysler Corporation reduced today its request for price increase for 1973 vehicles to $110 from $180.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 13 -- Two regulars remained absent as the New York Giants held their first workout today, but they both spoke to club officials by telephone and the officials aren't sure if one of them quit.

The pictures of Mother Goose nursery rhyme characters, made by nailing 10,129 pounds of colored corn cobs to the outside walls of one civic center, are being re placed by pictures on the theme, "Relaxation in South Dakota."

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- A 34-year-old Washington lawyer was found in contempt of court today for refusing to answer a series of grand jury questions about the June 17 raid on the offices of the Democratic National Committee.

Eagleton of Misouri as his running mate on the Democratic ticket.

The Board of Higher Education was told last night that the city's elementary schools and high schools should turn out better-prepared students instead of sending on to the City University young people who need mass remedial-education programs.
TRENTON, July 13 (AP) -- A private detective of Roseland was indicted today on charges of violating the state's wiretapping law in matrimonial investigations.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI) -- George A. Haag, former administrative assistant to Representative James M. Collins, Republican of Texas, was found guilty today of 23 charges in an $18,000 payroll kickback scheme.

I noted in a recent letter the remarks of one of your readers concerning the current development of shopping malls and her observation that the growth of shopping malls does occur concurrently with the growth of cultural facilities.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Pierre A. Rinfret, the economist who heads Rinfret-Boston Associates, Inc., a consulting company, will be an economic consultant to President Nixon during his campaign for re-election, it became known today.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., July 14 -- Moments after Senator George McGovern and the Democratic National Committee chose her as the new chief of the party here today, Mrs. Jean Westwood ran into the first bit of what she expects will be a mountain of problems.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 14 -- A five-story Sutton Place town house built more than 50 years ago for the daughter of J. Pierpont Morgan, the financier, has been offered by the owner to the United Nations as a residence for the Secretary General.

To an Englishman surveying American politics there is something profoundly ironic in the policies advocated by Senator McGovern in the recent primary campaigns. To Americans they may seem novel, extraordinary, perhaps even exciting; but to anyone acquainted with the recent history of Britain or Sweden they are depressing familiar.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation realized an increase of 14.4 per cent in second-quarter earnings on a sales gain of 7.6 per cent, lifting the half-year net by 19.8 per cent and sales by 7.6 per cent to mark the fifth consecutive record for these periods, according to yesterday's report by D. C. Burnham, chairman.

The bank merger front was active yesterday. In New York, the First National City Corporation, whose principal subsidiary, the First National City Bank is one of the nation's largest consumer lenders, announced an agreement to acquire the Acceptance Finance Company, a St. Louis-based small-loan company, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 (AP) -- An appeal by United Financial Group, Inc., from an order enjoining its continued operation and placing it under a receiver has been taken under consideration by the Ninth United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

Basil A. Paterson, elected yesterday as the vice chairman of the Democratic party, was the first black to run for statewide office in New York. He was the party's candidate for Lieutenant Governor in 1970.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The recent political campaigns sharply increased the truancy rate of some New York Representatives on House roll calls during the first half of the year.
Bishop W. Ralph Ward Jr. of Syracuse has been appointed the new Bishop of the New York Area of the United Methodist Church.
LEMA PLATFORM, in the Gulf of Mexico, July 13 -- This is a subtropical island inhabited by 26 men.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had agreed to defer its expulsion of Robert W. Stark Jr., as a member of the exchange, and of Robert W. Stark Jr. Inc., as a member firm, for one week until July 24.

MIAMI BEACH, July 14 -- Mrs. George McGovern said today that she "would like to be a very activist First Lady and I intend to be." She said she wanted to serve as the advocate in the White House for the children of America.

It was a perfect day for a children's outing in Riverside Park, one that might be remembered thoughtfully in years to come. It was sunny, with a cooling breeze off the Hudson, as 25 youngsters gathered around a tree-shaded, seldom-noticed gravesite 100 yards north of Grant's Tomb.
MIAMI BEACH, July 14 -- It was like two different conventions.
The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that college students must be allowed to register and vote in their college towns.

The President's goal of a politically balanced Supreme Court may have had some theoretical appeal among those who see the world entirely as a giant scale on which liberal and conservative views ought to neutralize each other. In practice, the effect of this balancing seems to be to create a sharply divided Court. Important cases involving civil rights, civil liberties and capital punishment have been decided by the narrowest of majorities.
DETROIT, July 14 (AP) -- Auto production was up 3,000 units this week because of continuing shutdowns and vacations, the trade paper, Automotive News, reported today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 15 -- South Vietnamese marines trying to complete the encirclement of Communist-occupied Quangtri reportedly fought a three-hour battle yesterday two to four miles northeast of the city.

MADRID, July 14 -- The European Common Market has become one of the most powerful factors for political change in Spain since Generalissimo Francisco Franco founded his regime in 1939 after victory in the civil war.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, July 14 -- North Korea gave a strong indication today that it wanted to turn the proposed North-South Red Cross talks on reuniting separated Korean families into some sort of political talks.

MIAMI BEACH, July 14 -- Delegates to the Democratic National Convention dispersed today to all parts of the country in the same peaceful and orderly manner that characterized a week that was almost all business and very little play.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission reported today its $36,000-a-year director of security had been "placed on leave without pay" pending the outcome of an investigation of allegations that he borrowed more than $100,000 from other commission employes and has not paid it back.

The United States National Bank in San Diego -- which is headed by C. Arnholt Smith, long-time friend and confidant of President Nixon -- said that it had acquired substantially all of the $95.5-million in assets of the Beverly Hills Fidelity Bank in exchange for assumption of its liabilities, including its deposits.
KABUL, Afghanistan, July 9 -- The old man nudged his mule, laden with grapes, through the busy bazaar. The turban-like cloth he wore loosely around his head nodded with each slow step.
Slithery princess dresses. Quilted jackets. Pants with pleats and high-rise waistlines.
Pop music moved into the Garden State Arts Center in Holmdel, N. J., Thursday night with the arrival of The Carpenters for a three-day engagement.

Trans World Airlines has agreed to pay the United States Government $87,000 for failing to inform more than 500 passengers that they were entitled to free transportation after being denied passage on flights for which they held reservations.

Wall Street reacted with approval yesterday to the selection of James J. Needham, a commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to become the first full-time salaried chairman and chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- A two-way cable television system that was given a tryout in Manhattan last year was patented this week by Joseph H. Beck, vice president of Video Information Systems, Inc., New York. Patent 3,676,580 covers the key instrument -a combination receiver, transmitter and tuner called a transponder -- and its operation in the network.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 14 -- The Western White House announced today that John Hay Whitney, the Communications industry executive, had resigned as a member of the board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.
State Supreme Court Justice Joseph P. Pfingst was sentenced yesterday to four months in jail and placed on probation for the rest of a three-year term for his conviction of bankruptcy-fraud charges.

MIAMI BEACH, July 14 -- The Democratic National Committee chose as its chairman today Mrs. Jean Westwood of Utah, a key organizer of Senator George McGovern's successful pursuit of the party's Presidential nomination.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 14 (Reuters) -- Iceland today published regulations extending her fishing limits to 50 nautical miles from 12 miles effective Sept. 1. Publication of the regulations follows the breakdown of talks between Icelandic officials and a British delegation.

A subtle trend toward erosion of the Bill of Rights is among the points of concern raised by the shift in the Supreme Court. Specifically, the decision denying reporters the right to refuse to reveal their sources of confidential information to a grand jury reflects, as Justice Stewart pointedly observed in his sharp dissent, "a disturbing insensitivity to the critical role of an independent press in our society."

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 14 -- A four-man committee voted today to uphold the decision of Lothar Schmid, the referee in the world chess championship match here, that Bobby Fischer, the American challenger, had forfeited yesterday's game to Boris Spassky, the Soviet titleholder.

Declarers who curse the fates because all the outstanding trumps turn out to be in one hand should remember that a foul division can be just what is needed. A case in point is the diagramed deal, which helped Jo Morse of Silver Spring, Md., and Helen Utegaard of Bethesda, Md., win a recent regional title.

There is a verbal sketch by a contemporary of Denis Diderot descanting in old age on a bewildering variety of topics in his usual mercurial and volatile way to a young man whom he had never seen before and who had dropped by only to pay homage to a revered elder. It is a charming and vivid piece with just enough malice to add savor.

Of course "there just isn't enough gold in the world to finance the immense boom in trade," as C. L. Sulzberger points out [column June 30]. How could there be with the price of gold held down by official decree while the cost of goods and services soared into the stratosphere? The cost of mining precious metals is no exception.
ROME, July 14 -- For the first time since fall, Italy has a fully functioning Government -- but the odds are it won't last long.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the United States had agreed to resume economic aid to Yemen.
ALGONA, Iowa -- Egypt can claim the wonders of the pyramids, Texas has a resplendent Presidential library that outdoes all others. But Iowa claims the world's only "million-dollar toilet."

A shadow roll on a horse that has been afraid of shadows proved most effective once more in the case of Robert Dotter's Dream of Kings at Aqueduct yesterday. The 5-year-old son of Saidam, opposing a small but formidable field in the feature race on the card, went on to take the seven-furlong sprint by a head.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 14 -- Tomorrow night's $125,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway is expected to wind up with only six starters. Keystone Hilliard, one of the three American representatives listed for the 14th annual 1 1/4-mile event, was scratched today and Une de Mai of France is almost certain to be withdrawn tomorrow morning.

HAMPTON BAYS, L. I., July 14 -- Despite the payment of $7.5-million for 11,000 feet of oceanfront property at Tiana Beach, Suffolk County still does not have clear ownership of the 295 acres of parkland.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The United States is in an extraordinary position in the latest international monetary flareup: Its currency is the one under attack and yet there is little or nothing it can do, wants to do or needs to do.
Anthony F. Zaleski has been elected executive vice president of Cooper-Jarrett, Inc.

The Times notes [news story July 3] that "Wall Streeters" are alarmed by George McGovern. Apparently they believe that his good prospects are responsible for the current market weakness. They also believe, his economic proposals would, if realized, cripple the nation's economy.
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 14 -- President Nixon issued today a proclamation designating September as national voter registration month.
Arthur F. Leiper demonstrates in his June 24 letter, "Aid to Parochial Schools," that he knows nothing about the great organization he slanders, the Brooklyn Sunday School Union.
LONDON, July 14 (AP) -- Banks throughout Europe today reluctantly bought $1.5-billion to shore up the dollar against heavy attacks by traders.
Twelve new issues bowed this week in public trading on the over-the-counter market and by the close yesterday most of them were being quoted at prices somewhat above their offering price.

The Minister of Colleges and Universities in Ontario has begun an investigation of Philathea College, an unaccredited religious college that has been granting doctoral degrees, to determine if its charter should be revoked.

Last Nov. 23, a Trans World Airlines jet arrived in New York from Paris with about 100 passengers and, among other things, 25 cases of Beaujolais wine. Since the air freight on a bottle of Beaujolais is probably three or four times the retail profit, there had to be some other reason for flying it from France.

A mysterious oil spill lightly soiled a five-mile stretch of Fire Island's Great South Beach yesterday between the communities of Saltaire and Sailors Haven, but the Coast Guard, with the help of the Town of Islip, had the beach cleaned up by nightfall.

William J. Levitt, who 25 years ago transformed a Long Island potato field into the largest experiment in instant mass housing anywhere (and built the 1,882 houses for an estimated $11.5-million), has come up with something else to talk about -- his yacht.
WATERBURY, July 14 (AP) -- Thirty-five Connecticut newspapers have appealed a state order barring the use of separate male and female designations in help-wanted advertisements.
For the first time this week the stocks on the American Stock Exchange edged upward yesterday. As measured by the Amex index the rise was 0.05 with the close at 26.95.
We talked to William H. Tehan of P. R. Herzig Co. at lunch the other day and realized once again that he's no man to talk with on an empty stomach.
The First National City Bank and the Irving Trust Company, as expected, yesterday raised their "floating" prime rates on business loans to 5 1/2 per cent, effective for the week beginning Monday.

MILWAUKEE, July 14 (AP) -- Jim Colbert shaved six strokes from par in his first eight holes today, finished with a 67, and gained a share of the lead with George Johnson after the second round of the $125,000 Greater Milwaukee open golf tournament. Colbert and Johnson each had a total of 133.
Bobby Fischer would never be happy playing chess with the sets collectors now prize most highly, the 18th-century examples by Wedgwood and Meissen.

ALBANY, July 14 (AP) -- A court proceeding was used by New York State today to push through scheduled payroll penalties despite a union move to have them held up until a case involving Easter weekend strikers was straightened out.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, July 14 -- The National Assembly approved the peace agreement with India early this morning, paving the way for a mutual withdrawal by armed forces from territory occupied along the Pakistani border since the two-week war in December.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel D. Proctor, a professor of theology at Rutgers University, was elected yesterday to take the place of the late Adam Clayton Powell Jr. as pastor of the 164-year-old Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem.

The 300 people who are here from all over the United States and Canada for the annual convention of the International Fire Buffs Associates, Inc., say they don't really want a big fire to break out in New York, but if there has to be one, they hope it comes now while they are here to "buff" it.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 14 -- British soldiers fought fierce gun battles with the Irish Republican Army here today after occupying Roman Catholic strongholds during the night. In 24 hours of almost continuous violence, nine persons were killed, four of them British soldiers.

LOS ANGELES, July 14 -- A panel of prospective jurors that had initially "appalled" defense lawyers in the Pentagon papers case indicated today under questioning criticism of the Vietnam war and the Government's security classification system.

Faced with what she termed" a tremendous philosophical dilemma," Mrs. Olga Connolly charged yesterday that United States Olympic Committee officials were treating women track and field athletes "like sheep."
MOSCOW, July 14 -- A high Siberian regional official has called on China to renew the good-neighborly relations that once linked his territory, Khabarovsk, with Manchuria, across the Amur River.
An experimental car, built by students at City College and equipped with both an electric motor and a gasoline engine, was unveiled here yesterday.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 14 -- John B. Connally, the Texas Democrat who was President Nixon's Treasury Secretary, announced today that he would support Mr. Nixon's re-election and spend most of his time until November attempting to persuade other Democrats to do likewise.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., July 14 -- The president of a Long Island dental supply company was held in $100,000 bail in Suffolk County District Court today on charges of absconding with $410,000 of his company's funds.
SAN DIEGO, July 14 -- Dave Schneck, the newest Met, had two reasons to celebrate after his major league debut tonight.
LONDON, July 14 (UPI) -- The daughter of the former Prime Minister of Rhodesia released after six months' detention with her father, arrived in Britain today.

The trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company are going to have to use the last $25-million of a $100,-million borrowing they made last year to meet payrolls falling due later this month and in August.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, July 14 -- In a storybook finish that defies belief, Lee Trevino leads the British Open at 207 with a day to go. He is a stroke ahead of Tony Jacklin and six strokes ahead of Jack Nicklaus, whose improbable dream of the grand slam faded with a routine par-round of 71 while the two leaders were taking the course apart.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) -- The Administration will limit exports of cattle hides in an effort to curb rising prices of shoes and other leather products, Government sources said today.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif. -- Is Siberia's famed Lake Baikal on the way to becoming another Lake Erie, a dying lake?

The stock market finally scored its first gain of the week yesterday, helped in part by the improved profits of several computer manufacturers and by a modest rally in the recently buffeted airlines and some glamour issues.

Mayor Lindsay returned yesterday from the Democratic National Convention in Miami Beach, saying that most of the New York delegation had been strangers to him, that he did not even know who would run Senator George McGovern's campaign in New York State, and that no one had asked him to take any special role in it.

Despite the petulant forty-minute protest walkout by the New York delegation, there is scant watching or viewing the Democratic National Convention's postponement of far-reaching reforms in the party's structure and operations as a capitulation by Senator McGovern to Old Guard elements. Rather, it was a concession to true democratic procedure and an expression of decent regard for the millions of Democrats who did not happen to be in Miami Beach.

The New York Yankees, who had been doing well for the past month, bumped heads with the American League's strongest team last night and wound up losing a double-header to the Oakland A's, 9-3 and 1-0.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, July 15 (Reuters) -- The Libya radio broadcast a recorded speech by Col. Muammae el-Qaddafi last night apparently with the aim of quashing rumors that the Libyan leader had been jailed after an extremist coup.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Senator William Proxmire accused the Pentagon today of allowing the Sperry Rand Corporation to reap large profits at no risk by letting it run an ammunition plant on the basis of guaranteed cost-plus profit.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 14 -- President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto's hometown, Larkana, was the scene today of the latest outbreak of the violence that has torn Sind, the main province of Pakistan, for a week.
GENEVA, July 14 -- A band of young Swiss anarchists has established links with similar bands in West Germany and Berlin, Hans Walder, the Swiss Attorney General, said today.

BOSTON, July 14 (AP) -- An aide to Senator Hubert H. Humphrey in the Senator's unsuccessful campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination said today that he would work for the re-election of President Nixon.
A State Supreme Court justice yesterday upheld the right of a mental patient at Bellevue Hospital to refuse electroshock treatment that had been prescribed by the hospital's physicians.

Following are excerpts from transcripts of speeches early yesterday morning to the Democratic National Convention in Miami Beach by Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Senator Thomas F. Eagleton of Missouri, the Vice-Presidential nominee, as recorded by The New York Times.
WESTFIELD, N.J., July 14 -- Violence erupted for the second successive evening here last night as black youths smashed windows in a dozen stores in this wealthy Union County suburb.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 14 -- The American Committee on Africa predicted today that new shipments of Rhodesian chrome and nickel would arrive in United States ports this month in violation of a Security Council embargo on trade with Rodesia.

The reviving health of the computer industry was attested to yesterday by the release of sharply higher earnings reports by the International Business Machines Corporation, Honeywell, Inc., and the Burroughs Corporation for the second quarter and first half of 1972.

CLEVELAND, July 14 (UPI) -- The United Transportation Union notified trustees of the Penn central Transportation Company today that it had granted strike authorization against the carrier in a dispute over crew sizes. No strike date was announced.

HARTFORD, July 14 -- With an unexpected surplus of $30-million in Connecticut's treasury this year, Gov. Thomas J. Meskill proposed today that the state sales tax, at 7 per cent the highest of any state in the Union, be rolled back to 6.5 per cent, where it was two weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Administration has requested the airlines for new measures to prevent weapons from being brought aboard airplanes in carry-on luggage and several airlines have taken steps to comply.

Nine films -- all of those that teamed Katharine Hepburn and the late Spencer Tracy -- will be shown at the Lincoln Center Library and the Museum for the Performing Arts, starting Sept. 13, as a benefit for the library.

BRANDS HATCH, England, July 14 -- The big tent with the clean windows near the entrance did little business today, but its very presence at the British Grand Prix marks a new attempt to increase the popularity of motor racing and empty the pockets of Britons.

PITTSBURGH, July 14 (AP) -- A Federal judge today found the National Gypsum Company in criminal contempt of court for its reluctance to produce company records subpoenaed by a grand jury investigating alleged price-fixing in the gypsum industry.

NEWARK, July 14 -- Arnold M. Hess, former secretary of the Board of Education here, testified today that two defendants charged with forcibly taking the wallet and notebook of New York Times reporter Fox Butterfield were not the same men he saw reaching over the shoulder of the news man at a turbulent school board meeting here 15 months ago.
MOSCOW, July 14 -- Premier Aziz Sidky of Egypt left today after a two-day visit in which he reviewed Soviet economic and military aid and the situation in the Middle East.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 14 (AP) -- Gov. George C. Wallace, his political future still in doubt, entered a rehabilitation center today for four weeks of intensive therapy aimed at making him physically independent.

The House Select Committee on Crime recently conducted hearings on drug abuse in the New York City schools. Although estimates of the extent of drug use varied, virtually all witnesses agreed that a drug epidemic was engulfing the New York City schools. Further, they concurred that this menace had cut across racial and economic lines, afflicting middle-class and ghetto school alike.

Erik Bruhn's staging of "La Sylphide," which was re-stored to the American Ballet Theater repertory at the New York State Theater last night, is a most elegant and eloquent version of this old Danish ballet.

MIAMI BEACH, July 14 -- Even George McGovern's people say frankly that he can be given no more than an outsider's chance of defeating the incumbent President. But it is important to distinguish that kind of realism from the orotund funeral orations for the Democratic party that some old political hands and commentators have been delivering here in Miami.

In perpetrating a revolution, there are two requirements: someone or something to revolt against and someone to actually show up and do the revolting. Dress is usually casual and both parties may be flexible about time and place but if either faction fails to attend, the whole enterprise is likely to come off badly. In the Chinese Revolution of 1650 neither party showed up and the deposit on the hall was forfeited.

The only known eyewitness to the 1968 Christmas Eve slaying of an East Side pimp and one of his prostitutes yesterday identified Patrolman William R. Phillips -- a key informer and witness for the Knapp Commission -- as the murderer.

Helen Torr, who died in 1967 at the age of 81, was known more as the wife of the late American artist Arthur Dove than as a painter in her own right. She had few exhibitions during her lifetime and they usually met with a succinct criticism that underscored her esthetic dependence on her husband.

MIAMI BEACH, July 14 -- New York delegates failed early today to select new Democratic National Committee members from the state in the confusion surrounding their walkout from the convention floor to protest the allocation of committeemen.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- A Federal District judge issued a ruling here today that could exempt some 14 million relatively low-paid workers from wage control.

Major-league baseball history was made in Detroit last night when brothers worked behind the plate for the first time as Kansas City cooled off the Tigers, the American League Eastern Division leaders, 1-0. Detroit had won five straight games.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 14 (Reuters) -- A court in central Thailand has sentenced a young American Mormon missionary and a friend to six months' imprisonment each for sacrilege, official provincial sources announced today.
BRUSSELS, July 14 (Reuters) -- Belgium today published a plan to eliminate the dollar as a reserve currency.

GOPPINGEN, West Germany, July 11 -- This hotbed of rural south German conservatism, where a cry of "ami go home!" was rarely raised in 27 years of American military presence, is up in arms against the United States Army.

MIAMI BEACH, July 14 -- Mrs. Martha Clampitt McKay of North Carolina had a drink with a national polling expert Tuesday afternoon to find out how the country felt about abortion. Louis Harris, the pollster, told her that the majority of the voters in the South and Midwest were against it.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 14 -- Six national leaders of the Vietnam Veterans Against the War were indicted today on charges that they had conspired to disrupt the Republican National Convention next month with firebombs and shootings.

TOKYO, July 14 -- A reader of the Japanese press or of dispatches about this island power might conclude that from mid-June to mid-July the Japanese were engrossed in the election of a new premier after the post had been held for nearly eight years by a man who had lately become increasingly unpopular.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 14 (AP) -- Yves-Michel Dumont, a French photographer released by the North Vietnamese yesterday after more than three months in captivity, said today that two American advisers had been captured with him and that he had seen a third captive American in Cambodia.

MONTCLAIR -- Frederick H. Sontag spent most of his time two weeks ago commuting between his home here and the Democratic party's Credentials Committee in Washington and pronounced himself "frustrated."

FLEMINGTON -- Harold Kitchin wasn't too busy at the window of the Flemington Agricultural Market Cooperative Association livestock market, checking off the cows, bull and calves as they were unloaded from farmers' trucks and tugged into rows of cobwebbed stalls last Monday.

The burly chauffeur who was with Thomas Eboli when he was murdered told the police yesterday that shots from a passing truck had killed the gangland chieftain as he was about to re-enter his blue Cadillac after making a midnight visit in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.

Blackfin, a 73-foot ketch skippered by Kenneth Demeuse of San Francisco, was reported 100 miles from the finish yesterday and leading the 2,700-mile yacht race from Bermuda to Bayona, Spain, according to radio reports received here by Sid Rogers, chairman of the race committee.

It is summertime on Staten Island, which makes it different from summertime in other places in New York. It is greener, quieter and more open on Staten Island, and for years people from other parts of the city, who think of Staten Island as being very nearly bucolic, have been spending their summers there.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 17 -- Bobby Fischer today won the third game of the world championship chess match without even being there. It was his first victory in the match and the first time he had ever defeated Boris Spassky.

A Staten Island ferryboat, crowded with homebound commuters, rammed into its slip at St. George late yesterday afternoon, injuring eight passengers slightly. The boat and the slip were damaged, but service was expected to be normal this morning.

The BankAmerica Corporation, San Francisco, and the Continental Illinois Corporation -- respectively the parent companies of the nation's largest and ninth-largest banks -- reported higher earnings yesterday for the second quarter and first half of 1972.

The Bay Ridge, Sunset Park and Gowanus sections of Brooklyn were plunged into darkness last night when the Consolidated Edison Company shut off electrical power to avoid "permanent damage to the network" after feeder cables had failed.

LONDON, July 17 -- The financial leaders of the six present and four future members of the European Common Market met here today and agreed on eight basic objectives for the reform of the world's monetary system.

PRAGUE, July 17 (Reuters) -- Thirteen prominent supporters of Alexander Dubcek, the liberal former leader of the Czechoslovak Communist party, went on trial in Prague city courts today.

LOS ANGELES, July 17 -- After Rusty Staub injured his right hand swinging at a pitch, Dr. Harold Brelsford, the Houston team physician, gave him a shot of cortisone and said, "At the worst, he'll be out three days."

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 -- The Federal Government took over all meat inspection functions in Pennsylvania today after the Department of Agriculture said state inspections had become too few and too lax to comply with the Wholesome Meat Act of 1967.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission reported today that its $250-million atom-smasher machine at Batavia, Ill., had attained record energies far beyond what scientists originally had hoped.
TRENTON, July 17 -- Here is how the New Jersey Assembly voted today on the income tax bill.

GUATEMALA, July 16 -- A visitor casually reading Guatemalan newspapers in the last week noted that a 14-year-old girl had been strangled, a man murdered with a machete, two farm workers blown up by a hand grenade thrown at them, and a number of other residents stabbed, kicked, robbed or kidnapped.

They were lionized on the sports pages in lush verbiage and the undisputed master of purple prose was George Trevor. LONG BEACH, Calif., July 17 (AP) -- Roman Gabriel, quarterback of the Los Angeles Rams, suffered a collapsed lung today.

ATTICA, N. Y., July 17 (AP) -- About 900 inmates at the State Correctional Facility here refused to leave their cells today, but created no disorder. According to Ernest L. Montayne, superintendent of the prison. Mr. Montayne said the prisoners were primarily protesting the layoff of a temporary nurse hired after last September's riot in which 43 persons died.
CANTON, China -- The Cultural Revolution is over yet not over; it has changed many things; it is now in a stage which I can best describe as mature assessment.

Fifty years ago H. G. Wells, the British polymath and amateur historian, was able to compress the history of the world up to 1920 into one volume of 1,171 pages weighing 3 pounds 3 ounces. The book was "The Outline of History, Being a Plain History of Life and Mankind." It cost $5.

In a tiny bedroom at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn a 34-year-old alcoholic drinks two and a half ounces of bourbon every two hours. Through earphones he listens to a series of clicks while electrodes taped to his scalp monitor the responses of his brain to the sounds.

After presenting the jury with a week of witnesses who chronicled the alleged events that led to the 1968 Christmas Eve slayings of a pimp and a prostitute, the prosecution in the trial of William R. Phillips began yesterday to try to tie the remaining threads in the case together.

Sulzberger's July 9 column, "The Red Hand of Ulster," may I ask if his assertion that "in the South, Protestants are second-class citizens; in the North, Catholics are second-class citizens" means that the Irish Republic's Deputy Prime Minister (Childers) and Ambassador to Washington (Warnock) are second-class citizens because they are Protestants?

Arthur T. Roth, who built the Franklin National Bank into the 18th largest bank in the nation before he was ousted as chairman two years ago, yesterday called on the New York State Superintendent of Banks to examine closely the recent purchase of 1 million shares of the bank's parent holding company by an Italian financier.
Eight feature films directed by John Huston will be shown free on a first-come-first-served basis next Tuesday over a 14-hour period at the Columbia II Theater, Second Avenue and 64th Street.
The National General Corporation, in a surprise step, disclosed in Los Angeles yesterday that three of its top officers had submitted their resignations.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- A spokesman for Representative Ford said that the Republican leader's statement, made at a joint news conference July 8, accurately reflected what was told to Mr. Ford and Representative Boggs during their talks with high Chinese leaders.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The harsh opposition of George Meany to the Presidential candidacy of Senator George McGovern is creating widespread confusion, deep cleavages and spreading dissension within organized labor.

PEKING -- A sign at the entrance to the National Fine Arts Exhibition here, the first of its kind in years, declares the exhibition's purpose: to show the faithful adherence of Chinese artists to Chairman Mao Tse-tung's revolutionary line in art. And it certainly does.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The income of the median American family rose above $10,000 for the first time last year, but the gain was wiped out by inflation, the Census Bureau reported today.

CRYSTAL LAKE, Iowa, July 17--The first Sorensons arrived here early yesterday morning to stake out a prime picnic spot at the town park. They lined up 12 green picnic tables in a single row, covered them with plastic tablecloths, then turned on the coffee.

The upturn late last week on the American Stock Exchange shares was shortlived; and shares resumed their decline yesterday, taking the index down to 26.80, off 0.15.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Mayor Richard J. Daley promised today to support all Democratic candidates in the November election, but his remarks left doubts as to the extent of his backing for Senator George McGovern, the party's Presidential nominee.

WESTBURY, L. I. July 17 -- Une de Mai, the French-bred trotting queen whose start in last Saturday night's $125,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway was canceled by an 11th-hour decision by officials of the State Harness Racing Commission, will get her chance here in a closingnight, $150,000 three-horse invitation race next Saturday.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee decided in April to seek a slower growth in the monetary "aggregates" even at the cost of some rise in short-term interest rates, it was disclosed today.
TRENTON, July 17 -- Gov. William T. Cahill's legislative drive for tax reform was defeated tonight when the Assembly overwhelmingly rejected his proposed state income tax.
A feeble morning rally in the stock market fizzled out in the afternoon yesterday and turned into a general retreat that carried most market indicators close to their lows for the year.

The referendum to authorize an Appellate Term Court for Nassau and Suffolk Counties, which is to be on the November ballot, will certainly be convenient for the lawyers concerned. Indeed, most lawyers are asked to campaign actively for this referendum. Yet its defeat should unequivocally apprise the lawyer-legislators that the voters expect something better in court reorganization and not just more of the same.
TRIPOLI, Libya, July 17 (Reuters) -- Libya's new Cabinet held its first meeting here today under Premier Jallud to discuss Government policies.

MANA, Mali, July 13 -- Dira Doumbia, a wiry 29-year-old peasant, hopes to marry in the fall and buy some new clothes. His cousin Bronlaye, 25, has bought a transistor radio, has recently taken a second wife and is saving to buy a pair of oxen.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 17--Since starting his professional football career as the No. 1 draft choice of the New York Jets in 1964 and earning American Football League rookie-of-the-year honors the same season, Matt Snell has had to restart his career twice.
A major restructuring of the American Broadcasting Company's broadcast division was announced yesterday by Elton H. Rule, president of A.B.C., Inc.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz moved in Manhattan Supreme Court yesterday to halt what he charged were violations of state antitrust law by the Mobil Oil Corporation.

The Board of Education, in a list submitted to the United Federation of Teachers virtually on the eve of the start of contract negotiations, proposed yesterday to lengthen the school year and teachers' workdays, reduce preparation periods and alter provisions on seniority, transfers, leaves and retirement.

Sales and earnings of the RCA Corporation reached new highs for the second quarter, Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman and chief executive officer, reported yesterday. He also noted that sales for the first-half were at a new high.

Pound was my constant guide and critic.

ASPEN, Colo., July 17 -- Someone has said that all good American tourists want to go to Paris when they die. Perhaps so, but for the American who happens to like music and skiing, there may be no happier place to go while he lives than this outrageously beautiful mountain town.

Eddie Belmonte failed to weigh-in after he guided Dutch Clover to a front-running triumph at $30.80 for $2 in the fourth race at Aqueduct yesterday. Robert L. Bernstein, chairman of the Association of American Publishers, denounced yesterday as "a sad, shabby affair" an attempt by the Justice Department to prosecute Beacon Press for publishing Senator Mike Gravel's four-volume version of the Pentagon papers.

Officials of the state's Scott Commission who are investigating New York City's government said yesterday that their work had almost halted because Lindsay Administration "harassment" had reduced the interrogation of city employes from a daily average of 50 to 100 to only three a day.
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif. July 17 (AP) -- President Nixon sent a delegation to Moscow today with instructions to try to negotiate a comprehensive trade agreement with the Soviet Union.
The 12-round heavyweight fight between former champions Muhammad Ali and Floyd Patterson has been rescheduled from Aug. 28 to Sept. 20 at Madison Square Garden, the promoters announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- An industry advisory committee has recommended to the Securities and Exchange Commission a two-tape industry-wide system for reporting trading in stocks listed on major national and regional exchanges.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 17 -- The Suffolk County grand jury began its inquiry today into the county's acquisition of the 295-acre Tiana Beach.

NEWARK, July 17 -- Mrs. Virginia Scott, president of the Parent Teachers Association, testified today that she was standing near Dr. E. Wyman Garrett at a turbulent Board of Education meeting here 15 months ago and that at no time did she hear him threaten either John Cervase, a board member, or Fox Butterfield, a New York Times reporter.

WESTHAMPTON, L. I., July 17 -- Steve Baldwin of the Babylon Yacht Club, the defender, came out of today's first four races in good position to retain his Great South Bay Racing Association junior championship.

ATHENS, July 17 (UPI) -- Eight Greeks who the Government says planned to kidnap John F. Kennedy Jr., son of the late President, and other prominent persons have been indicted for conspiracy and will be brought to trial soon, a Government spokesman said today.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 17 (AP) -- Sunny and Mild, claimed for $15,000 last time out, came back to win the Neptune-Ocean Township allowance purse at Monmouth Park under a ride by Steve Neff today.

Hank Aaron of the Atlanta Braves, bidding to overtake Babe Ruth as the all-time home run leader, was among four repeaters on the National League All - Star team announced yesterday by Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball.

THE HAGUE July 17 (Reuters) -- The five-party coalition headed by Premier Berend Biesheuvel seemed in danger of collapse tonight after the two Democratic Socialist ministers submitted their resignations to Queen Juliana, bitterly accusing their colleagues of not keeping their promise to fight inflation.
The Harness Tracks of America welcomed yesterday the return of Yonkers Raceway and the addition of four other tracks to the organization, swelling the membership to 47.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17 (UPI) -- President Nguyen Van Thieu's new martial-law decree provides jail terms for strikers, curfew violators and agitators, and allows the police to shoot to kill motorists who disregard orders to halt, the Government press agency said today.

William S. Rowe, president and chief executive officer of the $650 - million Fifth Third Bank in Cincinnati, said yesterday that he would oppose the bid by the $1.2-billion Union Commerce Corporation of Cleveland to take over his institution.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- State Department officials said today that they believed that the formation of a new Government in Libya yesterday was the result of about 10 days of severe dispute within the ruling Revolutionary Command Council, led by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Nixon Administration reimposed today price and wage controls on 62,000 lumber companies that had been exempt because they were relatively small.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs announced today that during the last fiscal year it seized illicit drugs valued at five times more than those seized in the previous year.

TEL AVIV, July 17 -- Israel's parliament today overwhelmingly endorsed the Government's handling of Arab affairs. Most Opposition members voted with the coalition in Jerusalem to defeat a Communist no-confidence motion, 60 to 6.

A team that includes some of the country's finest young players won a splendid victory Sunday night in the Fun City Regional Knockout Championship at the New York Hilton. Ken Lebensold, Steve Goldstein, George Tornay, all of New York; Louis Levy of East Orange, N.J., Mark Feldman of Cambridge, Mass., and Leslie Popper of Lynn, Mass., won the title in a field of 54 teams that included many of the world's top players.

A 19-year-old youth worker for the city's Youth Services Agency who was accused of wounding four bystanders with a rifle during a gang fight was indicted yesterday by a Bronx grand jury on charges of assault, reckless endangerment and possession of a dangerous weapon.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 17 -- Mrs. Albert B. Bower of the Pelham Country Club scored 39, 40-79 at Sunningdale C. C. today to win the medal by one stroke in the 33d annual championship of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association.
QUANGTRI, South Vietnam, July 17--This city of rubble and ashes trembled to the incessant roar of gunfire today as South Vietnamese paratroops battled their way inch by inch toward its center.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Industrial production rose further in June, but the rate of increase for the last two months has slowed from the rapid pace of earlier this year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LOS ANGELES, July 17 -- As the selection of the jury in the Pentagon papers trial moved into its second week today, it became virtually certain that the jury would contain some strong critics of the Vietnam war.
Earnings of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. in the second quarter and first six months of this year rose sharply on record sales, the concern reported yesterday.
Plans to raze the 80-year-old Third Avenue El in the Bronx, beginning next summer, were announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay at a City Hall news conference.

BALTIMORE, July 17 -- About 75 inmates seized part of the Maryland State Penitentiary in downtown Baltimore today and held four hostages for five hours before releasing them and returning to their cells. It was the second outbreak of violence at a Maryland state prison in the last 48 hours.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 -- Senator Richard S. Schweiker called today for reform of the nation's private pension system, and complained that workers are losing their pension rights when their companies go bankrupt, merge with other concerns or go out of business.

WEST TRENTON, N. J., July 17 (UPI) -- The body of a young man found earlier this month stuffed in a steel barrel submerged in Bergen County's Overpeck Creek was identified here today as that of a 22-year-old fugitive wanted on theft charges.
