Often, for me, the "mystery" of a suspense novel lies more in its appeal to its readers than in its plot. Like a doctor, a book critic has a professional interest in the particular ailments or dietary imbalances that impel readers to seek easement or relief in this or that kind of literature. I'm talking, of course, of works that have no independent appeal, like informativeness, esthetic value or what have you.

Ever since the Teamsters Union convention a year ago it has been obvious that a strange love affair was under way between the Nixon Administration and the nation's biggest union -- a union kicked out of the A.F.L.C.I.O. in 1957 because of the corruption of its dominating elements.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., yesterday reported higher second-quarter revenues and earnings, and it named Robert W. Haack a director. The big brokerage firm also increased its quarterly dividend slightly.
REHOBOTH BEACH, Del., July 18 -- Gov. Russell W. Peterson of Delaware faces a primary election challenge in his bid for the Republican nomination for a second term.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 18 -- After a nerve-racking, wearisome five-hour session of play this evening, Boris Spassky and Bobby Fischer drew the fourth game of the world's chess championship match.
The Federal Government will announce today a major investigation of alleged discrimination against Puerto Rican, black and other minority - group students in the New York City school system.

The jury in the trial of Patrolman William R. Phillips was told yesterday that the bullets that killed James Smith and Sharon Stango -- the pimp and the prostitute he is accused of murdering -- could not have come either of the revolvers Patrolman Phillips is known by the police to own.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 18 -- The second day of the junior phase of the Larchmont Yacht Club's 74th Race Week became a long, hot, weary and wasted afternoon for the 174 Blue Jay crews in a starting fleet of 280 on Long Island Sound.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, July 15 -- The citizens of this city have turned a deaf ear to an attempt at symbolic contrition for what Germans under Hitler did to their Jewish neighbors and to their artists. The attempt's sponsors -the city administration and Frankfurt's leading museum -are chagrined at what they consider public apathy tinged with hostility.

Chess, perhaps the most competitive, intellectually demanding and passionate of games, is rarely treated as casually as gin rummy in the increasing number of homes where it is played with any regularity.

WANTAGH, L. I., July 18 -- Nine-year-old Adrainne Schoenowitz was returned to her natural mother this morning after a year-long custody battle that ended yesterday when her foster parents, William and Beatrice Cahn, were denied a stay of a court decision restoring the child to her natural parents.

The nation's fifth largest steel company, the Republic Steel Corporation reported declines in third-quarter sales and earnings and lower steel shipments yesterday. However, earnings for the first half rose slightly over the 1971 period.
LONG BEACH, Calif., July 18 -- Roman Gabriel and the Los Angeles Rams were breathing easier today.
LONDON, July 18 -- The results of a Common Market monetary conference that ended here today brought at least temporary calm to crisisplagued financial centers of Europe.

SAIGON, July 18 -- Two heavy explosions of undetermined origin nearly sank the Seventh Fleet destroyer Warrington in the Gulf of Tonkin 20 miles off the coast and the North Vietnamese city of Donghoi yesterday, the United States command here reported today.

Dick Allen of the Chicago White Sox was the American League's leading vote-getter in the All-Star balloting by fans to gain the starting first-base job for the annual interleague game next Tuesday night at Atlanta.

CLONMEL, Ireland -- "Like any true killer, I wish to spare the victim," writes the contemporary Irish poet, John Montague and, in a certain sense, this might be called the sentiment of today's I.R.A. (Irish Republican Army) as its two bickering factions continue their intermittent fight for a united Ireland.
Grove Press will publish Clifford Irving's own account of how he tried to swindle McGraw-Hill, Inc., of some $850,000 with an apocryphal autobiography of Howard R. Hughes, the industrialist.

As if this week's summer hot spell were not enough of a problem, a stagnant mass of air -- roughly nature's equivalent of an electric blanket -settled in upon the city and much of the Northeast yesterday.

A concerted effort to end the serious pollution of New York Harbor was initiated by the Federal Government yesterday in a series of lawsuits against New York City, the Passaic Valley Sewerage Commission and several communities in New Jersey.

WARWICK, R. I., Wednesday, July 19 ((AP) -- Five members of the Rolling Stones traveling party, including Nick Jagger, the lead singer, and Keith Richard, lead guitarist, pleaded innocent last night in District Court to charges of asault on a photographer and obstructing police officers..

Thousands of long-distance telephone calls along the Eastern seaboard were disrupted yesterday when a piece of construction equipment severed an American Telephone and Telegraph coaxial cable near Cedar Brook, N. J.

LONDON, July 18 -- Dr. Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, announced here today an unusual wide-ranging agreement with the Soviet Government under which Occidental will provide patents and scientific and technological know-how in five fields in exchange for Russan oil, natural gas, metals and other raw materials.

A high Conservative party official said yesterday that if Vice President Agnew were denied renomination it would "foreclose" any chance in New York of a Conservative endorsement of the Republican national ticket.

Pepped up by reports of possible larger foreign purchases of American wheat, traders bid up wheat prices yesterday in an active session. The busy December delivery, for example, closed at $1.60 3/4 to $1.61 a bushel, compared with $1.57 the previous day.

They planted trees vacuumed sidewalks, painted kiosks, installed ash trays at subway entrances and bus stops, and in general treated their neighborhoods as they would their homes, and yesterday they received a small token of the city's appreciation.

The loss of Goeran Gentele throws the Metropolitan Opera's immediate and long-range plans into confusion. The Swedish general manager, who took office officially this month, had been training for the post for nearly two years, and had mapped out at least three seasons ahead for the Met.

Consolidated Edison engineers said yesterday that although they had replaced the damaged sections of underground cable that failed Monday night, it would take several days of examination in the shop to determine exactly what caused the failures.

The opening statements from the two sides in the American Presidential election campaign sound more like communiques from a battlefield than reasoned statements of future policy. Accordingly, the outlook is that the control of Pennsylvania Avenue over the next four years will be decided once more by the advertising techniques of Madison Avenue, and this raises one or two serious questions.

President Anwar el-Sadat's demand for the withdrawal of Soviet advisers from Egypt could be a momentous turning point in the Middle East. If most or all of the estimated 20,000 Soviet military personnel go home, it would substantially reduce the danger of a big power confrontation in the area and dramatically improve the possibilities for an Arab-Israeli settlement.
Steve Kline, whose "perfect game" came apart at the seams last Friday, pitched a slightly imperfect six-hit shutout last night as the New York Yankees overpowered the Minnesota Twins, 6-0.
POINT PLEASANT, N. J., July 18 -- A couple of drivers stood on their 24-foot outboard at the Kings Grant Inn marina today getting set for tomorrow's Hennessy Grand Prix ocean powerboat race.

The Xerox Corporation continued its high rate of earnings and revenue increases, showing records in the three months ended June 30 as well as for the first half-year, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.

The Federal Reserve Board confirmed yesterday that it had denied an application by the BankAmerica Corporation, parent company of the nation's largest bank, to enter the business of leasing peripheral computer equipment through a new company, the BAC Computer Corporation.

Swen Nater, who fought out of obscurity as a substitute behind Bill Walton, the all-American center from the University of California, Los Angeles, to be named to the Olympic basketball team, quit the squad yesterday at its training base in Honolulu.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Six seeded players survived 90-degree heat and won today in the first round of the $50,000 Washington Star tennis tournament. Ninth-seeded Arthur Ashe, twice a finalist here, was forced to go to three sets.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The House passed today by overwhelming margins two health bills that the Administration did not want and a third toward which it had been cool.
Top executives of two major retail chains, each a leader in its respective field, announced their resignations yesterday.

The International Paper Company yesterday named Joseph P. Monge, board chairman of its Canadian subsidiary, the Canadian International Paper Company, to become chairman of its finance committee. He will also be the company's chief financial, planning and administrative officer.

A Queens grand jury has subpoenaed Sergeant David Durk to determine the extent of police involvement in an attempt to record an alleged bribe offer to Milton Drucker, the executive secretary of District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell. Sergeant Durk is to appear before the panel today.
ATTICA, N. Y., July 18 -- A state of emergency for the Attica Correctional Facility was declared today by its superintendent, Ernest Montanye, after hundreds of inmates refused to leave their cells.

CAIRO, July 18 (Reuters) -- Following is a summary of President Anwar el-Sadat's speech on the withdrawal of some Soviet advisers as issued by the Middle East News Agency, the official Egyptian press agency:

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 18 -President Anwar el-Sadat's decision today to ask for withdrawal of Soviet military advisers and experts from Egypt has been attributed by informed Arab quarters here to mounting domestic pressure.

PLANDOME, L. I., July 18 -Gene Borek of Pine Hollow captured the 37th Long Island Professional Golfers' Association championship today, with a record 54-hole score of 201 over the 6,502-yard, par-72 Plandome Country Club course.

UPPER MARLBORO, Md. (AP) -- In Maryland's third penal disturbance since Saturday, inmates at the Prince Georges County Jail took three guards hostage tonight to force a grievance meeting with county officials.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -Howard J. Samuels, president of New York's Offtrack Betting Corporation and a member of the Mayor's Narcotics Control Council, proposed today a tough, $3-billion program that would put this country's half a million heroin addicts under medical care within five years.

The highest ranks of bridge administration have traditionally been dominated by men. No woman has ever held high executive office in any international federation or in the American Contract Bridge League.

Two more airlines, American and Continental, announced yesterday that they were modifying their Boeing 727 jets so that the rear exit from which several hijacker - extortionists have bailed out could no longer be opened in flight.

NEWARK, July 18 -- Dr. E. Wyman Garrett denied today that he threatened the lives of Fox Butterfield, a reporter for The New York Times, and John Cervase, a school board member, at a turbulent Board of Education meeting here 15 months ago.

Despite the warning of the 1965 Northeast blackout, a spot check of 22 hospitals in New York City yesterday disclosed that almost all were without adequate emergency electrical generators when the lights went out in part of Brooklyn Monday night.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 18 (AP) -- Army Capt. Charles Richards of Tacoma, Wash., swam into the lead today in the United States Olympic modern pentathlon trials, setting a United States pentathlon record in the 300-meter swim.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -Egypt's President, Anwar el-Sadat, announced today that he had ordered the immediate withdrawal of Soviet "military advisers and experts" from his country and the placing of Soviet bases and equipment under the exclusive control of Egyptian forces.
A leading West Coast thrift institution improved its offer yesterday in a move to take over the Citizens Savings and Loan Association of San Francisco, an institution with assets of $625-million.

ASPEN, Colo., July 18 -Audiences at the Aspen Music Festival are traditionally snooty about their listening habits. The other day, Itzhak Perlman chose to perform the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto and there was much pursing of lips.
The Associated Press announced yesterday that it was holding discussions with Hsinhua, the official Chinese press agency, on an agreement for the exchange of news and photos.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 18 -- Cambodia has appealed to United Nations member countries to save the temples and monuments at Angkor from threatened destruction.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -George Meany is making a strong, last-minute personal appeal to key union leaders to vote against any proposal at tomorrow's meeting of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. executive council to endorse George McGovern, union officials reported today.

MOSCOW, July 18 -- The reported Egyptian demand for the removal of Soviet military advisers may not be good news to the Kremlin but it is likely to be welcomed by the man in the street who has been traditionally critical of a heavy foreign aid burden while his own rising expectations are left wanting.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 18 -- Israel dramatically refused to take a seat at a meeting of the Security Council tonight after her request for discussion of a full exchange of war prisoners held in the Middle East was denied.
The president of the Board of Education, Joseph Monserrat, yesterday defended the board's far-reaching proposals for this fall's new contract with the city's teachers.

Bill Virdon's push-button managing failed to function with its usual efficiency last night, and the Atlanta Braves downed the world champion Pirates, 4-2, ending Pittsburgh's five-game winning streak.
The 20 per cent increase in Social Security benefits could create a new hardship for New York State's small property owners who are over 65.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 18 -- William Whitelaw, the British administrator of Ulster, asked the people of Northern Ireland today to send him views about the future of the province.

Sweltering New Yorkers increased their demands for electricity to a near-record level yesterday, only hours after the Consolidated Edison Company restored service to more than 200,000 Brooklyn residents who had been blacked out in the city's worst power failure since 1965.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I., July 18 -The Suffolk County Legislature approved the acquisition today of more than 1,000 acres of land for two new county parks, despite charges that the procedures in one instance were "repeating the same mistakes" of nearly three years ago when it voted to buy Tiana Beach.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 19 (AP) -South Vietnamese troops reportedly inched closer to the walled Citadel of Quangtri city yesterday as bitter house-tohouse fighting continued.

Bausch Lomb, disclosed that second-quarter consolidated sales amounted to $47,323,000, a rise of 21 per cent from $39,270,000 in the 1971 period. Representatives of the city's construction industry called on Mayor Lindsay yesterday to name a "construction coordinator" with the power to cut through the red tape and bureaucracy that they say fosters corruption.

At least 18 alleged drug wholesalers, and 50 pounds of marijuana and a "large quantity" of LSD tablets, were seized last night and early today in a series of police raids at several houses and apartments on Staten Island.

BAYONA, Spain, July 18 (AP) -- Blackfin, a 73-foot ketch sailed by Kennedh De Meuse, of Alameda, Calif., was the first of 46 craft to complete the 2,700-mile voyage from Bermuda.

Investors who trade American Stock Exchange shares do not like their companies to file registration statements covering sale of additional shares. Yesterday, when the market closed at 26.75, down 0.05 in the index, there were several examples.

ROME, July 18 -- Classic is the word for fashion in Italy today as in the rest of the civilized world, but the interpretations are a lot more exuberant. Armholes are deeper, shapes more swirly, necklines lower and evening clothes more glittery than they are any place else.

FRANKFURT, West Germany -- The most talkedabout young choreographer in Germany today is an American, John Neumeier, a Wisconsin-born dancer and choreographer who has scarcely ever worked in the United States.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz went to court yesterday on behalf of Brooklyn and Queens residents who have complained of "horrible," "atrocious" and "intolerable" odors in the air over their homes and places of business.

DUBLIN, July 18 -- After his light workout today, Muhammad Ali, in a short white satin robe, was lying on the rubbing table in his tiny dressing room at Croke Park when somebody knocked on the door.

Corporate and tax-exempt borrowers dipped heavily into the capital markets yesterday, but long-term interest rate movements remained inconclusive. There was no news outside the market to cause any major shift in sentiment, although relative calm returned to the international monetary scene.
There is something new in Times Square -- a floor show at the Automat.

CARLISLE, Pa., July 18 -The temperature was 94 and the humidity almost as high at the Washington Redskins' training camp today when Christian Adolph (Sonny) Jurgensen, a quarterback soon to be 38 years old, cocked his extraordinary passing arm.

A New York racing fan who saw last Saturday's British Grand Prix was stunned at the introduction of parimutuel betting there. "It was strange," says Miss Pat Greise, "to hear them hawking odds over the publicaddress system.

You come away from "Present Tense," four oneacters by Frank D. Gilroy, conscious of words more than anything else. Throughout last evening, down at the Sheridan Square Playhouse, you could almost hear a typewriter's clickety-clack in these tight, terse playlets, staged and performed with the same precise efficiency.

The New York Stock Exchange has chosen as its first full-time, salaried chairman James J. Needham, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Though reportedly not the stock exchange's first choice -- its top recruiters were after a chief with greater public reputation and more sophisticated inside knowledge of Wall Street -- Mr. Needham does bring some commendable qualifications.
GRAND CANYON, Ariz. -Across the great chasm, filled to the rim with silence a mile and 2 billion years deep, a bright new sun appeared in a flash on the southern horizon.

LOS ANGELES, July 18 -Rusty Staub, making a surprise return to the line-up exactly one month after he injured his right hand, gave the Mets a little lift tonight, but it wasn't enough as Los Angeles won, 2-1, on Frank Robinson's twoout homer off Danny Frisella in the 10th inning.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -Frank Sinatra furiously denounced the House Select Committee on Crime today for permitting a convicted felon to engage in what he called "character assassination" by saying the singer was a front man for the Mafia.

While this has been applauded by those concerned with the plight of our aged, it will have a detrimental effect on many of those it was designed to help.
ROME, July 19 -- Senator George McGovern pledged in an interview published in Milan today that if elected President he would guarantee the continued defense of Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -Senator James L. Buckley, differing sharply with New York's other Senator, Jacob K. Javits, said today that dropping Vice President Agnew from the Republican ticket this fall would "clearly hurt President Nixon's re-election chances."
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 19 (AP)--Top-seeded Jimmy Connors and Dick Stockton scored easy victories today to reach the semifinals of the $25,000 Buckeye tennis tournament.

TOKYO, July 19 -- Kakuei Tanaka, Japan's vigorous new Premier, declared today that he was preparing to negotiate a new Japanese relationship with China, which he called "the great diplomatic issue of this country."

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The White House and the North Vietnamese Government announced simultaneously today that Henry A. Kissinger had conferred secretly in Paris during the day with Hanoi negotiators.

The Eastman Kodak Company realized a 34 per cent rise in second-quarter earnings on a sales gain of 17 per cent and increases of 32 and 15 per cent, respectively, for the half, all setting new records, the mid-year report disclosed yesterday.

NEWARK, July 19 -- Dr. E. Wyman Garrett pleaded guilty in Essex County Superior Court today to a reduced charge of interfering with a New York Times reporter at a turbulent Board of Education meeting here 15 months ago.

LONDON, July 19 -- British officials and members of the Irish Republican Amy's militant Provisional wing are conducting secret talks in Belfast and London in an effort to work out a new cease-fire in Northern Ireland, knowledgeable sources said today.
State unemployment insurance benefits beyond the basic 26-week period will be curtailed and possibly eliminated within the next two weeks, the Labor Department said yesterday in Albany.

Gov. George C. Wallace underwent surgery in Birmingham to drain an abscess near one of the abdominal bullet wounds he received when he was shot at a Maryland rally in May. The Alabama Governor was said to be "doing fine" after the surgery, the third he has had to heal his wounds.

LOS ANGELES, July 19 -- The Mets' once-glorious pennant dreams plummeted sharply into near hopelessness tonight when X-rays disclosed that Rusty Staub has a fractured bone in his right hand and the team lost to Los Angeles, 5-0.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 19 (AP) -- Bombs and gunfire claimed four more lives in Northern Ireland today.

The proposed regulations, already reported out by the City Council's Committee on Environmental Protection, are expected to be approved by the full Council and Mayor Lindsay. They emphatically should be.

Senator George McGovern's appearance July 12 before dissident elements in the lobby of the Doral Hotel was indeed a remarkable event. After having prevailed upon local police not to break up this peaceful group who sincerely felt disillusioned by the wording of a statement on Vietnam, Senator McGovern risked further embarrassment and confusion by agreeing to submit to such questioning.

PROVIDENCE, R.I, July 19 -A long-standing Rhode Island law that required persons voting in the primary of one political party to wait 26 months before voting in the primary of another party was declared unconstitutional today.
Henry Aaron tied Babe Ruth's home run record last night. No, no, not THAT record.
In a major change of policy, the United States Government intervened in the foreign exchange markets yesterday to protect the value of the dollar.

A former school psychologist whose previous sortie into private practice was described by the president of the Suffolk County Psychological Society as "a clear violation of the ethical code" is now running a therapy and teaching center offering marriage counseling, educational testing and individual and group therapy.

MOSCOW, July 19 -- The Soviet Government told its citizens today for the first time that Russian military personnel were being removed from Egypt, but contended that the action was being taken by joint agreement.

HONG KONG, July 19 -- A marine court of inquiry returned a verdict of probable arson today after a two-month inquiry into the spectacular blaze that reduced the Queen Elizabeth to a blackened hulk resting on her side in Hong Kong harbor.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -The Senate Interior Committee shelved indefinitely today a Nixon Administration-backed bill to authorize the temporary licensing of nuclear power plants.

VINHKIM, South Vietnam, July 18 -- Ho Van Bao hurriedly stuffed his squealing baby pigs into a big shipping basket.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 19 -- As of tonight, no driver had been listed for Fresh Yankee of Canada in next Saturday night's $150,000 challenge race at Roosevelt Raceway against Une de Mai of France and Speedy Crown of the United States.
CAMBRIDGE, Md. -- In a crab-meat picking shed on the Choptank River, 40 women, mostly black, mostly elderly, sat at tables digging the meat out of blue crabs with a knife.

DUBLIN, July 19 -- Weakened by a head cold and perhaps victimized by an alleged long count, Muhammad Ali didn't stop Al (Blue) Lewis until the 11th round tonight in a brawl that enthralled an estimated 20,000 spectators at Ireland's first major prize fight in nearly four decades.

MUNICH, West Germany, July 17 -- The newest hero of the West German counterculture is a tall and articulate 20-year-old athlete who has captured a surprising place for the New Left in the most popular and highly paid group in the country -- the national soccer team.

In an apparent effort to reduce political influence in the city's Police Department, the International Association of Chiefs of Police has been hired to help determine which commanders should be promoted above the rank of captain.

Pearl Gordon has learned to combine the joy of French cooking, the subtleties of Chinese cuisines and the regimen of natural foods she followed as a youngster to prepare meals for her family and at the same time satisfy her own need for a low cholesterol diet.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 19 -- As they say in poker, the players came to play.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 19 -Travelers from Cairo reported here today that Soviet advisers in Egypt have been arriving in Alexandria since Monday, preparing to embark for home. The advisers have arrived in buses and military trucks under strict security provided by the Egyptian forces, according to the travelers, who said that the Egyptians have been careful to treat the departing Russians well.

Diversity has been the American Ballet Theater's trademark. Tuesday night at the State Theater, the company seemed to drive this point home with insistence in its final premiere of the season, Peter Van Dyk's pas de deux, "Unfinished Symphony."

All of the diversified chemical companies that reported earnings yesterday showed higher results for the second quarter and first half this year, with the exception of Bristol-Myers whose profits for the initial six months this year declined 11.2 per cent.

POINT PLEASANT, N. J., July 19 -- Sandy Satullo of Cleveland won the Hennessy Grand Prix today, but that is only half the drama. He had never entered an ocean power boat race before last February, has never lost a race in four outings and today was his 50th birthday.

The Metropolitan Opera, still reeling from the blow of Goeran Gentele's death, has named his right-hand man, Schuyler G. Chapin, as acting general manager with instructions to carry out Mr. Gentele's already firmly set plans for the coming season.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- Raymond Patriarca, reputed Mafia chief in New England, told Congressmen today that he had never had any business dealings with Frank Sinatra and "never met the gentleman in my life."
BUCHAREST, July 19 -- President Nicolae Ceausescu appealed today for a vote of confidence from the Rumanian Communist party in the face of mounting opposition within the party's upper ranks.

TOKYO, July 19--Japan's new Premier, Kakuei Tanaka, said today that another revaluation of the yen "must be avoided at all costs."

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 (AP) -- Manager Danny Murtaugh of the National League All-Star team has named nine pitchers to next Tuesday's game, including Steve Blass, who pitched Murtaugh's Pittsburgh Pirates to victory in the seventh game of last year's World Series.

ROME, July 19 -- The trouble with normal fashions is they don't make very exciting viewing. Everybody is off the kooky kick, with the result that the fall couture collections are honorable but not exhilarating.

Recent Census Bureau statistics for the greater New York metropolitan area and for the nation agree on one cardinal point -- the median income of black families continues to lag far behind that of white families. The police were hunting yesterday for gangland figures named by the chauffeur of Thomas Eboli, the Mafia leader who was slain on Sunday.
The city's Health Commissioner, Dr. Joseph A. Cimino, said yesterday that the heat wave had begun to take its toll among the chronically ill.

When Yelberton Abraham Tittle retired as Giant quarterback, the grateful Giants bestowed on him the rare honor of retiring his number with him. Thus was No. 14 removed from the rolls. Emotional man that he is, Y. A. was almost in tears when his uniform jersey was handed him as a permanent memento while the then vast army of Giant worshipers glowed in almost unanimous approval.

Of all the transparent exhibitions of slanting the news, your "From a Saigon Mother" (Op-Ed June 27) takes the biscuit. I admire the esprit de corps among your editors. What a pity some of the spirit cannot be channeled into backing our own soldiers engaged in a war for the self-determination of Southeast Asia.
CUSTER, S.D., July 19 -Senator George McGovern celebrated his 50th birthday today by riding horseback through the Ponderosa pines at his Black Hills vacation retreat.

E. F. Hutton Co., a major brokerage house, reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 12 per cent. The concern said it earned $2,395,000 in the period, up from $2,107,000 a year earlier.

Wheat prices continued to rise yesterday, still influenced by the hope of larger exports. At the same time corn prices showed some gains following word that record numbers of cattle were coming to market at this summer's high prices.

The longest competition in the New York bridge season ended Tuesday night when Jeff Rubens and Michael Becker, both of New York; Bill Passell of Ardsley, N. Y., and Chuck Lamprey of White Plains won the double knockout team championship for the Von Zedtwitz Trophy.

Tidewater Marine Service, Inc., New Orleans, and the Exchange Oil and Gas Corporation announced yesterday an agreement in principle for a merger that would involve an estimated $50-million. The proposed exchange, subject to final auditing of figures and shareholder approval, calls for an exchange of 0.35 shares (an estimated total of 1,826,156) of Tidewater for each of the 5,252,600 outstand ing shares of Exchange Oil.

The Scott Commission will drastically reduce the scope of its inquiry because of lack of funds, time and Lindsay administration "obstacles," Stuart N. Scott, chairman of the state commission to study the city's government, said yesterday.

The failure of Consolidated Edison Company feeder and distribution cables last night reduced power voltage and blacked out buildings in scattered areas of a wide part of southern Brooklyn and in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.
GUATEMALA, July 16 -When Guatemalans go to farewell parties, they sing "Las Golondrinas." It is a Mexican song.

The Howard Johnson Company said it expected to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed offer of up to 1,150,000 shares of split stock by the estate of Howard D. Johnson and certain members of the Johnson family.

Back in 1952 Josef Stalin convened an international economics conference in Moscow whose chief goal was to convince American businessmen that billions of dollars in Soviet-American trade annually was a real possibility. After Stalin, Nikita Khrushchev repeatedly sought to persuade this country that such prospects were real and worth acting upon.

JERUSALEM, July 19 -- Premier Golda Meir and her top advisers today puzzled over the departure of Soviet advisers from Egypt, uncertain whether it marked a major turnaround in the Middle Eastern conflict or only a lesser power struggle in the Egyptian leadership.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (UPI) -- Trustees of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company announced today they had filed a petition with Federal court here seeking approval of a previously announced agreement to sell 95 2/3 per cent of its holding of the common stock of the Pennsylvania Company to a group of 49 banks.
A controversial bill barring discrimination against homosexuals in employment, housing and public accommodations was voted down again yesterday by the City Council's Committee on General Welfare.

BOGOTA, Colombia, July 19 -- The co-pilot of a Colombian airliner with 52 passengers aboard, wounded by a passenger who had shot the captain to death, made a smooth landing at Cartagena, Colombia, last night as other passengers used paper napkins to keep blood from blinding him.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- History provides no support for the political strategy which the leadership of organized labor seems determined to adopt in this Presidential campaign.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 19 (UPI) -- The Ohio Supreme Court overturned an appeals court decision today and said the father of a Kent State University co-ed killed by National Guard troops cannot sue the state for alleged "negligent and wanton" mis conduct.
American Airlines, Inc., and Trans World Airlines both announced yesterday higher earnings for the quarter ended June 30 and reduced losses for the first six months of 1972.
Beginner or expert, Joe Brooks's "Trout Fishing" (Harper Row -- Outdoor Life; 302 pages, illustrated, $8.95) belongs in your library if you are a fly fisherman.
LOS ANGELES, July 19 (AP) -- Boris Spassky came close to defeating Bobby Fischer in the fourth game of their world championship chess match.
Every five minutes on an average, five New York fire trucks race from their firehouses with screaming sirens on an unnecessary trip because someone turned in a false alarm.

Linda's Chief, a "real running machine" in the words of his trainer, Al Scotti, registered his fifth straight victory in an undefeated career by taking the $27,575 Tremont Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- A House education subcommittee approved legislation today that would prohibit Federal courts or agencies from requiring busing to desegregate elementary schools.

CAIRO, July 19 (Reuters) -Many of the military advisers and technical experts sent by the Soviet Union to Egypt since the Arab defeat in the 1967 war with Israel were on their way home today, ordered out by President Anwar el-Sadat.

Don Simmer, the manager of the San Diego Padres, took the blame yesterday for the hit by Denny Doyle, the Philadelphia Phillies' second baseman, that cost Steve Arlin a no-hitter Tuesday night. Doyle bounced a two-out, two-strike single in the ninth inning over the head of Dave Roberts, the rookie third baseman.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 19 -- Negotiators for the Red Cross organizations of North Korea and South Korea today fixed on Aug. 5 as the date when a big delegation will travel from the capital of one to the capital of the other to discuss the prospects for visits by family members between the two Koreas.

ROME, July 19--Arrangements were being made today to return to Sweden the bodies of Goeran Gentele, director of the Metropolitan Opera, and two of his daughters. They were killed yesterday in an automobile crash on the island of Sardinia.
Stever Aubrey, a top man at J. Walter Thompson, the world's largest agency, has resigned to become chairman and chief executive of F. William Free Co.

The Nevada Hotel is still standing, but most of its tenants are gone now and most of its windows are covered with tin.

A report of two outbreaks of whooping cough among the staff of the University of Colorado Medical Center has focused attention on a paradoxical situation in which doctors are diagnosing cases of the childhood disease among a small but growing number of adolescents and adults.

A New York Telephone official admitted yesterday that the company's application for the right to make customers pay for local directory-assistance calls concealed a rate increase of about $11.3-million.
BONN, July 19 (Reuters) -Britain has formally objected to the West German Government over Rhodesian athletes taking part in the Munich Olympic games, a British Embassy spokesman said here tonight.

The New York Yankees went to heroic lengths yesterday in their summertime campaign to win back the affections of their straying public. They gave away 13,600 T-shirts to entice the next generation into the Stadium and then treated them to a 13-3 mauling of the Minnesota Twins.
Occidental Petroleum hit pay dirt in Wall Street again yesterday as a brisk market rally pushed stock prices higher.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -Eighty-eight per cent of the nation's 7,000 nursing homes that receive Medicaid funds have been granted Federal certification under a new program, the White House announced today.
SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., July 19 -- Pat Schwab of the Playboy Club carded a one-over-par 73 for a three-round total of 214 and a four-stroke lead in the 52d New Jersey State open golf tournament today.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Administration officials privately voiced pleasure today over the removal of at least several thousand Soviet military personnel from Egypt, But they cautioned that the over-all meaning of the latest developments in the Middle East was still unclear.
Airline hijackings are so common now that someone has finally decided that there may just be a fairly substantial market for -- of all things -- hijack insurance.

The case for the appointment, rather than the election, of judges seems to us to be persuasive. Voters stumbling through crowded ballots cannot hope to know the qualifications or lack of them of most of the candidates for judicial posts, who normally owe their nominations to entrenched party organizations. Judicial posts are part of their dispensable patronage, and too often the test applied is less genuine merit than long-term service in partisan causes.

In a dispatch published on July 3, your correspondent said that President Bhutto was willing to agree that the cease-fire line in Kashmir should gradually become the border between India and Pakistan and wanted a secret agreement with Mrs. Gandhi to this effect.

BELMONT, Mass., July 18 -The ultraconservative John Birch Society, unsuccessful in prolonged past efforts to impeach Earl Warren as Chief Justice of the United States and to "get the U.S. out of the U.N. and the U.N. out of the U.S.," has begun a project that is producing results.
PARIS, July 19 -- The French Government said firmly today that it would not attempt to step in where the Russians had stepped out in Egypt.

An acupuncture clinic that opened here one week ago closed down yesterday after the State Department of Education, which regulates the practice of medicine, issued an opinion that the nonphysicians who were administering the needle therapy at the clinic were practicing medicine.

" Hear America First," the perky little concert series that materialized recently at the Greenwich Mews Theater to brighten a few July evenings, offered its third and final event on Tuesday and retired for the summer.

FLINT, Mich., July 19 (AP) -Judge Stephen J. Roth of United States District Court cleared the way today for an appeal of his finding that Detroit's schools are segregated by law. He also opened avenues of appeal of his order that 52 suburban school districts be included in a desegregation plan.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -Housing starts continued at a high level in June and the nation's factories have begun to operate at a slightly higher proportion of their capacity, Government reports disclosed today.

PONTIAC, Mich. July 19 (AP) -- The parents of children bused under court order to achieve racial integration in public schools here remain split down racial lines over the program's success, according to a survey just completed.
Stocks struggled to rise yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, but after prices jumped in the morning they turned down late in the session.
ATTICA, N. Y., July 19 -The three-day inmate strike at the State Correctional Facility here, during which as many as three-fourths of the 1,200 prisoners refused to eat or work, ended today.

Jokes abounded that a tunnel linked the two dwellings, so close was relationship between the two nations.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Executive Council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. voted today to refrain from endorsing either President Nixon or Senator George McGovern for the Presidency. GROVER, Colo. -- The pattern seems always the same this time of year in the high plains east of the Rocky Mountains. Mornings break with a cloudless blue sky and the humidity a little high. The hot sun beats down.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 19 -- That John Riggins has been having trouble getting into his New York Jets' helmet is not because his head is swollen over last season's accomplishments.

" The David Steinberg Show" is the latest addition to the list of summer series that have been bobbing about in a television sea of repeats. For five weeks Mr. Steinberg's show will be replacing reruns of "The Carol Burnett Show" on the Columbia Broadcasting System.

BERLIN, July 19 -- West Berlin today bought a piece of land from the East Germans at the Potsdamer Platz, in the heart of the city.
WASHINGTON, July 19--Senator John Sherman Cooper, a leader of antiwar Republicans in the Senate, proposed today the unconditional withdrawal of all American forces from Indochina within four months.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday that it had suspended Edward A. Merkle, chief executive officer of the Madison Fund, Inc., from association with any investment company, broker-dealer or investment adviser for 60 days.

ACCRA, Ghana, July 19 -Ghana's military government has issued a "subversion decree" calling for the execution by firing squad of anyone convicted of attempting to overthrow the ruling council "by unlawful means."

BRUSSELS, July 19 (UPI) -The 10 nations of the enlarged European Common Market announced agreement today to continue preparations for the controversial meeting of heads of government in October.

The National Science Foundation, long an important source of funding for basic research far removed from the marketplace, is planning to broaden its scope by conducting experiments of its own to learn how the Government can stimulate lagging technological development in the commercial and industrial sectors of the economy.

PROVIDENCE R. I., July 19 -- Electrical power was shut down in Providence, its suburbs and most of Rhode Island for more than an hour tonight after a severe rainstorm struck southern New England. Parts of southeastern Massachusetts also were blacked out.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 20 -- The senior one-design class sailors returned to the 74th Race Week at Larchmont Yacht Club today after a hiatus of three days.
R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc. achieved record sales and earnings in the three and six months ended with June for the eighth successive year, according to yesterday's semi-annual report.

QUEBEC, July 20 (Canadian Press) -- J. C. Tremblay, an all-star defenseman in three of his 12 National Hockey League seasons with the Montreal Canadiens, signed the a multiyear contract with Les Nordiques, the Quebec City team in the New World Hockey Association tonight.

SALTVILLE, Va. -- "When I first came here, Saltville was a utopia. If it could have gone on for an eternity, that would have been beautiful." Robert G. McCoy was recalling Saltville, perhaps with a touch of irony, as the ultimate company town, just a few years ago, when the giant Olin Corporation owned the houses and the stores and hospital and helped the lives of several thousand residents.

CARLISLE, Pa., July 20 -- There are 17 free agents in the National Football League still available to the highest bidder but George Allen, the maestro of the Washington Redskins who operates with an unlimited budget, says he is not especially interested.

Mayor Lindsay, who plans to stay at his City Hall desk during most of the Presidential campaign, criticized the Democratic ticket yesterday for failing to pay sufficient attention to the problems of the cities.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that the Egyptian order ousting Soviet military personnel appeared to be limited at present to advisers serving with Egyptian military units.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Al H. Chesser became the first elected president of the United Transportation Union on Jan. 1. That was the same date on which William H. Dempsey took over the National Railway Labor Conference, which is the management group.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Clark MacGregor, the manager of President Nixon's re-election campaign, said today that he had asked Mr. Nixon to delay any serious campaigning until three weeks before the election.

The Union Carbide Corporation, the nation's second largest chemical producer, realized a 33 per cent increase in second-quarter earnings on a sales gain of 5 per cent, while half-year earnings were up 25 per cent and sales by 3 per cent, the mid-year report disclosed yesterday.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 20 -- A newsdealer was shot dead here today after gunmen had planted a bomb in his shop on Springfield Road. His wife was shot in the back and seriously wounded as she knelt beside the dying man.

Orders for shares of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation continued to deluge the New York Stock Exchange and the rest of the nation's securities markets yesterday in an unprecedented surge of public speculation.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Treasury confirmed today the decision of the Federal Reserve System to intervene in the foreign exchange markets and said the new technique would be used "upon occasion . . . when it is desirable to help deal with speculative forces."
Dozens of Mafiosi have been in hiding since the shooting of Thomas Eboli, high officials reported yesterday as a new apparent gangland slaying came to light.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 20 (UPI) -- Three members of Vietnam Veterans Against the War posted bonds totaling $75,000 today and walked away after a week in jail calling the Federal conspiracy charges against them "garbage."

The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation and subsidiaries achieved new highs in telephone revenues, manufacturing sales, net income and share earnings for both the second quarter and first half, Leslie H. Warner, chairman, reported yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July -- 20 Secretary General Waldheim said in a report submitted today that South Africa was willing to accept a special United Nations representative to work toward self-determination and independence for the disputed territory of South-West Africa.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Senate voted today to increase the Federal minimum wage for most nonagricultural workers to $2.20 an hour over the next two years, a much larger rise than had been sought by President Nixon or approved by the House. The vote was 65 to 27.

MISSOULA, Mont., July 16 -- Well-informed civilian and military sources have disclosed that in an effort to clear away enemy-controlled forests, the United States made a number of concerted attempts to set huge fire storms in Vietnam during 1966 and 1967. The project was ultimately abandoned, they said, because the moist tropical rain forest would not burn.

Silver prices made a bright showing in early morning futures trading yesterday gaining 3 cents an ounce in some contracts. Mrs. Linda Lauretz Fortnow and Stanley Leonard Bartels, both of New York, were married here yesterday afternoon by Surrogate Samuel S. DiFalco in his chambers.
Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange, a technical ingredient in the stock-market outlook, dropped 201,791 shares in the month ended last Friday, the Big Board reported yesterday.

PRAGUE, July 20 (AP) -- Three former Communist party officers, including a key supporter of Alexander Dubcek received sentences of up to two-and-a-half years in prison today for anti-Government activities.

ROME, July 20 -- Fashion designers aren't the only people yearning for the good old days. American Airlines, Inc., has arranged a lease agreement with the Loews Corporation under which the airline will become one of Manhattan's major hotel operators, it was learned last night.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The percentage of black families headed only by women has reached nearly 32, the Census Bureau reported today.
DETROIT, July 20 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit blocked at least temporarily today moves to start school busing in the fall between Detroit and its suburbs.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A two-year Government study released today concludes that, contrary to charges that catapulted Ralph Nader on the way to prominence, 1960-63 Chevrolet Corvair models were at least as safe as comparable models of other cars sold in the same period.

LOS ANGELES, July 20 -- While Rusty Staub entered Roosevelt Hospital in New York, where he will undergo surgery tomorrow for the fractured bone in his right hand, the Mets carried on without him here tonight and edged the Dodgers, 2-1.

ATLANTA, July 20 -- Gov. George C. Wallace, recuperating in Birmingham, Ala., from bullet wounds and further surgery, will not attend the nominating convention of the American Independent party next month, a spokesman for his campaign said today.

LOS ANGELES, July 20 -- On the ninth day of jury selection in the Pentagon papers case, the trial judge questioned the 40th prospective juror today and found the first one to say he had read any material from the controversial papers.

Reginald Maudling was one of the intelligent young British Conservatives -- Edward Heath and the late Iain Macleod were others -- who worked overtime under R. A. TRENTON, July 20 -- Herbert J. Stern, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, said today that a memorandum and a complaint by a former top official of the State Transportation Department touched off the Federal investigation last April that led to the indictment of Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin and two other men on conspiracy and extortion charges.

PARIS, July 20 -- The formal Vietnamese peace talks continued today, but they only marked time in the wake of renewed private contacts between Hanoi's Le Duc Tho and Henry A. Kissinger in Paris yesterday.

The state commission investigating the city government won the right in State Supreme Court yesterday to question city employes even when two commissioners were not present.

Forecast of a lower stock market and higher consumer savings were made yesterday by Albert Sindlinger and Eliot Janeway at an interview between sessions of the July seminar sponsored by the latter in the New York Athletic Club.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 20 -- Pending further investigation, the Office of Economic Opportunity announced tonight that it would withhold payment of $60,000 in Federal antipoverty funds to a private agency that arranged to send 67 local high school students on a tour of Europe and Africa during July and August.
Six weeks before their first training camp the New York Islanders yesterday finally picked their coach -- Phil Goyette, one of hockey's most respected players.
The chairman of the State Public Service Commission said yesterday that his agency would not at this time allow a request by the New York Telephone Company to charge for directory-assistance calls.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Committee for Economic Development recommended today that the government chart guidelines and procedures for selective termination of wage-price controls.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Rod Laver, the world's best unseeded player, and three of the top-seeded stars were eliminated today in the third round of the $50,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament.

At the age of 75, Sam Chatmon, a singer and guitarist, made his New York debut Wednesday evening at the Folklore Center, Avenue of the Americas at Third Street, Mr. Chatmon, a thin, wiry man with a lined face and twinkling eyes, has been performing since World War I and, with several of his brothers, was a member of the Mississippi Sheiks, a group that was popular in the late nineteen-twenties and early thirties.

LONDON, July 20 -- Revivals seem to be very much the order of the day in the London theater -- which is partly as it should be. It is always sensible for a theater go take stock of where it is, both in the classic repertory and, more dangerously but often just as rewardingly, in the repertory of the fairly recent past.

The All-Star game's selection of pitchers is a "fraud," the Pirates' top reliever, Dave Giusti, charged yesterday. His former manager, Danny Murtaugh, selected the National League's nine pitchers (the starting line-up, except for the pitcher, was selected by fans).
Underwriters of tax-exempt securities pushed interest rates down another notch yesterday but demand from investors for several new issues was nonetheless brisk.

The current defender of the faith is the Light Opera of Manhattan, which was founded three years ago by William Mount-Burke and is operating at the small Jan Hus Playhouse on East 74th Street.

The First Pennsylvania Corporation reported yesterday a marked slowdown in the rate of growth in its earnings. The company, the parent organization of the First Pennsylvania Banking and Trust Company, Philadelphia's largest bank, said that its net operating earnings in the first half of the year amounted to $17.2-million, or 1.39 a share, up 3.7 per cent from the $16.6-million, or 1.35, earned last year.

ASPEN, Colo. -- Amid July 4th week end distractions, President Nixon's veto of the Public Broadcasting Act failed to arouse the public curiosity it deserved. On the surface, the differences seemed minor: Mr. Nixon had recommended one-year extension of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting with $45 million for fiscal '73; Congress voted two years with $65 million for '73 and $90 million for '74.
Your editorial (July 13) correctly states that the resumption of the Paris peace talks offers the last chance to end the Vietnam war before the American elections.

Right at the outset, Louise Varese in her memoir of the composer Edgard Varese, who was her husband, warns off the musicians and the musically knowledgeable. Her book, she says, is a personal memoir, neither exhaustive nor technical. Her disclaimer may have been designed for those who believe they can better understand the music by getting close to the man.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- The regular Democrats who were denied seats at the party's Miami Beach convention sought contempt citations today against the 59 Democrats who replaced the delegation led by Mayor Richard J. Daley.

PARIS, July 20 -- The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development had some good words to say today about the future economic performance of the United States. What it saw was a lower rate of inflation and unemployment and "significant" improvement in the balance of payments.

J. Paul Sticht will resign as president of Federated Department Stores, Inc., effective Oct. 31 to become a consultant to the large retail company and serve as an "active part-timer" in various personal and business endeavors.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 20 -- The Egyptian military command played a major role in the removal of the Soviet military advisers from Egypt, according to a variety of sources here.

GENEVA, July 20 -- The Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, Secretary General of the World Council of Churches, has written President Nixon that he believes that United States planes are deliberately bombing dikes in North Vietnam.

"Berlin to Broadway With Hurt Weill," a melange of the German composer's enduring musical stage success, will be presented at the Theater de Lys beginning Oct. 1 by Hank Kaufman, an agent turned producer who has lived in Rome for the last 18 years.

PARIS -- There is no doubt that the withdrawal of Soviet military forces from Egypt is the most important regional development since Moscow sent SAM missiles and crews to that country. How many of the approximately 20,000 Russians there will go is unknown but, both psychologically and factually, the East Mediterranean power balance must change.
MOSCOW, July 20 -- The United States Secretary of Commerce, Peter G. Peterson, arrived here today for the first meeting of a new Joint Soviet-American Commercial Commission opening tomorrow.

Willis Reed, the New York Knicks basketball star, was arrested last night in an automobile incident involving an off-duty patrolman. Mr. Reed was charged with reckless endangerment, menacing, harassment told impersonating a police officer.

Slow trading of 3.1 million shares marked another day of declining prices on the American Stock Exchange. The index closed at 26.68, off 0.07. In the over-the-counter market the NASDAQ index ended at 134.27, off 0.57.

FORT WORTH, Tex., July 20 (AP) -- Tim Dement of Bossler City, La., his flicking left jab consistently on target, all but sidetracked Bobby Lee Hunter's quest of a gold medal tonight in the United States Olympic boxing trials.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Governor Rockefeller and 11 of his fellow Governors appealed today to the Senate Finance Committee to approve quickly a House-passed revenue-sharing bill without major changes.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Personal income, held back by the floods in the eastern part of the country, showed no increase in June, the Commerce Department reported today.
New Yorkers endured yet another day of furnace-like heat and sticky, humid air yesterday and the National Weather Service predicted at least two more days of the same.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The commissioners of major professional sports presented a united front today against proposed regulations that would allow cable television to pick up many events without the promoter's permission, but one of their club owners, who is also a cable television operator, took the opposite view.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 20 -- Duncan MacDonald, the owner of fresh Yankee, named himself today to drive the 9-year-old mare in Saturday night's $150,000 challenge trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

CAIRO, July 20 -- The Egyptian leadership made several moves today apparently intended to limit the emotional and political impact of President Anwar el-Sadat's decision to oust Soviet military advisers from Egypt.

AREA A -- Good catches of bluefish, some up to 17 pounds, are being made by boats trolling and chumming off Barnegat Ridge and a run of medium-sized weakfish has begun about a mile off the beach in the Barnegat area.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy held a secret hearing today to investigate charges that the director of the Atomic Energy Commission's Division on Security had borrowed more than $150,000 from commission employes.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 20 -- Bobby Fischer, swooping down on a blunder by Boris Spassky, forced the champion's resignation today in the fifth game of their world championship chess match.

LAKE WARAMAUG, Conn., July 20 -- The national single sculls champion, Jim Dietz of the New York A.C., had little trouble qualifying today for tomorrow's semifinals in Olympic rowing trials on Lake Waramaug. Only Tom Rafferty of the Schuylkill B.C. made it to the starting line with him in the fourth heat.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The White House said today that it was dropping plans to press ahead this year with emergency legislation to combat transportation strikes but denied that the decision represented a "deal" with organized labor.

Canada is to be congratulated on the good judgment of its Minister of Northern Development, Jean Chretien, who also supervises that country's 28 national parks. Confronted by a plan to impose a whole new tourist town on Banff National Park, the Minister rejected the proposal for the obvious damage it would do to one of Canada's best-known scenic attractions.

PARIS, July 20 -- The dollar continued to strengthen in Western Europe's financial centers today as European bankers and monetary authorities enthusiastically welcomed the decision of the Federal Reserve Board to intervene in the markets in defense of the dollar's exchange rate.

A federal judge yesterday granted a stockbroker a preliminary injunction against the New York Stock Exchange, which has called for the broker's expulsion from membership because of the way he recapitalized his firm.

AUSTIN, Tex., July 20 -Mounting summer demand for Texas oil simply cannot be met by Texas wells, the Texas Railroad Commission reported today.

Monetary expansion accelerated during the last two weeks, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday. It appeared doubtful, however, that the quickening represented any change in the central bank's policy of moderate monetary expansion.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 21 -- Stuart B. Rowe Jr. of Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club won his fourth consecutive race today in his neighbor's backyard at Larchmont Yacht Club's Race Week. But Rowe's perfect record in the International One-Design Class, with only one day remaining, may discourage some skippers from returning and thus hurt his chances of winning the trophy as the outstanding skipper.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 -A national stock-market tape incorporating trades on all regional securities exchanges as well as on the New York boards will be operative in about one year, William J. Casey, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said here today.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Nixon has sent congratulations to President Georges Pompidou on the seizure of three heroin laboratories in southern France since last Saturday, Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, said today.

Rusty Staub, the Mets' home run and runs-batted-in leader despite having played in only one of his team's last 28 games, underwent surgery yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. The one-hour operation for the removal of the hook in the hamate bone of his right wrist was performed by Dr. Richard Eaton, assisted by Dr. Peter LaMotte, the Met's team physician, who said," Everything went well."

The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company rolled up record sales and earnings in the quarter and six months ended with June, with profit gains of 35 and 30 per cent, respectively, for the periods, it was reported yesterday.

The Kaiser Industries Corporation had a second-quarter net profit of $6,674,000, or 23 cents a share, including an extraordinary gain of $578,000, or 2 cents, from the sale of CATV operations, it was reported yesterday.

PARIS, July 21 -- The United States may have to pay some old debts as it reactivates reciprocal borrowing facilities with other countries to get the money that may be needed for propping up the dollar in the exchange markets, Paris sources said today.

PARIS, July 21 -- The Government has won another round in the struggle for tight political control of France's state-owned television, it dismissed Pierre Desgraupes, whose name has stood for objective, critical, sometimes nonconformist reporting, from his job as director of newscasts of the network's major channel.
KENT, Conn., July 21 (AP) -- Jim Dietz and John Van Blom recorded victories in single-sculls competition today on Lake Waramaug to advance to the final of the United States Olympic rowing trials.

Willis Reed, the captain of the Knicks, will plead not guilty Aug. 3 to charges of reckless endangerment, menacing, harassment, impersonating an officer and a traffic violation. Those charges were lodged against him after a near-accident Thursday with a car driven by an off-duty patrolman, Joseph Guarino.

Reversing a State Supreme Court decision, the Appellate Division yesterday upheld the constitutionality of a provision of the state's Mental Health Law that directs the transfer of a "dangerously mentally ill" patient from a state civil hospital to Matteawan State Hospital for the criminally insane.

MYCHANH, South Vietnam, July 21 -- A kind of random killing has begun all along Route 1 south of Quangtri, in which there seems to be no safe place for anyone, especially the cursing drivers of trucks, tanks and ambulances jammed up for miles.

CAIRO, July 21 -- President Anwar el-Sadat's decision to end Egypt's reliance on Soviet military assistance was a coolly arrived at, deliberate move that was several weeks in the making, informed Egyptian sources and foreign diplomats said today.
Three Democratic judicial conventions nominated 13 men yesterday, including the Bronx County District Attorney, Burton Roberts, to run in November for the State Supreme Court.

FORT WORTH, Tex., July 21 (UPI) -- Duane Bobick pummeled flabby Leroy Jones to win his 58th straight heavyweight fight and Tim Dement, conqueror of Bobby Lee Hunter, captured a squeaky decision over Gregory Lewis tonight, to move into the finals of the United States Olympic boxing trials.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The Communications Satellite Corporation reported today revenues of $25,618,000 for the second quarter of 1972, and $50,858,000 for the first six months, compared with $22,229,000 for the April-June period of 1971 and $44,163,000 for the first half of 1971.

LEBRIJA, Spain, July 21 (Reuters) -- Seventy-six persons died and 103 were injured when a holiday express and a local passenger train crashed head-on near this town in southern Spain today.

The Wachovia Corporation, a diversified bank and financial service concern with $3-billion in assets, reported yesterday that its net operating earnings in the first half of 1972 were $15.5-million, or $1.06 a share, up 7.1 per cent from the $14.5million or 99 cents a share earned in the same period last year.

PITTSBURGH, July 21 (UPI) -- A mass of polluted air hovered over the Ohio River Valley today and officials obtained court orders to force some industries to halt air emissions in an attempt to ease the crisis.
TORONTO, July 21 (Canadian Press) -Graham Kerr, television's Galloping Gourmet, has decided to perform from now on for an audience of one -- his wife, Treena.

In a dull trading session involving only 2,897,000 shares investors managed to bid up prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. The Amex index closed at 26.75. up 0.10.

Retail inventory losses -- the merchant's bane and also believed to be symtomatic of a deeply-rooted social problem -are down slightly so far in 1972, along with shoplifting and internal theft, a nationally known loss-prevention expert reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -A team of Moscow inventors was granted a United States patent this week for the TU144, the Soviet supersonic aircraft that was exhibited at the International Air Show in Le Bourget, France, in 1971.

MOSCOW, July 21 -- Soviet scientists prepared today for a soft landing of their latest Venus spacecraft tomorrow in the hope that it will supply the first chemical data on the surface of the distant planet.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The elimination of commercials from television programing for children could cost the major networks millions of dollars they could not replace, according to a study released today by the Federal Communications Commission.
