After two weeks on the sidelines with a virus infection, Roberto Clemente returned to action for the world champion Pittsburgh Pirates yesterday and saved them from a continuing state of embarrassment at the hands of the Cincinnati Reds.
CAIRO, July 23 -- In a mood of relaxed rejoicing, Cairo celebrated today the 20th anniversary of the nationalist revolution in which Gamal Abdel Nasser and his fellow officers overthrew the monarchy.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 23 (UPI) -- Major oil companies from Britain, the Netherlands, France and the United States began negotiations today with Iran's national oil company in an effort to extend standing export arrangements with the West, oil sources said.
KYOTO, Japan, July 8 -- This ancient seat of Japanese government and culture is beginning to feel the special truth of Wordsworth's line: "The world is too much with us."

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The American Civil Liberties Union, in a detailed report, has concluded that the response by Federal and local authorities to last year's May Day antiwar protests here amounted to "a profound blow to civil liberties" and a "suspension" of certain provisions of the Constitution.
Congress has resumed its work in this five-week period between the Democratic and Republican conventions, but the outlook for passing effective legislation is bleak.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 23 (UPI) -- Sassy, owned by E. Russell Schmidt of Grosse Pointe, and Windigo of Grand Rapids set a record pace today in the Chicago-to-Mackinac Island yacht race.

Pre-election rhetoric is having some dampening effect on consumer confidence, the Conference Board reported over the weekend. However, there has been a rise in optimism about the state of the economy, with a sharp drop in the number of people considering current business as "bad."
PITTSBURGH, July 23 -- The steel market appears to be recovering from the summer slowdown.
JERUSALEM, July 23 -- The Israeli Government, after heated public controversy, decided today to bar the return of two communities of Israeli Arabs to their former homes on the Lebanese border.
HANOI, North Vietnam, July 23 -- American air raids over Hanoi reached a peak this weekend and, according to an official communique, left many dead and wounded throughout the city.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- President Nixon will meet with Japan's new Premier, Kakuei Tanaka, in Hawaii on Aug. 31 and Sept. 1 for talks expected to concentrate on China and trade.

More than one-third of the 4.6 million people living in the eight metropolitan area counties of New Jersey close to New York City are of "foreign stock," according to a newly released study by the United States Census Bureau.

ACCRA, Ghana, July 22 -- Stressing a theme of self-reliance, the six-month-old military Government of Ghana is gambling that a spirited national program called Operation Feed Yourself will galvanize the nation, win popular support for "the soldiers" and also help to rescue a failing economy.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday ordered creation of an alcoholism program for permanent city employes afflicted with the disease. The program will be managed by the bureau of alcoholism of the city's Health Services Administration. The health agency will establish a unit to provide medical examinations, psychiatric and psychological evaluations.

Careful review of the qualifications of those graduates of Philathea College who are holding teaching or public service positions is clearly in order. Whether the obscure Canadian Bible college is an outright diploma mill remains to be determined; but, as indicated by recent disclosures in The Times, the institution is obviously in no position to train psychotherapists, classical scholars or educational administrators.

S-Night finally has arrived. After all the waiting, all the anticipation, and all the colorful reports from cities that span the continent, the Stones will open the final concerts of their 1972 tour tonight at Madison Square Garden.

NEW DELHI, July 23 (AP) -- The External Affairs Minister, Swaran Singh, said today that India and Poland had agreed to keep the 18-year-old international peace-keeping commission in Indochina in operation, to be ready for use when fighting in the region ends.

SYDNEY, Australia, July 23 -- The Chinese table tennis team's two-week tour of Australia was canceled today after its officials protested that the presence of a women's basketball team in Sydney from Taiwan at the same time was "a political plot."

"I called up all my friends," said Dee Strickland, "and told them I was taking a cruise -- to Poughkeepsie." On Saturday, Mrs. Strickland, who lives at 303 West 154th Street, did just that, along with 2,431 other persons, and unlike passengers on cruises to the Caribbean or around the world, it was difficult to find a complainer among them.
Assemblyman Antonio G. Olivieri of Manhattan urged yesterday that neighborhood family service centers be established to enforce special children's rules now in the jurisdiction of the Family Court.
Soul at the Center's program at Philharmonic Hall last night merited far better attendance than the half-full auditorium which greeted it.

AKRON, Ohio, July 23 -- Bert Yancey, who says he is practicing more and playing better golf, rolled in a putt for par and beat Tom Ulozas today at the first extra hole in a playoff of the $150,000 American Golf Classic.

RALEIGH, N. C., July 23 (AP) -- Kathy Whitworth, leading career money-winner in women's pro golf, successfully defended her laurels today in the $20,000 Raleigh classic, winning by two strokes from Marilynn Smith.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) -- Thirty members of Congress urged the United Nations today to take steps in the Security Council to punish countries that offer refuge to airline hijackers.
RYE, N. Y., July 23 -- The American Yacht Club cruise, extended this year, in its 41st running, to seven days, began shortly before noon on a white-capped sea today.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said yesterday that he was disappointed at the failure of efforts by his department and other law-enforcement agencies to curb organized crime, the narcotics traffic and police corruption.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- With the Nixon Administration preparing to resume the sale of offshore oil-drilling leases, the oil industry has begun a public-relations campaign to ease public fears that offshore exploration and production may be environmentally harmful.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 23 (AP) -- The United States won the American Zone final of the Davis Cup tennis competition today with a hard-fought doubles victory over Chile.

FORT WORTH, July 23 (AP) -- The United States Olympic Boxing Committee today announced the team for the Olympic trial finals beginning Aug. 5 at Bear Mountain, N. Y., to determine this country's entries in the Games.
DETROIT -- Being married almost triples a man's chances for success on the job.
"Soul at the Center" got off to a rocking start yesterday afternoon with a gospel service that had members of the audience at Alice Tully Hall hugging one another and capering in the aisles.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Confident that the most successful grass-roots appeal for small contributions in American politics will see them through what is likely to be the costliest Presidential year, fund raisers for Senator George McGovern are shrugging off the threat of defections by some of the Democratic party's largest donors.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 23 -- Glen View Stable's Copper Khan made a clean sweep of the open jumper division by winning the final class today at the closing session of the three day Lake Placid horse show.

WELLESVILLE, Pa., July 23 -- Ch. Mi-Le's Mischief Gold Pot triumphed at the third annual York Kennel Club show today. The Pomeranian, owned by Lady Conyers of Bermuda, defeated 1,577 rivals. It marked his sixth best-in-show award and his 16th group victory.

A dispute that had threatened to shut down a summer free-lunch program for 500,000 city children was resolved by Federal and state officials yesterday on terms acceptable to a group of food companies that had said they would discontinue their services.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 23, (UPI) -- Jimmy Connors defeated Andrew Pattison of Rhodesia in the final of the $25,000 Buckeye tennis tournament today, 7-5, 6-3, 7-5. The 19-year-old Illinois left-hander won $5,000 in prize money.

Less than two weeks ago, speculators were pouring hundreds of millions of dollars into Europe, mostly into West Germany, in anticipation of a dollar devaluation. As the flood of dollars rose, the Governor of the German Central Bank, Karl Klasen, was asked how much longer the Germans could go on taking dollars.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 23 -- Yugoslavia's drivers, who already endure one of the highest highway accident and death rates in Europe, are worrying about an added hazard this summer -- Turks hastening homeward from jobs in West Germany or other countries, usually in second-hand cars of uncertain condition, frequently with forged driving licenses and generally reluctant to spend money along the way for a night's lodging.

If you look at the relatively high prices on items at the Globe Food Market at 64th Street and First Avenue -- $1.79 a pound for fancy mushrooms compared with 90 cents for the more ordinary variety at the A. P. a block away and 36 cents for a quart of milk compared with the A. P.'s 32 cents -- you might conclude that the Globe is a gold mine.
George Meany's reluctance to support George McGovern's candidacy against a Republican Administration points up the dilemma in which workers find themselves these days.
Prices of tax-exempt bonds edged higher in moderately active trading yesterday, but long-term interest rates in the corporate and Treasury sectors showed practically no change at all.

The Senate is expected to begin consideration today of a marine mammal protection bill which falls far short of what is required if dolphins and other ocean mammals are to receive the timely help they urgently need. As reported from the Senate Commerce Committee, the bill is weaker than the already unsatisfactory bill passed by the House.
A proposed affiliation of three New England utilities into a single entity was approved yesterday, subject to certain conditions, by a Securities and Exchange Commission examiner.
Dawdling stock prices ended yesterday on the American Stock Exchange with the index up 0.16 to 26.94. It was the sharpest rise since May 12, when the index also made a 0.16-point gain.

BARCELONA, Spain, July 24 (UPI) -- Juan Gisbert beat Frantisek Pala of Czechoslovakia, 6-3, 6-3, 4-6, 6-0, to clinch the European Zone B final of the Davis Cup today and advance Spain to the next round against the United States.

WASHINGTO July 24 -- President Nixon's chief economic adviser told Congress today that it was a "delusion" to believe that the steep rise in Government spending could be covered by increasing taxes on "a few" people who are presumably not paying "their fair share."
BLACKSVILLE, W. Va., July 24 -- An explosion today in the Consolidation Coal Company's Blacksville No. 1 mine ended any hope of finding alive nine miners trapped in the mine since Saturday.

A high-level Wall Street operations committee has told the Securities and Exchange Commission that a proposed rule for the safekeeping and control of customer securities would be so onerous that it might jeopardize the public interest.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 24 -- More than 1,000 aerospace technologists and urban leaders convened here today to resume a dialogue that so far has produced more promises than mutual assistance.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 24 (AP) -- Former President Lyndon B. Johnson, who suffered a second heart attack in April, was hospitalized here tonight after suffering chest pains and nause.

DETROIT, July 24 -- The Chrysler Corporation today reported that its June-quarter profit had more than doubled to $68.4-million, or $1.33 a share, from $31.4-million, or 63 cents a share, a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Broad-based but nonscientific polls taken to preparation for drafting the Republican national platform in Miami Beach next month indicate that crime, drugs, inflation, welfare and Federal spending are among the most urgent issues facing Americans.

Friends of Mrs. Marit Gentele, whose husband, Goeran Gentele, director of the Metropolitan Opera, was killed in an automobile accident last week in Sardinia, said she was planning to return to New York by the opening of the new opera season in September.

SOUTH PORTLAND, Me., July 24 -- Workmen and residents of islands in Casco Bay are cleaning up island beaches and Portland Harbor of an estimated total of 40,000 gallons of industrial fuel oil that has spilled into the ocean from an oil tanker.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The White House today discounted as "clearly speculative" and "without substance" a published report from Lebanon crediting a meeting between President Nixon and the Saudi Arabian Defense Minister last month with having had a significant bearing on President Anwar el-Sadat's ouster of Soviet military advisers from Egypt.

The International Controls Corporation, whose major claim to fame has been its stake in I.O.S., Ltd. -- since sold -- told shareholders here yesterday that it had done well on its 18-month I.O.S. investment. But few shareholders seemed in the mood to hear it.

President Sadat and Egyptian missile crews have already undermined hope that last week's announcement of the expulsion of Soviet advisers from Egypt might mark a turn toward rationality and peace in the Middle East.
LAC DESERT, Quebec -- A fierce competitiveness lurks inside the restaurateur, Peter Kriendler, of New York City's 21 Club.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Price Commission, citing what it called inconsistent and unorthodox profit-margin reporting by big corporations, has tightened the reporting rules to require companion statements by a certified public accountant.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- New orders for durable goods soared in June to a record of $34.99-billion, the Commerce Department reported today. A surge of defense orders was partly responsible for the advance.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- In his speaking tour on behalf of the League of Nations in the fall of 1919, Woodrow Wilson told an audience: "Sometimes people call me an idealist. Well, that is the way I know I am an American. America is the only idealistic nation in the world."

SAIGON, Tuesday, July 25 -- Tamquan, a district capital in South Vietnam's central coast province of Binhdinh, has been recaptured by Saigon troops after two months of Communist occupation, an army spokesman reported yesterday.

In February 1970, after months of deliberation on various alternatives, President Nixon submitted a special message to Congress setting forth his recommendations for new legislation to deal with strikes in the transportation industry.
The creators of "Sesame Street" announced yesterday that they were planning to develop a series on health.

I am a naturalized American citizen, a professional man of moderate means, a liberal and a registered Democrat with a perfect record of party loyalty. I respect Senator McGovern's intelligence, his honesty and his ambition.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, July 25 (AP) -- South Vietnamese paratroops tried to storm the Citadel of Quangtri city yesterday but ran into withering enemy fire, according to reports from the scene, and at nightfall the outcome of the battle was said to be still in doubt.

The City Planning Commission voted at a special meeting yesterday to seek an amendment to the 1972-73 capital budget to provide $245.2-million more in state and city funds to enlarge and improve six sewage-treatment plants.
PARIS, July 24 -- Chinese representatives have signed a preliminary purchase agreement to buy two Concorde supersonic aircraft, it was announced today.
Rains in the plains states and talk of better export business combined to propel wheat prices upward yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 24 (UPI) -- The United States won the two remaining singles matches against Chile today for a 5-0 sweep of the American zone Davis Cup final.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 24 -- At the quarter-mark of the world championship chess match, Bobby Fischer seems to be well on his way to taking the title away from the Soviet Union, which has held it since Mikhail Botvinnik won the crown in 1948.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- President Nixon received a progress report today on the Government's crackdown on narcotics violation but told officials heading the drive that he wanted the number of arrests for drug violations doubled in the next year.

Periodically an article appears in some publication similar to the editorial "Watch Your Language" in the July 10 Times deploring the deterioration of English as a means of communication. Actually, such locutions as "far out," "where I'm at" and so on are additions, making expression sharper. Can anyone think of synonyms for such expressions?

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Two supporters of Senator George McGovern are preparing to offer personal assurances to the Israeli Government that the Democratic Presidential nominee would be a stanch ally in the White House.
The lingering oppressive heat has driven people all over the city out of their homes to spend nights in search of breezes and sleep in parks, on beaches, fire escapes and stoops.

The dollar was strong in world foreign-exchange markets yesterday, as traders continued to assess the Federal Reserve System's decision last week to intervene in the markets in support of the United States currency.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Senior American analysts believe China is rapidly building an arsenal of tactical nuclear weapons and special aircraft designed to deter a major Soviet military thrust across the long border, or to throw up a nuclear defense if deterrence should fail.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The House of Representatives narrowly approved today a bill to authorize Federal compensation to food growers, manufacturers, packers and distributors who claim to have lost money as a result of the Government's 1969 ban on the use of cyclamates as an artificial sweetner.
ATLANTA, July 24 -- Player representatives of the 24 major-league baseball teams took a novel but not necessarily promising step today -- they agreed with their owners on something.

Rafael Kubelik, the Czechoslovak-born conductor, agreed yesterday to strengthen his immediate involvement with the coming season of the Metropolitan Opera, which was to have been the first under the direction of the late Goeran Gentele.
From Dave Brinkley to the next-door neighbor, people are saying that Nixon will be hard to beat. It seems to me that only a miracle could cause his re-election.

A rather unlikely subject, silversmithing, is attracting more students every year in art schools and universities across the country -- three institutions in New York State give Masters of Fine Arts degrees in it -- but the question in an outsider's mind is likely to be: Wily are so many young persons interested in majoring in it? And, after taking it, what can they do with it?

Once again the New York area commuters are victims of the old railroad game. Despite U.S. Government 5.5 per cent guidelines, we have to pay a 23 per Cent increase in commuting fares. Along with that change in fares this month, we have been greeted with a new schedule.

SWANZEY, N.H., July 24 -- -- People in Swanzey say that the Lord watches over "The Old Homestead." On nights when the drama of rural Yankee life in the late 19th century is revived in the outdoor Potash Bowl here -- well, it just hardly ever rains.

A succession of cable failures at a Consolidated Edison substation cut off power yesterday to more than 400,000 people in Brooklyn and Queens and left them without air-conditioning or food refrigeration and, in some cases, without water.

Charging that the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn had no concern for their human rights, 25 of 55 prisoners scheduled to appear in Supreme Court yesterday refused to leave their cells in the Brooklyn House of Detention.

DENVER, July 24 -- Two California experts led the field of 168 pairs into the second semifinal session of the life master pairs championship in the Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League here tonight.

WASHINGTON -- After each one of Buffalo Bill's Wild West shows, Sitting Bull would give the money he had made to the ragged troupe of hungry children who always followed him. The famous Sioux chief never understood the white man's savage neglect of his own poor. The human indignity of begging was incomprehensible to him.
WHITE PLAINS, July 24 -- A flash fire destroyed the Penn Central's new high-level station platforms here this afternoon, disrupting service through the evening rush hour.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Senate, in a series of seesaw actions, adopted today an amendment requiring the withdrawal of American troops from Vietnam in exchange for release of prisoners of war, but then reversed itself by killing the over-all bill.

CUSTER, S. D., July 24 -- Senator George McGovern said today that as President he would not resume the bombing of North Vietnam even if there were difficulties in obtaining the release of prisoners of war after all United States forces had been withdrawn from Indochina.

Opening nights in New York, whether for the Rolling Stones or the Broadway theater, are fraught with the pains of nervous anxiety. When the Stones made it to the stage at Madison Square Garden last night for the closing concerts in their two-month American tour, there was at least the suspicion that the stomach butterflies were fluttering.

The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company reported yesterday that sales and earnings for the three months ended June 30 were the highest for any quarter in its history. The report also showed that profits in the first half exceeded $100-million and sales surpassed $1-billion, both for the first time.

Edward Gelsthorpe, president and chief executive officer of Hunt-Wesson Foods, Inc., a subsidiary of Norton Simon, Inc., will leave his job to become vice chairman-marketing for the Gillette Company on Sept. 1.

Bobby Womack, "The Soul Communicator," has a hoarse but penetrating voice and an explosive, declamatory style of delivery that ought to cut through steel walls. Steel walls, maybe. But he was engulfed in echoing rumble when he tried to push his voice through a foggy amplifying system last night at a Alice Tully Hall, where he shared a "Soul at the Center" program with the George Falson Universal Dance Experience and Diana Ramos.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a fraud suit today against a financial columnist for The Los Angeles Herald-Examiner, charging him with buying stock, then touting it in his column and finally selling it after the price went up.

This letter is in response to the recent editorials and letters regarding the recent flood disaster in the eastern United States. The germane point of all of these articles has been the suggestion to move the river-valley communities to higher land in the mountains.

Whether the astonishing work in E flat (K.271) is the greatest of the early Mozart piano concertos or the earliest of the great Mozart piano concertos is the kind of hair-splitting we may safely leave to the virtuosos of lobby discussion. But its indubitable greatness and earlyness certainly qualified the piece for inclusion on the opening program of the Mostly Mozart Festival last night at Philharmonic Hall.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) -- James D. Hodgson, Secretary of Labor, said today that the Administration had found jobs or job training for at least 1.3 million Vietnam-era veterans during the 12 months ending June 30.
A drug commonly used to control irregular heartbeats has shown initial promise in blocking the psychological and behavioral effects of drinking alcohol, a leading researcher in alcoholism has found.

Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein urged the City Council yesterday to investigate what he alleged to be a wide disparity in the rate of welfare applicants placed on the rolls in the city's 43 welfare centers.

Coney Island Hospital officials charged yesterday that heart patients were dying needlessly because the hospital had not been permitted to hire nurses to staff a newly completed addition to the coronary care unit.

JERUSALEM, July 24 -- Four surface-to-air missiles were fired at Israeli Air Force planes flying over the Sinai Peninsula today from a battery on the Egyptian-held western bank of the Suez Canal, the Israeli military spokesman announced. The last such attack occurred in September, 1971.

Earlier this month, British Minister William Whitelaw risked violent reaction from militant Ulster Protestants and abuse from his own Conservative party by meeting secretly with leaders of the Irish Republican Army Provisionals. In discarding his previous pledge never to negotiate with gunmen, Mr. Whitelaw thus indicated that the "Provos" could help shape Northern Ireland's future if only they would halt the terrorism.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 24 (AP) -- B. J. Brown's Jolly Fox took the lead on the backstretch and triumphed by 6 1/2 lengths today in the $8,500 Ocean Township Purse at Monmouth Park.

It is a matter of growing concern in the mutual fund industry that, every month for the last several months and from time to time before that, more mutual fund shares are turned in than are purchased. But, as in all run-downs of industry results, the general figure masks considerable variations within.
A demerit-prone cadet has won a court order preventing his expulsion from the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y.
JERUSALEM, July 24 -- The Government of Israel is quietly intensifying the establishment of new settlements in the lands captured from the Arab countries in the 1967 war.

ATLANTA, July 24 -- The appropriate procedure, of course, would be for Henry Aaron to hit a game-winning home run for the National League in tomorrow's All-Star Game spectacular in the Atlanta Stadium. That was Babe Ruth's style and Henry already is crowding in on the Babe in inexorable approach to one Ruthian record of majestic proportions, the career mark of 714 homers.
STOCKHOLM, July 24 (UPI) -- A Swedish journalist said today that he saw United States planes bomb civilian targets in North Vietnam Saturday.

The rift between Senator George McGovern and Democratic party leaders in this state is so serious that it is unlikely that the Presidential nominee will be able to win more than token support from many of the leaders.

About 40 young heroin addicts now undergoing rehabilitation picketed the DeMille Theater, Seventh Avenue and 47th Street, yesterday in protest against what they felt was the light treatment of addiction in the film "Come Back Charleston Blue," in its premiere engagement at the DeMille.
PARIS, July 24 -- The European Economic Community accused 22 sugar-refining companies today of flouting the interest of the consumer by restraining competition and keeping prices artificially high.

The Norfolk Western Railway Company reported yesterday a loss of $22,406,000 for the second quarter of 1972, including special charges totaling $44,266,000 to provide for a decline in the company's investments in Dereco, Inc., a subsidiary that includes the Erie Lackawanna Railway.
Dance came into its own at "Soul at the Center" last night at Alice Tully Hall with Diana Ramos and George Faison, black choreographers who have something to say and who say it very well.

FISHERS ISLAND, N. Y., July 24 -- Herbert L. Jamison Jr.'s and Rudolph J. Schaefer 3d's Fair American, sailed by Jamison, won the Commodore John B. Shethar Bowl today. The 84-foot sloop placed first in Division I, on corrected time, on the 81-mile distance race which opened the American Yacht Club's 41st annual cruise.

Richard Nixon's Agnew move, a sort of king's pawn opening to his campaign, apparently gives the President a needed opportunity to bring king's rook -- John Connally -- into play as well. If he develops that line of attack properly, Mr. Nixon himself may have little more to do this autumn than call Bobby Fischer in the locker room at the moment Spassky falls.

MOSCOW, July 24 -- Iosif Brodsky, the Russian poet who left for the United States last month, has appealed to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, for the right to return eventually to the Soviet Union.

An electric power failure in Queens forced the cancellation of the thoroughbred racing card at Aqueduct yesterday, disappointing about 22,000 fans, the expected attendance for a hot Monday in July, plus thousands more who normally wager at the city's 82 off track betting shops.

Two main philosophies about corruption have emerged in the last three weeks as city officials and construction industry executives have sat down together to grope for antidotes to the poisonous graft that pervades the building business in New York.

The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle with the staff of the Federal Trade Commission that would create a new corporate organization in settlement of an antitrust action by the F.T.C.
PRAGUE, July 24 (Reuters) -- Two more subversion trials opened in Czechoslovakia today, one of them carrying the possibility of 10-year prison terms for the defendants.
The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has found "reasonable cause to believe" that McCann-Erickson violated the law by maintaining a discriminatory hiring policy for minority groups.
"It's a wipe-out," Mrs. Giselle Szanto said yesterday as she looked around at the empty freezers in her Carvel store at Queens Boulevard and 82d Street.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- At least 15 calls to President Nixon's campaign organization were placed from telephones in the home and office of a man said to have led the break-in at the offices of the Democratic National Committee on June 17.
MANSON, N. C., July 24 -- On a green hill near this tiny town, an ancient antebellum mansion sits as both a monument to the past and a sign of the times.
CAIRO, July 24 -- President Anwar el-Sadat today blamed the Soviet Union's "excessive caution" as an ally for his decision to demand the departure of Soviet military personnel.

LOS ANGELES, July 24 (AP) -- Ricardo Chavez-Ortiz, an unemployed father of eight who hijacked a jetliner last April and then held a gun on newsmen as he poured out his troubles in a radio broadcast, was convicted of air piracy today and sentenced to life imprisonment.

With the advent of New York's first protracted high-temperature period of 1972 and its concommitant strain on power resources, it was hardly surprising that the occasion coincided with your front-page account of a State Public Service Commission announcement.
As if Con Edison did not have enough trouble with the heat wave, the utility is going to have to deliver a staggering amount of current this week to keep the Rolling Stones rolling.

Robert Martin McKiernan signaled his ascension yesterday to the presidency of the 25,000-member Patrolmen's Benevolent Association with a virulent denunciation of Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 24 (UPI) -- Rod Laver, miffed over not being seeded, quickly defeated Tom Leonard 6-0, 6-3 today in the opening round of the $50,000 First National Tennis Classic.
The Health Department has cited 21 more restaurants and food-precessing establishments for serious violations of the city Health Code.

ATLANTA, July 24 -- Bob Gibson of the St. Louis Cardinals and Jim Palmer of the Baltimore Orioles were named the starting pitchers today for baseball's 43d All-Star Game, which will be played in the home of the Atlanta Braves here tomorrow night before a sellout crowd of 52,744 fans and a national television audience.
TOKYO, July 24 -- A district court in central Japan found six large industrial companies guilty of air pollution today and ordered them to pay $286,350 in damages to 12 plaintiffs.

A drug overdose administered in the prison killed an inmate found dead on Rikers Island on Saturday, the Chief Medical Examiner's office reported yesterday. Aides to Dr. Milton Helpern, the Medical Examiner, said that the prisoner, 29-year-old John Smith, was the second inmate in city jails to die of an illegal drug dosage this year.
The net income of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) fell in the quarter and six months ended June 30.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 24 -- Secretary General Waldheim and Secretary of State William P. Rogers clashed today over charges that the United States bombing had intentionally damaged dikes in North Vietnam.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 24 -- Vice President Agnew outlined today the Republican campaign position on the environment as choosing "progress as a nation" instead of "an end to growth and an end to technological progress."

A suspended patrolman pleaded guilty yesterday to attempting to commit perjury at the time he was a witness at a closed-door session of the Knapp Commission investigation into allegations of corruption in the Police Department.

CALCUTTA, India, July 24 (AP) -- The sacred scarves that symbolize the throne of Bhutan passed today to a teen-ager who was brought to his Himalayan homeland in the late nineteen-sixties to learn how to be king.
The stock market responded to highly favorable economic news yesterday by rocketing to its biggest gain of 1972.

AKRON, Ohio, July 24 (UPI) -- D. Donald Lowers, a lawyer whose multimillion-dollar investment scheme collapsed in bankruptcy leaving him $11-million in debt, pleaded guilty today to 26 counts of selling unregistered securities.

YONKERS, July 24 -- As Yonkers Raceway reopened tonight for its second-half, 72-card season, the start of the first event was three minutes late. No one seemed to mind, because for more than eight hours picketing security guards had threatened to cancel the first program.
The Rolling Stones, considered by many the most exciting rock 'n' roll band in the world, whipped 20,000 fans into a frenzy last night at the first of four sold-out concerts in Madison Square Garden.
Stock prices soared yesterday in their best showing of 1972 in response to the latest Government reports of a rapidly expanding economy.
The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a Jersey shore municipality could not charge nonresidents higher fees than residents for the use of a municipal beach.

The State Joint Legislative Committee on Crime presented evidence yesterday that the politically well-connected father of a correction officer arrested on a major drug charge went to see the assistant Brooklyn district attorney handling the case.

The Anaconda Company reported yesterday dramatic gains in second-quarter and first-half net income after inclusion of certain extraordinary items. However, John B. M. Place, president and chief executive officer, was quick to point out that all divisions were profitable in the first half and contributed to the earnings gains.

Sgt. David Durk, a key witness in the Knapp Commission investigation of corruption in the Police Department, foiled and captured two alleged muggers on a street on Manhattan's West Side last night with the aid of his service revolver and a pizza.

"Extraordinary growth" and lower loss ratios justify sharp premium cuts for the more than 700,000 New York motorists required to buy automobile liability coverage through the assigned risk plan, a State Insurance Department actuary testified yesterday.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 24 -- After asking for, and getting, a one-week delay in reporting to training camp, Joe Namath showed up eight hours before the ii P.M. deadline yesterday. But the New York Jet's quarterback is still not completely in the fold.
ROME, July 24 -- The three major Italian trade unions today ratified a labor-federation pact that many Italians hope is a step toward unification of the labor movement here.

Wilt Chamberlain thinks he is underpaid. Desperately late, the House Banking and Currency Committee is at last getting down to business on the Housing and Urban Development Act of 1972, one of the most comprehensive and important pieces of housing legislation of the past three decades. DETROIT, July 25 -- New car sales in the middle third of July totaled 274,272 units against 260,990 the year before.
