WASHINGTON, July 26 -The State Department today disputed a dispatch of The New York Times from Brussels that described members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as "baffled and bitter" at President Nixon's signing of a declaration of principles with the Soviet party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, in Moscow.

DENVER, July 26 -- A New York pair became the first in the history of the game to win the life master pair championship at the Summer Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League two straight years. Alvin Roth of New York and Barbara Rappaport of East Orange, N. J., last night repeated their 1971 victory in Chicago, and established a strong claim to be regarded as the world's best mixed partnership.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- A former bank clerk told a House committee today that he agreed to have horses registered in his name after being "wined and dined" by a horse broker blacklisted by the racing establishment.
Moderate profit advances were reported yesterday by several major oil concerns for the quarter and six-month periods ended June 30.

PARIS, July 26 -- Emanuel Ungaro made it. After being known as promising for several years, he was finally acclaimed today as having produced the best collection in Paris. Of course, the competition wasn't staggering.

When Eldridge Waith was promoted to assistant chief inspector in charge of all of Manhattan north of 59th Street a little over four years ago, he became one of the two highest-ranking blacks in the Police Department.

TRENTON, July 26 -- A series of hearings on proposed wider legalized gambling in New Jersey opened here today in the wake of the defeat last week of a state income-tax bill proposed by Gov. William T. Cahill as part of a sweeping tax-reform program.

Paperback rights to "I'm O.K. -- You're O.K.," a lay-man's guide to self-analysis by Dr. Thomas A. Harris, have been sold by Harper Row to Avon Books for $1-million. That figure is believed to be the highest for the reprint sale of a single book in publishing history.
"So I go from diplomacy to politics," said Kenneth B. Keating at a luncheon in New Delhi marking his farewell as United States Ambassador to India.

The Rolling Stones and radical chic came together last night in a virtually nonradical chic came together stop musical-theatrical series of events that stretched from Madison Square Garden to the roof of the St. Regis Hotel.

PRAGUE, July 26 (Reuters) -- Six persons were jailed for terms ranging from 26 months to five years today on subversion charges in the central Moravian town of Brno. It was the fifth subversion trial in Czechoslavakia in the last nine days.
LIGONIER, Pa., July 26 -Jack Nicklaus, who underwent surgery yesterday for an infected index finger on his right hand, is out of the national team golf championship.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 26 -- Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky played to a draw today after 49 moves in the resumption of their adjourned seventh game. The score now stands at 4 to 3 in favor of the American challenger.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -The Export Import Bank has authorized a $4,455,000 loan for United States imports to be used in construction of an offshore drilling yard at Cromarty Firth, Scotland, the bank announced today.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, July 26 -- North Korean Red Cross negotiators indicated today that they would accept Seoul as the place for the first session of the full - scale North-South Red Cross talks scheduled to open on Aug. 5 to discuss ways of reuniting separated Korean families.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Soviet authorities have given a New York company a virtual monopoly in the distribution of Soviet motion pictures in the United States and in the production of films in the Soviet Union for showing on American television.

The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stockholdings by major shareholders, directors and officers of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange has not made such a list available this week.

HOUSTON, July 26 (AP) -- Col. David R. Scott of the Air Force, commander of Apollo 15 and one of three astronauts recently reprimanded for smuggling 400 stamp covers to the moon and back, has been dropped from the astronaut corps and given a space agency desk job.

ATLANTA, July 26 -- Before the All-Star Game last night. Gaylord Perry of the Indians seemed to sense what the script called for. He grinned at Jim Palmer of the Orioles and Wilbur Wood of the White Sox, two fellow pitchers on the American League squad.
When a new ad agency opens and is hard-pressed for business, some very interesting prospective clients often come knocking on the door with some unusual and generally cut-rate arrangements in mind.
Lower earnings, revenues and shipments for the second quarter and first half of the year were reported yesterday by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

The main multibillion-dollar contract for development of the nation's space shuttle, a vehicle that will vault into space like a rocket but land like an airplane, was awarded yesterday to North American Rockwell
Educators throughout the country are becoming increasingly concerned about the growing number of unaccredited colleges and universities that are sprouting on the fringes of academe.
As an Argentine very much concerned with his country, I wish to make a few comments about Juan Peron's recent presidential nomination.

MUNICH, West Germany, July 26 (AP) -- Organizers of the Olympic Games, which open Aug. 26, knuckled down this week to solve problems uncovered during the five days of the West German sports championships held last week at the Games complex here.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -Nothing better illustrates the change that is beginning to be felt in the traditionalist House of Representatives than the adoption of an end-the-war amendment by the Foreign Affairs Committee.
The Mostly Mozart Festival, which began at Philharmonic Hall on Monday, lost no time in breaking away from Mozart to concentrate on Bach, the guest composer of the festival, as it were.
Two cancer researchers say they have confirmed through human lung cancer cases the theory that occupational exposure to asbestos enhances the cancer-causing effects of cigarette smoke.

The pin-up girl of the nineteen-twenties and thirties was redhaired. The screen idols women wanted to be like were (depending, of course, on the generation they belonged to) Clara Bow, Nancy Carroll and Ann Sheridan.
WASHINGTON, July 26 Canada and the United States resumed trade talks today in a distinctly warmer atmosphere than when Washington broke off the dialogue in frustration in February.

HONOLULU, July 26 -- Senator Thomas F. Eagleton indicated on his arrival here today that if public opinion polls over the next 10 days or two weeks showed a strongly unfavorable response to his disclosures of medical illness, he would withdraw from the ticket as the Democratic VicePresidential nominee, regardless of Senator George McGovern s encouragement of him in the last two days.
The city's public utilities specialist, Dr. Charles Lawrence, castigated Consolidated Edison yesterday for its "unforgivable" performance during the heat wave.
Feminists around the country are planning demonstrations for the week ending on Aug. 26, the 52d anniversary of the ratification of the 19th Amendment, which gave women the right to vote.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 26 -- If Gary Hammond could divide himself like an amoeba it wouldn't be long before he might make up an entire football team -- complete with substitutes. Right now his name pops up in more places on the New York Jets' depth chart than anybody else.
The Health Department has made public the names of 21 more restaurants and food stores in which it has found serious violations of the City Health Code.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., July 26 -- They came around one day in 1932 and told Charles Pollard he could get a free physical examination the next afternoon at a nearby one-room school.
A little squeeze play developed yesterday in old-crop soybeans -- the August delivery. Prices moved up about 3 cents a bushel to close at $3.50 1/2.
TRENTON, July 26 -- Six patrolmen taking part in a job action, today tied up 14 miles of the Palisades Interstate Parkway, from the George Washington Bridge to the Rockland County line.

AMAGANSETT, L. I. -- For vacationers in the Hamptons, their appetites whetted by salt air and summertime activities, food is certainly no problem, not even for those inclined to do the cooking at home rather than to dine out.
If you know enough about an automobile to repair one, you may be able to get a very good buy in a used car right now.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Senate, in its first major test on the defense budget, approved funds today to start construction on a fourth nuclear-powered aircraft carrier that will cost at least $1-billion.

An offering of 1,081,000 shares of Avon Products capital stock at $117 was announced after the close of the market yesterday by an underwriting group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., and Hornblower Weeks-Hamphill Noyes.
LONDON, July 26 (AP) -- Both the U. S. dollar and the British pound weakened in European foreign exchanges today although both currencies tended to firm at the close of business.

A man close enough to menbers of the Phillips family to be called "Uncle Leo" by them testified yesterday that he was with Patrolman William R. Phillips and his wife until 7 or 7:30 on the night that James Smith and Sharon Stango were murdered.
The Navy has written to Litton Industries expressing "significantly increased" concern over the company's ability to carry out its $1-billion contract to build five LHA amphibious-assault ships.

ATHENS, July 26 -- A multimillion dollar Greek oil refinery concession, a bone of contention between two shipping millionaires, Aristotle S. Onassis and Stavros S. Niarchos, was awarded by decree today to two other Greek shipowners.

PepsiCo, Inc., and the Wilson Sporting Goods Company, 88.2 per cent owned by PepsiCo, announced yesterday tender offers amounting to about $25million in connection with a previously announced proposal for PepsiCo to acquire all outstanding equity securities of Wilson by January, 1973.
CUSTER, S. D., July 26 - Senator George McGovern stood firm today against mounting pressure from some of his supporters to drop his VicePresidential running mate, Senator Thomas F. Eagleton.
Four persons were shot and[ wounded, at least one criti-[ cally, when five armed men! invaded a Brooklyn bar early yesterday.

A gospel service began the current forthnight of "Soul at the Center" program last Sunday, and the musical message of Jesus rang out again last night at Alice Tully Hall, punctuated by the shouts, cheers and occasionally the dancing-in-the-aisles of the small but jubilantly enthusiastic audience.
The trick was to get 1,000 kites flying and keep the 250,000 feet of string being held by 1,000 children running on Central Park's Sheep Meadow from becoming one gigantic tangle.

The Treasury's huge exchange offering, announced after the formal close of bond trading yesterday, met with general approval in Wall Street despite the reservations of some that the Government might not get as many takers as it hoped.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Senator Thomas F. Eagleton's disclosure yesterday that he had submitted three times to treatment for nervous exhaustion and fatigue may be a political event of the first magnitude and it may not.

The Olympic ideals are becoming scarce, Avery Brundage said recently. His latest battle was staged yesterday when Brundage, the president of the International Olympic Committee, warned Kenya to keep Government out of the selection process for that country's Olympic team.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 26 -- Brazil's Roman Catholic Bishops in the last two months have begun to stake out a clear position as defenders of the little man and champions of human rights in a country where varying degrees of repression are the rule.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 26 -- Did Bobby Fischer miss a victory in the continuation of his adjourned seventh game with Boris Spassky? This is the question heatedly discussed by the grandmasters and experts assembled here.

DEAL, N. J., July 26 -- Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks carded a 79 today for a two-round total of 155 and tied the first-round leader Cindy Ferro of Forest Hill, in the 39th Women's Metropolitan Golf Association 54-hole stroke-play championship at the Hollywood Country Club.

PEKING, July 26 -- Peking's official newspaper, the oracle of Chinese Communism for more than a quarter of a century, has opened a sudden campaign against the turgid prose that fills Chinese publications, including its own formerly unassailable pages.
For the 19 months Herbert J. Stern has been the United States Attorney for New Jersey, he has, he says, devoted his energies and those of his staff to the nonpartisan prosecution of corruption.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The retail price of farm-produced foods, which has been a weak point in the Government's anti-inflation program, rose sharply again in June, the Department of Agriculture reported today.
No one who lived through the third week of July in New York City needs to be told about the electric power shortage.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The first United States diplomat to be stationed in Iraq since the Arab-Israeli war in 1967 will be going to Baghdad shortly, State Department officials said today.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 26 (AP) -- Guerrillas burned a country club and set off more than 20 time bombs today, on the 20th anniversary of the death of Mrs. Eva Duarte de Peron. She was the wife of Maj. Gen. Juan D. Peron, deposed as President in 1955.

The United States International balance of payments showed a sharp improvement in the second quarter on one measure but little change on another, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company estimated yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, July 26 -- A special three-judge panel of Federal appellate judges, including Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas, met in a Pasadena hotel room this morning and stayed the beginning of the Pentagon papers trial until a wiretapping issue was resolved.
In "Fat City," John Huston's fine film version of Leonard Gardner's novel, life is having a cigarette and no match -- then finding a match and getting slightly ill on the first puff.

Demonstrating how a Bronx gasoline station at 175th Street and Jerome Avenue allegedly tampered with its pumps to deliver less gasoline than was being registered, Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson announced yesterday that inspections of the city's 5,000 filling stations would be stepped up.
Columbia University's chief spokesman said yesterday that the administration would consider new security measures as a result of the shooting of a college dean on Tuesday.
On a clear day you can see the future -- on the Avenue of the Americas. On a hot summer day, when the city levitates, but relaxes, some of the splendor of the season transfers to the streets.

BRUSSELS, July 27 (Reuters) -- The Belgian Central Bank and the banking commission completed details of the gentlemen's agreement with major commercial banks of the plan to withdraw 10,000-million francs from circulation through interest-free special deposits by the commercial banks at the Central Bank, the Central Bank said today.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Delegations of governors and mayors have trooped to Washington in recent days to have coffee with President Nixon, testify before the Senate Finance Committee, and lobby their Senators for passage of the revenue-sharing bill. Already approved by the House in June and strongly backed by the Nixon Administration, this measure would provide $5.3 billion annually to the states, counties and cities.
LONDON, July 26 -- Britain's industrial crisis eased today with the release of five dock workers whose imprisonment had led to widespead unofficial strikes by thousands of workers.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, July 27 -- South Vietnamese paratroopers hoisted their national flag over the Citadel in Quangtri yesterday but reports from the field said that pockets of enemy soldiers remained in and around the battle-scarred fortress.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 26 (AP) -- In her second start since winning the Regret Stakes at Churchill Downs in May, Mrs. Pamela Furman's Nalees Folly came from the middle of the pack to win the $20,450 Seashore Stakes by 1 1/4 lengths today at Monmouth Park.
A smoky smelly fire in two Consolidated Edison transformer vaults in the Wall Street area early yesterday forced the closing of several buildings, and disrupted securities processing.

The Federal Bureau of Prisons is beginning to put into effect a ten-year plan for building more than sixty new correctional facilities that will cost taxpayers over $650 million at present estimates. This is well-intended, under President Nixon's mandate to make the Federal prison system a "model," but such a construction program seems to many critics the wrong way to proceed.

DEARBORN, Mich., July 26 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company announced today that it had met 4,000-mile emission-control test requirements for seven of 12 engine "families" for its 1973-model cars. Thirty-five vehicles have passed the tests.
The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) elected a new president yesterday and the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation named a new chief executive officer.
Adrienne Lederman (letter July 7) seems to think police and fire sirens could be less noisy.

MANHASSET, L.I., July 26 -John Mangan of Rye, Dr. Richard Raskind of New York and Warren Woodcock of Forest Hills, Queens, reached the quarterfinals of the national clay-court tennis championship for men 35 years and over at the Shelter Rock Tennis Club today.
Increased earnings and record revenues were reported yesterday by The New York Times Company for the second quarter and first six months of this year.

Shares of the New Process Company fell 8 3/8 yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. The stock, the most actively traded issue of the day, closed at 21 after selling for most of the week below last Friday's close of 33 1/2.
The selling began in earnest yesterday -- but there was a prelude on Tuesday. Behind it was another round of the game the institutions play -- which might be called, "Let's get out of old X fast."
In his July 14 letter, John Cabot Grampp asks if it is possible that the winning numbers in New York State's 50-cent lottery are those of unsold tickets.

Braulio Baeza heard jeers at Aqueduct yesterday, and just about a half-hour later he heard cheers. The impassive rider from Panama was the target of the boos of many in the crowd of 23,049 after he had finished out of the money on an odds-on favorite, but he bounced right back to win the feature and the consequent applause.

ST. LOUIS, July 26 -- Physicians who treated Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, holding to principles of medical ethics, declined today to comment or disclose further information on the Missouri legislator's history of psychiatric treatment and hospitalization, including electric shock therapy for "depression."

Four Jewish organizations called yesterday for the removal of Luis J. Fuentes as superintendent of Community School District 1 on the Lower East Side because of what they called his "hostility to Jews."

WASHINGTON, July 26 - President Nixon appealed to Congress today to protect the "economic interest of all American citizens" by enacting a $250-billion spending ceiling, and threatened to veto any measure he deemed excessive
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Federal Reserve Board "is in a favorable position to continue pursuing a path of moderate monetary growth," its chairman, Arthur F. Burns, told Congress today.

A commission of inquiry in Uganda, headed by a British judge, has confirmed what had long been assumed: Two Americans investigating the report of a tribal massacre in the Ugandan Army were murdered by Ugandan troops July 9, 1971. Now it is up to General Idi Amin, Uganda's military ruler, to make good his pledge on appointing the commission that he would prosecute vigorously any officers implicated in the killings.
The stock market posted a slight decline yesterday for the second straight day. There was some weakness in glamour issues, steels, chemicals, airlines and oils.

Mario M. Cuomo, appointed by Mayor Lindsay to mediate the Forest Hills low-income housing controversy, yesterday recommended a 50 per cent reduction in the size of the project, and was immediately assailed by both sides.

Anthologies are an agony to review. Coming to terms with a book by a single writer is difficult enough, but here, in "Doors and Mirrors," I'm facing 44 of them, from 14 countries, and I feel that they are all shouting at me. Yet I think that this anthology, by Hortense Carpentier and Janet Brof is a good one, the best collection of Spanish-American writing I've read so far.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 26 -- The Burger Chef fast-food operation, on which General Foods took a $39.7-million after tax write-off in fiscal 1972, is now operating in the black, C. W. "Tex" Cook told 750 stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.
The Howard Johnson restaurants and Motor Lodges account will be returning on Oct. 31 to Boston, which it left in 1968.
Where Mama Goldberg's kosher restaurant once served matzoh ball soup on Second Avenue, the Flower Drum Restaurant now serves Nixon-Chou banquets at $10 a head.

WASHINGTON, July 26 - Senator George McGovern's campaign manager proposed today that President Nixon and Vice President Agnew join their Democratic challengers in making detailed disclosures about their health.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Treasury today offered holders of nearly $20-billion of securities maturing as far in the future as 1975, a package of exchange options, including a new 12-year bond to yield 6.45 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today that it had awarded $375-million since the beginning of the year to schools that train doctors, dentists, nurses, veterinarians and other health professionals.
EUREKA SPRINGS, Ark., July 24 -- On one page of Down Home, the town's new underground newspaper, an article announced the birth of a baby to a popular couple in the "freak" community.

MOSCOW, July 26 -- Gavriil I. Shapiro, the Jewish activist who has sought emigration to Israel and has evaded active duty as a reserve officer in the Soviet armed forces, was sentenced today to one year's correctional work without loss of freedom.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Government officials and conservationists called today for an international treaty to protect the polar bear.

JERUSALEM, July 26 - Premier Golda Meir appealed to President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt today to join in making a new start toward peace in the Middle East, to "meet as equals, and make a joint supreme effort to arrive at an agreed solution."

GENEVA, July 26 -- The Common Market announced today that it would cancel most of a series of special import taxes that the United States had complained were in violation of the European bloc's international trade commitments.

Democrats need not succumb to despair because George Meany refuses to endorse the McGovern-Eagleton ticket. In 1968 the Democratic ticket had the solid support of labor; moreover there was no ogre of McGovern extremism to frighten the electorate. Yet the Hubert Humphrey whom Mr. Meany embraced lost to the Richard Nixon whom he abhors.

When the Mets began this season, they were depending on a $95,000 player to lead them to the pennant. Now, as they struggle to stay in the pennant race, they're relying on a player whom they once valued at $500.
YONKERS, July 26 (UPI) -Sonnetson, driven by Ken McNutt, captured the $6,000 New Haven Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

LONG POND, Pa., July 26 -Peter Revson survived a series of bad breaks today, including a blown engine, to lead the field in the second and final day of qualifying for Saturday's Schaefer 500 auto race.

President Nixon has asked Governor Rockefeller, once a political rival, to place his name in nomination at the Republican National Convention in Miami Beach next month, Republican sources said last night.

Con Edison should be commended for its "Save-a-Watt" campaign. However, in view of the current power crisis, it is unfair to expect city residents to cope with brownouts and blackouts in this heat wave. Fans, air conditioners, refrigerators and freezers (not to mention lighting) are essential for comfort in the summer.
A Buildings Department inspector was dismissed from his job yesterday after he pleaded guilty to taking a $100 bribe. He was the eighth inspector to be cited for corruption in the last month.

The Metropolitan Museum, which already owns 10 undisputed Goya paintings, added another major work of the Spanish master to its collection this week. A full-length portrait of a young boy, the canvas is valued at $2-million to $3-million by Jose Lopez-Rey, one of the world's leading Goya experts. He believes the oil is one of the artist's masterpieces and one of his best portraits.

BUENOS AIRES, July 26 -Argentina's anti-inflationary forces suffered a sharp setback when the resignation of Carlos S. Brignone as president of the central bank was announced by the military Government here just before midnight yesterday.

The honor of the United States, solvency of the United Nations and prospects for international cooperation for peace will all be at issue when a Congressional conference committee meets soon to consider a State Department appropriations bill.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -The United States armed services overrode State Department resistance in 1947 and began an arms program for Latin America aimed at consolidating United States military influence and excluding "foreign" ideologies from the hemisphere.

Mrs. Clayton L. Thomas is flying high these days. When she's not in a show ring, the Palmer, Mass., resident might be up in the clouds. She is secretary-treasurer of a balloon school. She also is president of the Pembroke Welsh Corgi Club of America and her license plate is CORGI 1.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 26 -- With Pete Gogolak giving cause for joy with his place-kicking and Joe Taffoni, an offensive tackle, apparently ready to start, plans for the football Giants' opening preseason game Saturday in Canton, Ohio, took positive form today.

HAKONE, Japan, July 26 (AP) --Japan rejected United States requests today to ease its import restrictions on American goods, particularly farm products, to help correct bilateral trade imbalance heavily in favor of Japan.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- United States intelligence sources say there are "strong indications" that the Soviet Union is removing from Egypt most of its warplanes assigned with Soviet flying crews to the Egyptian air defenses.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Administration said today that any damage done to the North Vietnamese dike system by American bombing was accidental and had only "the most incidental and minor impact" on the system.

LAKE FOREST, Ill., July 26 -- To leave last place in their division this coming football season, the Giants will probably have to climb over the St. Louis Cardinals, a team in transition. Such prospects do not seem bright for New York, because Bob Hollway, the coach performing surgery on the Cardinals, says he has made much progress.

Not every long-haired troublemaker has returned to "the system" through George McGovern, the Presidential candidate with the Tim Leary smile. Though George has received the enthusiastic endorsements of such counterculture heavies as Abbie Hoffman, Jerry Rubin and Rolling Stone magazine, it is not because McGovern is a radical, but because Yippies Hoffman and Rubin have ceased being so and Rolling Stone never was.
At the height of lawsuits, contractbreaking and trust threats affecting the sports world, the American Basketball Association yesterday turned to a lawyer to become its new commissioner.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Ralph Nader and Consumers Union sued the Price Commission today in an effort to compel it to hold public hearings on the automobile companies' proposed increases of 2.5 to 3 per cent in the prices of 1973 models.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, July 27 (AP) -- At least 50 South Vietnamese marines were killed on July 11 in the worst recorded helicopter crash of the Vietnam war, the Saigon command acknowledged today for the first time.

The New York Plan, which was signed 19 months ago by Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay with promises to provide training for 800 blacks and Puerto Ricans in the construction industry, was condemned yesterday as a dismal failure.
The Coast Guard is encountering difficulty in maintaining its enlisted personnel strength at 35,000 men. A service spokesman has reported that the nationwide recruiting target in June was 900 men.
Two policemen were shot but not seriously wounded in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn last night while investigating reports of a previous shooting at the scene.

The General Accounting Office report on cost overruns of $28.7 billion on current weapons development programs is a useful reminder of continuing Pentagon inefficiency, if not of deliberate attempts to mislead the Congress by low estimates when weapons are being approved. But it misses the real point now in debate as the Senate votes on the defense procurement bill.
Twice this year, on July 4 and July 5, the Massachusetts lake trout record was broken by anglers fishing Quabbin Reservoir.
ATLANTA, July 26 -- The major leagues headed back to their pennant races today after an All-Star Game that produced another victory for the National League and new controversy for Earl Weaver.

Second-quarter sales and earnings of Philip Morris, Inc., set records and marked the 32d consecutive quarterly advance, the company reported yesterday. Revenues for the half exceeded the billion-dollar mark for the first time.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 26 -- A six-year study has shown that written tests to gauge future job performance do not discriminate against minority groups when the examinations are carefully administered, the Educational Testing Service announced here today.
PANAMA, July 26 (Reuters) -- Six Britons, including three children, arrived here yesterday after surviving 37 days adrift in a dinghy in the Pacific Ocean living on emergency rations and raw fish.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Senate rejected today legislation that would have required much of the oil imported into the United States to be carried on tankers flying the American flag.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 26 (AP) -- British troops and gunmen battled near Belfast's center today, and Protestant workers closed almost all of Northern Ireland's industry and commerce with strikes mourning the dead of last week's bombing.

An off-duty policeman, lying on an elevator floor and threatened with death by an armed man who had just robbed him, pulled a gun from his ankle holster and shot the assailant dead, the police said last night.

It is with great regret that I must agree with the premise in your recent editorial that "the proposed pumped-water storage plant on Storm King Mountain is still a long way from realization." With all the efforts that have been made by the public utilities in the East, we have barely been able to keep our heads above water with regard to energy requirements.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 27 -- The eighth game of the world championship chess match appears to have been a disaster for Boris Spassky. To the dismay of onlookers, Spassky, after 10 moves of an English opening that gave him at least equality despite his playing black, seemed unable to maintain the high quality of his play.

HONOLULU, July 27 -- Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, the embattled Democratic nominee for Vice President, denounced as a "damnable lie" today a charge by the columnist Jack Anderson that he had a record of arrests for drunken and reckless driving.
The July 17 Op-Ed article by Sally Kilby-Kelberg is insulting to me and my faith.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 27 (AP) -- American casualties in the Vietnam war last week included 10 persons killed in action, one killed in non-combat duty and 9 wounded, the United States command announced in its weekly summary today.

HARTFORD, July 27 -- Connecticut has acquired an option on a seat on the PBW Stock Exchange in Philadelphia, in order to trade common stocks directly in the management of state pension and retirement funds.

A few months before he was to have been ordained as an Episcopal priest in Santa Fe, N. M., James Richards and his wife, Wilma, a Roman Catholic, sat down and talked about just what they felt themselves to be.

Senator Allen J. Ellender of Louisiana, chairman of the Appropriations Committee and president pro tempore of the Senate, died last night of a heart attack at the Bethesda Naval Hospital in Maryland. He was 81 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -Three leading Democratic economists told Congress today that it would have to raise taxes next year, to become effective in 1974, and warned that the Nixon Administration was likely to try to slow the current economic expansion prematurely.
Without ceremony, work began yesterday on a new Columbia gymnasium, a project that has vexed the university since the end of the last century.

Shares had another day of downward drift on the American Stock Exchange yesterday with the index closing at 26.76, off 0.07. The trend in the over-the-counter market was also down, and the NASDAQ index closed at 135.80, off 0.50.

It was state-of-the- art rhythm and blues night at the "Soul at the Center" concert in Alice Tully Hall last night. The groups ran the gamut from the golden-oldie sounds of the revived Moonglows to the newer rhythms of Bobby Knight and the Soul Society, New Birth and the Niteliters.
Whatever the real significance of Egypt's recent move vis-a-vis the U.S.S.R., it is evident that relations between the two countries are at present seriously strained.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The United States Parole Board granted parole today to Ralph Ginzburg, the former publisher of Eros, a quarterly magazine, who was convicted of sending obscene material through the mail.
PRAGUE, July 27 (Reuters) -- The son of the former Communist party secretary Jaroslav Sabata was sentenced to two and a half years in prison for subversion, it was announced today.
TORONTO, July 27 (Canadian Press) -- The Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company, Ltd., announced today it was beginning construction of a $3.87-million sawmill in Kapuskasing.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 27 (AP) -- The 20th Special Forces Group has denied that a staged kidnapping came as a surprise to officials of Alabaster, a town some 20 miles south of here.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -The Nixon Administration announced today that the ceiling for increases of corporate dividends in 1973 would be 4 per cent, the same limitation that has been in effect this year as part of the wage-price controls program.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 27 -- Decisively whipping Boris Spassky -- even, for a while, toying with him -- Bobby Fischer moved into a commanding 5-3 lead today in the world championship chess match.

President Nixon's biting attack on critics of his Indochina policy at his news conference yesterday is not likely to stem the rising tide of antiwar sentiment that found expression in both houses of Congress this week.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 27 -- The director of Gov. George C. Wallace's Presidential campaign is expected to announce here Saturday that the wounded candidate will not run on a third-party ticket this year.

Israeli Prime Minister Golda Meir gave full recognition to the potential significance of President Sadat's eviction of Soviet advisers from Egypt when she told the Knesset: "It would seem that this hour in the history of Egypt can, may, should be the appropriate hour for change. And, if it truly is the hour for change, let it not be missed."

AT the outset of the Paris Peace Conference of 1919 someone suggested to Woodrow Wilson that he might find it useful to read a handbook, which had been written for the British delegation by C. K. Webster, about the Congress of Vienna and the international system it created.

RUMSON, N. J., July 27 -Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks shot a 77 today for a total of 232 and won the 39th Women's Metropolitan Golf Association 54-hole stroke-play championship at the Rumson Country Club.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 28 -- Fire Base Bastogne, an important strong-point defending the southwest approach to Hue, has been abandoned to North Vietnamese forces in the face of intense Communist shelling and ground attacks, a Saigon spokesman reported yesterday.

Monetary expansion, which accelerated markedly in the first half of July largely because of temporary seasonal factors, appears to have subsided to more normal levels in the latter part of the month, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

Burlington industries, Inc., is closing its research center in Greensboro, N.C., and moving all research operations to smaller laboratories in 11 divisions of the company, Ely Callaway, president, said yesterday.

"Please allow me to introduce myself; I'm a man of wealth and taste," Mick Jagger wrote in "Sympathy for the Devil," the song sung at Altamont but conspicuously absent from the latest live performances of the Rolling Stones.

CUSTER, S. D., July 27 -- The quiet euphoria that filled Senator George McGovern's Sylvan Lake vacation retreat as recently as last weekend, when staffers gathered in the common hall of the lodge among the pines for a sing-along with the Presidential nominee, has disappeared.
Mrs. William R. Phillips took the witness stand in a packed courtroom here yesterday to give her husband an hour-byhour alibi for the night that James Smith and Sharon Stango were murdered.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- A secret analysis by the Government's top narcotics enforcement agency has concluded that the amount of high-quality heroin being smuggled into the United States from Southeast Asia "is greater than previously realized."

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July 27 -- On the day that Bertolt Brecht's "The Resistible Rise of Arturo Ui" Went into rehearsal at the Williamstown Theater, Peter Hunt, the director, told the male apprentices who had been cast in minor speaking roles and walk-ons that they would have to cut their long hair and shave their beards.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation reported yesterday declines in sales and net income for the second quarter and first half.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -The nation's productivity, or output per man-hour, rose strongly in the second quarter of this year, the Labor Department reported today.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 27 (AP) -- Mrs. H. C. Piper Jr., wife of the board chairman of Piper, Jaffray Hopwood, Inc., an investment and brokerage concern, was kidnapped by two masked men from her home today and held for ransom, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Aides to Senator George McGovern first learned the complete history of Senator Thorn-I as F. Eagleton's psychiatric treatment at a breakfast meeting in the Senate Dining Room on July 19, six days after the Democratic Presidential nominee chose Mr. Eagleton to be his running mate.

The quintet that Jimmy Heath has brought into Jazz City this week (the last week before the club, on Third Street at the Avenue of the Americas, reverts to being Folk City) is an exceptionally good balance of youthful virtuosity and polished experience.
Tropical Storm Agnes and a generally rainy month adversely affected chain store sales in June, according to a survey of The New York Times completed yesterday among 28 leading chain organizations.

Edith Piaf was literally born on the street, which was fitting, for her songs were of the street. Her father, an itinerant acrobat named Louis Gassion, performed wherever he could collect a crowd. He "was good in bed," Simone Berteaut assures us in the first paragraph. Edith was born of one mother and Simone was born of another, and thus is her half-sister who has written this tough, tender biography.

Eldridge McKinney, who is being sought in connection with the Tuesday shooting of a Columbia College dean, was keenly aware of the pressures of being a black student at the school and his outlet was companionship with a tightly knit group of young men from similar backgrounds, a close friend said yesterday.
LONDON, July 27 -- Militant dockers voted today to keep all British ports closed, despite the pleas of their top leaders and the release yesterday of five jailed colleagues.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 27 -- Terrorist bombings and shootings continued in Northern Ireland today as the British Army pressed its stepped-up offensive against the I.R.A.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Senator Gaylord Nelson, Democrat of Wisconsin, announced today the formation of a committee to support a strike against the Farah Manufacturing Company. He called for a nationwide boycott of the company's products.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- President Nixon said today that the differences between him and the Democratic Presidential nominee on fundamental questions of foreign and domestic policy were so wide that American voters would have "the clearest choice in this century" when they go to the polls in November.
Forty-five librarians picketed the corporate offices of Nabisco here yesterday, protesting the crumby way they felt they had been dealt with by the cracker company in one of its advertisements.
Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy, calling crime rates in the country a "national disgrace," said yesterday that state governments should play a stronger role in law enforcement.

Four past Olympic gold medal winners, Jesse Owens, Bob Mathias, Johnny Weissmuller and Peggy Fleming were presented sets of sterling silver commemorative medals depicting great moments in Olympic history at a luncheon at The Four Sea sons Restaurant yesterday.

The president of the state American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, Raymond R. Corbett, informed union leaders throughout the state yesterday that the state group would follow the lead of the national A.F.L.-C.I.O. executive council and remain neutral in the Presidential race.

William J. Bailey, 57 years old, has been elected president of the Carrier Corporation, effective Nov. I. Mr. Bailey, who has been executive vice president, succeeds Charles V. Fenn, who has decided to retire ahead of his scheduled ,retirement date in September, 1973. Mr. Fenn will remain a director.

In learning of the medical history of Senator Thomas Eagleton one is moved to compassion and admiration for a man who has struggled to overcome periods of depression and has become a capable, energetic Senator.

Ferguson Jenkins reminded the Phildelphia Phillies of one of their worst mistakes last night. The 6-foot 5-inch righthander, whom the Phillies traded to the Chicago Cubs in 1966, allowed Philadelphia just one hit as the Cubs won the first game of a doubleheader, 4-0, at Philadelphia.

LOS ANGELES, July 27 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied today an effort by the defense to block the Pentagon papers trial until the Justice Department discloses details of a wiretap incident involving the defense.
Potatoes, platinum and silver scored impressive gains yesterday in futures trading.

PARIS, June 27 -- The 152d meeting of the Paris peace talks was held here today and Communist and Western sources said that there had been no change from the positions the United States and North Vietnam took at secret talks eight days ago.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Federal Trade Commission said today that it planned to lodge a complaint against the A. P. food chain, the nation's largest, because several of its stores had allegedly advertised products at sale prices but had failed to make them available or had sold them only at higher prices.

The drive for measurable increases in productivity by city employes announced by Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton is welcome news. However, it is disappointing that in defining goals for the Corrections Department, its single most important function -- producing defendants for scheduled appearances in court -- was omitted.

Professor Kilson's criticism of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences' decision not to award Ezra Pound the Emerson-Thoreau Prize (letter July 16) is premised on the assumption that what Pound did was not particularly heinous. Indeed, Professor Kilson concedes that his attitude would be different if what Pound did entailed a "direct commission of criminal or murderous acts against humanity."

MANHASSET, L. I., July 27 -Dick Siderowf, the Westport, Conn., stockbroker playing out of the country club of Aspetuck, triumphed twice today in the Metropolitan Golf Association's amateur championship over the par-70, 6,596-yard Deepdale Club course.
A lawyer who had been a city policeman was indicted here yesterday on a charge that he had offered a $20,000 bribe to a narcotics detective to commit perjury in a Bronx heroin case.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers will make himself and his aides available to brief Senator George McGovern and Senator Thomas Eagleton on foreign affairs, a State Department spokesman said today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- An essential building block in the construction of a system of peaceful relations in Asia may well have been constructed by the recently announced accord between South and North Korea.

AREA A -- Striped bass fishing on Long Beach near Surf City picked up the last few days, with surfcasters doing well on small-to-medium-sized fish. Rebel plugs have been effective. Bay fishing for fluke has been reasonably good near the inlets and light tackle enthusiasts are having a field day with small bluefish a short distance offshore from Barnegat Inlet.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27 (AP) -- The Penn Central Transportation Company, estimating it sustained about $30-million in damages and lost business during the June flood, said today it was furloughing 1,000 employes in an emergency economy move.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., July 27 -- John Corcoran, president of the Consolidation Coal Company, defended today the safety record of the company's: Blacksville No. 1 mine.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 27 (UPI) -- Hundreds of African tribesmen have fled their ancestral homeland in Rhodesia's Inyanga Mountains to avoid arrest in a dispute with white landowners.

By a formula of his own devising, Seymour Topping, assistant managing editor of this newspaper, has combined the personal and the historic in a narrative in which each quality enhances the other. His experiences in China and Southeast Asia explain, illustrate and sometimes dramatize the course of history.
Leading New York Democratic politicians and labor leaders called on Senator Thomas F. Eagleton yesterday to withdraw as the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- President Nixon charged today that Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations and other "well-intentioned and naive people" had been "taken in" by Hanoi's propaganda into following a "double standard" of criticizing the United States war effort while ignoring North Vietnam's invasion of South Vietnam.

ORANGE, France -- This Provencal city of about 25,000 people was the capital of the operatic world earlier this week with the Spanish soprano Montserrat Caballe heading an international cast for a once-only performance of Verdi's "Il Trovatore" that packed an audience of 7,000 into the spectacular Roman theater.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Senate endorsed today the Nixon Administration's proposal to spend nearly $1-billion to accelerate development of the Trident missile-launching submarine.
Blessing Angelica and Sailly Le Sec engaged in a tense stretch duel in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday, with the former prevailing by threequarters of a length.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 (UPI) -- Marijuana smoking reduces fluid pressure in the eyes and may prevent glaucoma, a significant cause of blindness, researchers reported yesterday.

Paul Kolton was designated yesterday to become the first full-time, paid chairman of the American Stock Exchange and the choice surprised nobody in Wall Street. Mr. Kolton is considered a capable and likable administrator who had no acknowledged rivals for the job.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 27 (AP) -- Nikki Pilic defeated Rod Laver in straight sets today to gain the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Pro Classic at Louisville.
Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

The Board of Education yesterday made public its school safety plan to "get the cops out of the schools" and replace them with specially trained but unarmed men and women who will work with students and the surrounding community in an effort to prevent school violence.

The Boise Cascade Corporation reported yesterday secondquarter income of $1.51-million, which a $200-million extraordinary charged reduced to a loss of $198.49-million, compared with $40.24-million net loss in the year-ago quarter after an extraordinary charge of $44-million.

Home runs by Bobby Murcer and John Callison, plus another save by Sparky Lyle, were chief ingredients last night as the Yankees successfully opened the second half of the season.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- President Nixon asked Congress today for $135.2-million in supplemental funds for his campaign against drug abuse, including $2.5-million for a new office of national narcotics intelligence.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 27 -- In the three-deep defensive depth chart that Coach Alex Webster prepared today for Saturday's opening preseason game, Jack Gregory is listed as the left tackle.
LONDON, July 27 (Reuters) -- The value of gold rose to a new postwar peak in late trading here today.
DENVER, July 27 -- The second round of Spingold knockout team championship play here this afternoon saw the first appearance of the top-seeded teams, which had a bye yesterday.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 27 -- The Connecticut State Wom en's Golf Association, which had lost its first two meetings with the women's Tri-County Golf Association, won its third annual team match, 29 1/2 to 15 1/2, today at Brooklawn Country Club.

Judge Wilfred Feinberg of the United States Court of Appeals issued a limited stay yesterday of a District Court decision that would have permitted the expulsion of Robert W. Stark Jr. Inc. from the New York Stock Exchange.
The first indictment of a yearlong investigation into an alleged conspiracy to inflate meat prices in the metropolitan area was announced yesterday.

Apparently, it is risky to criticize the Ladies' Professional Golfers Association. An official admitted yesterday that Sandra Palmer, who spoke harshly of the L.P.G.A. for suspending Jane Blalock, was censured for her statements.

LIGONIER, Pa., July 27 -Arnold Palmer and his youthful partner, Jack Lewis, who became a last-minute replacement for the ailing Jack Nicklaus, scored a 66 today in the opening round of the Professional Golfers' Association national team championship.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The National Peace Action Coalition announced today that it would sponsor demonstrations in 13 cities in early August to protest American bombing of North Vietnamese dikes.

Mario M. Cuomo's recommendation to Mayor Lindsay that the controversial Forest Hills low-income housing project be reduced 50 per cent in size won the support yesterday of Representative Edward I. Koch, Democrat-Liberal of Manhattan, and the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.

Tenneco, Inc., yesterday reported an increase of 13 per cent in second-quarter earnings on a gain of 15 per cent in revenues, bringing the half-year results up 16 and 17 per cent, respectively, all setting records.
The New York vhapter of the American Institute of Architects announced its support yesterday of the Madison Avenue mall plan advanced by the Office of Midtown Planning and Development.

The National Institutes of Health said yesterday that it planned to conduct a major study of acupuncture to determine whether the Chinese needle technique was safe and effective as a pain-killer in surgery and when used for the relief of chronic pain arising from certain diseases.

LONDON, July 27 -- The British Government, in a major move to cripple the effectiveness of the Irish Republican Army, is sending 4,000 more soldiers to stricken Northern Ireland.

The oil industry continued to report mixed earnings results as the Shell Oil Company yesterday announced sharply higher profits and the Atlantic Richfield Company reported lower net income.

DOWNEY, Calif., July 27 -Champagne flowed into the early morning hours at the Tahitian Village restaurant here today. Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the city would sue several midtown Manhattan hotels as part of the campaign to clean up the area.

Borough President Sebastian Leone of Brooklyn said yesterday he would ask the Public Service Commission to determine if the Consolidated Edison Company should reimburse businessmen for losses suffered through power outages in the last two weeks.

Bache Co., the nation's second-largest stock brokerage house, disclosed yesterday that it wants to hire more black stock brokers and is actively recruiting to find them.

PEKING, July 27 -- Chairman Mao Tse-tung has broken months of official silence on the fate of former Defense Minister Lin Piao by telling two foreign statesmen in recent weeks that Mr. Lin was killed in an air crash last year while fleeing the country in the wake of an attempted coup.

BETHPAGE, L. I., July 27 -- Five hundred to 600 workers may be out of their jobs as a result of Grumman Aerospace Corporation's loss of the contract for the space shuttle to North American Rockwell Corporation, company officials said here today.
Lyndon B. Johnson flew by helicopter from Fort Sam Houston, Tex., where he was hospitalized Monday night, to his ranch, near Austin.

There was a nervous undertone to the stock market yesterday as prices registered their third straight setback and as another big glamour issue -Holiday Inns -- plunged sharply.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Saturday, July 29 (UPI) -- Gunmen kidnapped and then shot to death a 51-year-old hotel executive in Belfast yesterday and others forced their way into the home of a former Cabinet minister in the Northern Ireland provincial government, fired a shot at him, and then set the house ablaze.

The alibi for Patrolman William R. Phillips for the night that James Smith and Sharon Stango were murdered was supported here yesterday by two more of his relatives -- Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. McKee, the uncle and aunt at whose home Mr. Phillips says he spent much of that night.

LIGONIER, Pa., July 28 -- "All I was doing was praying for him," said Kermit Zarley after he and his partner Bryant (Babe) Hiskey finished with a 63 today and tied for the lead at 130 in the $200,000 national team championship. Sharing the top-spot with them after 36 holes were Lanny Wadkins, the rookie, and Gibby Gilbert after a round of 64.

PARIS, July 28 -- While calm has returned to the currency markets since intervention by American authorities nine days ago to support the exchange rate of the dollar, the speculative fever has returned in gold.

BATON ROUGE, July 28 -- The body of Senator Allen J. Ellender will be flown to the state capitol here tomorrow to allow Louisianans to pay their last respects to the state's senior United States Senator.

MANHASSET, L. I., July 28 -- George Burns 3d of Wheatley Hills, recent winner of the Long Island Golf Association amateur championship, became a threat to capture the 70th Metropolitan Golf Association amateur title today at the Deepdale Club.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 28 (AP) -- A six-state search was pressed today for two men who the Federal Bureau of Investigation says abducted the wife of a Minneapolis millionaire and left a ransom note demanding about $1-million.

A New Jersey legislator said yesterday that the information that led to the extortion indictment of the state's Secretary of State last month had not been acted upon in the office of the state Attorney General for almost two years.

ROCHESTER, July 28 (UPI) -- While the Rochester police continued their search for the robber who gouged out the eyes of two persons on July 9, a fund set up to aid one of the victims passed its original goal of $2,000.

CLEVELAND, July 28 (AP) -- Chris Evert spoiled the tennis comeback of Mrs. Margaret Court today with a 6-3, 6-3 victory that gave the United States a 1-1 split with Australia in the first Bonne Belle series.

YAKIMA, Wash., July 28 -- Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court will decide over the weekend whether to delay the Pentagon papers trial until a wiretapping controversy is resolved.

ARNOLD'S COVE, Nfld., July 28 (AP) -- A 66-foot wooden motor schooner with 15 persons aboard caught fire and sank last night in Placentia Bay. Six persons were rescued and one body was recovered. Officials ordered a search for eight persons reported missing.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission served notice today that it would not abandon its attempt to keep institutional investors from becoming or remaining members of stock exchanges.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 28 -- Jack Nicklaus said today he was definitely planning on playing in the Professional Golfers' Association championship that begins at the Oakland Hills Country Club, Birmingham, Mich., next Thursday.

MOSCOW, July 28 -- The stuffy room in the Central Chess Club of Moscow was slowly filling up for the regular analysis of the latest game in the match between Boris Spas-sky of the Soviet Union, the world champion, and Bobby Fischer, the American challenger.
GENEVA, July 28 -- The Swiss Ministry of Justice disclosed today that it had frozen more than $500,000 hidden in secret Swiss bank accounts by international drug traffickers.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (Reuters) -- The Senate voted today for an amendment cutting off Defense Department funds for any use of rainmaking or creation of forest fires as a weapon of war.
NORTH CALDWELL, N. J., July 28 (AP) -- A work stoppage by prisoners at the Essex County Corrections Center here has ended after three and a half days.

J., July 28 -- On their training-camp field at Monmouth College, the New York Giants bad been split into units, with Alex Webster, the head coach, working quietly with the offense, and Jim Garrett, the intense assistant coach, working loudly with the defense. DETROIT, July 28 -- The General Motors Corporation disclosed today the largest three-month profit ever reported by any American company. But General Motors still asserted that a price increase on cars and trucks was needed this fall.

DETROIT, July 28 (AP) -- The United States auto industry built its five millionth car of the year Wednesday, the trade newspaper Automotive News reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) -- President Nixon signed legislation today permitting persons between the ages of 18 and 20 to buy Federal crop insurance. He told an audience of young farmers "Your Government has faith in young people; we believe you are a good risk."

NEW DELHI, July 28 -- President V. V. Giri today ratified the peace agreement between India and Pakistan. NEWARK, July 30 (AP) -Simone Rizzo DeCavalcante, reputed organized-crime figure in New Jersey, has become a highly rated nurse in the Federal prison system.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 30 -- A marketing clinic -- the first of its kind -- will be held this fall to provide practical guidance to the underdeveloped countries in how to tailor their products to consumer tastes around the world.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- In mice and guinea pigs, scientists have been able to make cancers diminish or even fade away by deliberately manipulating the animals' own natural immunologic defenses.

Some significant class action suits are moving through the courts that question whether interest should be charged by lenders on the basis of a 360-day year -- a practice banks have long followed -- or the more exact 365-day calendar year basis.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -The National Commission on State Workmen's Compensation Laws reported to President Nixon and Congress today that workmen's compensation programs were "inadequate and inequitable." It called for massive reforms guaranteed by the Federal Government.

The United States Supreme Court decision of June 29 outlawing capital punishment spares 612 men and women under sentence of death. It constitutes a historic turn in our country toward humaneness and rationality in the administration of criminal justice.
CLEVELAND, July 30 -- The General Motors Corporation is back in the heavy-duty equipment market, which it was forced to leave under terms of an antitrust consent decree four years ago.
BALTIMORE, July 30 -- It took a little more than 24 hours and a short trip here for the Yankees to become a .500 ball club again.

James W. Harpel, 34, is a general partner of Century Capital Associates, a private investment adviser that manages institutional, foundation and hedge-fund accounts. His firm is geared basically to managing institutional money -- the sector that dominates presentday markets.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 30 (AP) -- Four leftist guerrillas were killed and one was injured in shooting during a police raid on a house in downtown Teheran yesterday, the Iranian police reported today.

LONDON -- They trudge along Waterloo Bridge and climb down the steps, overlooking the Thames, to the theater box office. They endure all-night Peter Lorre festivals, 1923 Scandinavian epics, cartoons from Zagreb and Czechoslovak children's films "... a heartwarming but unsentimental story about a boy living on a stud farm during the Austro-Hungarian Empire days."

WASHINGTON, July 30 -Nearly half the $4.2-million currently available to labor unions for campaign contributions is controlled by union leaders friendly to Senator George McGovern, a study of the political treasuries of labor and other special-interest groups has disclosed.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits said today that the Presidential election might develop in part into a test of public attitudes toward mental illness if Senator Thomas F. Eagleton remains on the Democratic ticket.
PRAGUE, July 30 -- The current trials of prominent supporters of Alexander Dubcek, the former Communist leader, are intended by his successors to close a bitter chapter in Czechoslovak history.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (AP) -- The 180,000 books damaged by fire and water at Temple University's Charles Klein Law Library will be freeze-dried like coffee in an attempt to save them, according to the school librarian, Edward C. Surrency.
MANHASSET, L. I., July 30 -- George Burns 3d of Wheatley Hills captured the 70th Metropolitan Golf Association amateur championship at the Deepdale Club today.

James Dickey, who won the 1965 National Book Award for poetry and published his first novel, "Deliverance," in 1970, has been described as a poet "concerned primarily with the direct impact of experience."

President Nixon's return last week to the tired theme that his war critics are "naive" dupes of Hanoi indicates a desire to pose campaign debate over the nation's defense posture in terms as irrelevant and unilluminating as were the arguments over the missile gap and the future of Quemoy and Matsu in earlier election dialogues.

The good news is that Tommie Agee started a game for the first time in three weeks and hit a home run for the first time in two months. The bad news is that Jim Fregosi replaced him on sick call with a strained right knee.

LONDON, July 30 -- When Britons speak of Maurice Victor Macmillan, it is perhaps inevitable that they compare him with the Macmillan they know better, his father, Harold, who was Prime Minister from 1957 to 1963.

Robert L. Leuci, the key undercover agent in an 18-month Federal investigation of corruption in the criminal justice system here, was said by Life magazine yesterday to have admitted committing crimes during his seven years as a police narcotics detective.

NEWARK, July 30 -- On Wednesday evening, more than 3,000 operagoers, perhaps half of them from across the Hudson, will file into a cavernous hall, a former Masonic mosque, in the heart of this city's central ghetto to hear -- as they do several times each year -- opera, European style.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, July 31 (AP) -- United States planes have shot down two MIG-21 interceptors northeast of Hanoi, American pilots reported yesterday.

Ted Gross, the city Commissioner of Youth Services, was arrested yesterday and charged with possession of a forged driver's license after being stopped early in the morning in a routine check for stolen cars.

BHUBANESWAR, India -- Mrs. Nandini Satpathy, the youngest Chief Minister of an Indian state and only the second woman to hold this powerful political office, is tackling the numerous challenges of Orissa, India's problem state, with the verve and zest of the schoolgirl firebrand that she once was.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The nation's welfare rolls topped 15 million persons in March, a record, but the rate of increase has slowed to only a third that of the last two years.

The chairman of a City Council Committee investigating violence in schools asserted yesterday that Family Court judges were dismissing charges against an average of three suspects a week because the Board of Education had only one lawyer to represent teachers and students who said they were victimized.

The notion that the golden age of oratory in America ended in 1925 when William Jennings Bryan contracted quinsy was dispelled over the weekend when Gino Marchetti, Ollie Matson, Ace Parker and Lamar Hunt were invested with immortality, outfitted with harps and wings and installed in the Professional Football Hall of Fame in Canton, Ohio.

" Soul at the Center's" Sunday night program at Philharmonic Hall finally drew the kind of audience this fine series deserves. No doubt the program -- the singers Novella Nelson and Donny Hathaway and the soul group Labello -- had something to do with the fact that a large and enthusiastic houseful of listeners turned out for the show.

CLEVELAND, July 30 (AP) -Chris Evert avenged her Wimbledon loss with a 6-3, 4-6, 6-0 victory over an erratic and careless Evonne Goolagong today but the 17-year-old Floridian failed to prevent an Australian triumph in the first Bonne Belle tennis competition.

A 44-year-old man was stabbed to death last night by a man in a wheelchair on a visit to a friend's apartment in Harlem, the police reported. The unidentified suspect in the killing was being questioned about the circumstances of the slaying but had not been charged early today.
The Federal Government has cut by 50 per cent the premium rates for its crime insurance for businesses and homes and has added Tennessee to the number of states where the coverage is available.

Harmon Killebrew of the Minnesota Twins should soon become the second leading home-run hitter in American League history. The muscular first baseman yesterday walloped the 533d homer of his career (his 18th this season) to give the Twins a 1-0 triumph over the Chicago White Sox.

Ten state legislators -- all with Conservative and Republican party backing -- were given a 100 per cent rating by the New York State Conservative party, which gave the 1972 Legislature as a whole a rating of 78 per cent.

BELGRADE -- Communist ideas did not spring forth from the working class. Doctrinaires and political movements put them there instead. Marx and Lenin were aware of the difference between Communist theory and the working-class movement. The advantage of Marx and Lenin over other theoreticians and Communist leaders is that for them the revolution and the new society provide the link between their "scientific" views and the working class, that is, the labor movement.

BOSTON, July 30 -- The headquarters of the Unitarian Universalist Association, a tranquil brick mansion on Beacon Street overlooking the Boston Common, shows no outward signs of fear or paranoia. Among the staff there is some banter about the telephone being "bugged" and a suggestion that the F.B.I. may have planted listening devices behind the portraits of early Unitarian leaders, but no one talks in whispers.
ESPANOLA, N.M., July 30 -- The barbecue pit was 35 feet long and a ton and a half of beef had been cooking in it beneath a blazing fire for 24 hours.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -Anticipating a new search for a Vice-Presidential nominee, Senator George McGovern's staff members said today that they were considering a number of urban-based Roman Catholic politicians as possible replacements for Senator Thomas F. Eagleton of Missouri.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 30 -All good plays age well, but some good plays age unexpectedly well. These are often just plays that at their time of writing seemed the most contemporary and, therefore, the most evanescent.

LIGONIER, Pa., July 30 -- Kermit Zarley and Bryant (Babe) Hiskey of Houston, who had never finished better than in a tie for 30th place, succeeded Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus today as the national team golf champions.

Amid controversy over tactics and the referee, the new world bantamweight boxing champion, Enrique Pinder, left yesterday from Panama City to visit the shrine of his patron saint, Martin de Porres, in Lima, Peru.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 30 (AP) -- Virginia Piper, home safe after being kidnapped for $1-million ransom, said today she had feared for her life only after her abductors abandoned her in the darkness of the northern Minnesota wilderness.
Two Parisian restaurateurs, Michel Oliver and Alain Senderens, flew home yesterday, ready to translate a dream into reality.

LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Monday, July 31 -Thousands of British Army troops attacked Londonderry's barricaded "Free Derry" districts and other strongholds of the Irish Republican Army at 4 A.M. today (11 P.M. Sunday, New York time).

WASHINGTON, July 30 -Senator George McGovern and Senator Thomas F. Eagleton have for the last few days been like the tips of two icebergs bobbing up and down, back and forth, in the troubled waters buffeting the Democratic national ticket.
SHENANDOAH, Pa., July 30 -- Casimir Shuck, a 66-year-old retired miner, waited on a hilltop corner to shake hands with Arnold Miller, a candidate for president of the United Mine Workers of America.
This is another of those deceptive occasions when, on the surface of things, a return to the past may seem like progress or sorts.
CALLICOON, N. Y., July 30 -- In a sight that would bring joy to a liniment salesman, some 400 canoeists crossed the finish line here today in a daylong series of races.

MOSCOW, July 30 (AP) -- The commander of the Soviet Union's Navy said today that his fleets, led by a growing number of nuclear submarines, could detect and destroy an enemy vessel anywhere in the world.

George Kennan recently spoke of "disturbing symptoms of an underlying instability in Western Germany and the state of semi-anarchy in Italy that is only slightly less alarming because it is chronic." Reports from Italy mention open threats of a coup.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -Senator George McGovern intensified the pressure today on Senator Thomas F. Eagleton to withdraw as his Vice-Presidential running mate, but Mr. Eagleton refused to yield.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Government has revised downward significantly the official figure for corporate profits in the first quarter of this year as well as for the year 1971.

At 8:06 P.M. Saturday, three teen-age girls bounded up the escalator of Philharmonic Hall emitting squeals of dismay as they saw the doors to the hall being closed by the ushers. Their tickets were for the second terrace -- two more flights up -- so they settled on a bench near the veranda to hear the opening number piped in over the loudspeakers.

When President Nixon flew to Peking and Moscow there was euphoric elation by some writers and there were dire predictions by others. This was particularly true regarding the Peking trip. How do the trips look in retrospect?

CHINCOTEAGUE, Va., July 30 -- Humane Society officials, who had threatened to use their powers of arrest unless organizers of the popular Chincoteague wild pony roundup and auction took immediate steps to improve the animals' care, took no action last week as more than 50 of the wild colts went to the auction block.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -The biggest political casualty in the Eagleton affair may prove to be not Senator Thomas F. Eagleton but the man who chose him to seek the Vice Presidency. In the five days since Senator Eagleton disclosed a history of treatment for nervous exhaustion and depression, Senator George McGovern appears to have undone much of his effort over the last 18 months to establish an image as an unusually candid Presidential candidate.

Investment strategists face particularly difficult decisions this week as they appraise the Treasury's sweeping offer to exchange its securities for three new notes and bonds. Subscription books will be open from this morning until Wednesday at 5 P.M.

A group of residents of Tudor City, angered by the owner's plans to build a new residential building on private parkland in the area, has urged the City Planning Commission to set up a new zoning category that would forbid any construction on the site.
PEKING, July 30 (AP) -- An agreement was reached today on the exchange of news and photos between the Associated Press and Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency.

Hubert Humphrey retired from his last Presidential race showing the professionalism which has always marked his political career. He mentioned the "good battle" he had fought and lost, although he might well have alluded to the personal attacks against him and the political maneuverings of his opponents which contributed to his loss.

TORONTO, July 30 (AP) -"The opposition didn't concern me. When you're concentrating all you're worrying about is running to the best of your ability," said Jim Ryun after he ran a sparkling 3:52.8 mile in the Metro Toronto Police games last night.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -The Apollo 14 astronauts, without the knowledge of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, carried 200 silver medals coined by a private mint on their moon flight in January, 1971.

'Fire Pool' Rate Cut Is Ordered The New York Property Insurance Underwriting Association -- the association of insurance companies also known as "the Fire Pool" -- has been ordered by the New York State Insurance Department to lower its average premium rates 11.9 per cent. The reductions will go into effect on new policies issued after Sept. 15 and on renewals after Oct. 15.

No greater challenge to the American process of democratic government will confront us in the coming few years than finding a sane and sensible way of reconciling the often conflicting requirements of adequate energy supplies and of environmental protection.

TOKYO, July 30 -- A television commenator here rather neatly summed up the feelings of politically aware Japanese about President Nixon's sudden invitation to Premier Kakuei Tanaka to meet in Hawaii at the end of August to discuss China policy.

Following are excerpts from the transcript of a television interview with the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, yesterday on the program "Face the Nation" broadcast by the Columbia Broadcasting System, as recorded by The New York Times.
MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga. (AP) -- Eight persons were killed tonight in a head-on collision between a truck and a car that carried seven men on Georgia Route 22 near this central Georgia city.
MONTAUK, L. I. -- Normally, this sedate resort and fishing community on the tip of Long Island would not be singled out for its swinging social scene. The Hamptons, it isn't.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 30 -- Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, saying he had a cold, today requested and received a postponement of the scheduled ninth game in his 24-game world championship chess match against Bobby Fischer of the United States.
DENVER, July 30 -- Three bridge teams piled up big leads tonight in the quarterfinals of the Spingold knockout team championship in the Summer Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League.

SITKA, Alaska, July 30 (UPI) -- A strong earthquake in the Gulf of Alaska sent shock waves south to Seattle today and caused a brief evacuation of about 6,000 residents from their homes in Sitka in a tidal wave alert.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 30 (AP) -- Tom Woods, Oregon State University's National Collegiate Athletic Association high jump champion, leaped 7 feet, 2 1/4 inches last night, but the Soviet Union's young distance stars scored a 124-108 victory over the United States in a twoday junior track and field meet.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 30 -- The Government is prepared to consider concessions to the people of Soweto, the black African townshipsatellite of Johannesburg, that could give the people more powers of self-administration.

MEXICO CITY, July 30 -- The money found in the possession of five suspects in last month's break-in at the offices of the Democratic National Committee in Washington has been traced to four bank drafts totaling $89,000 issued here in the name of a prominent Mexican lawyer.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- In their moments of personal political crisis, Senator Thomas F. Eagleton and then-Senator Richard M. Nixon went on national television to defend themselves against being dropped as VicePresidential candidates.

A new program for immediate removal from the city's welfare rolls of all addicts who discontinue therapy in an approved drug-treatment program was announced yesterday by the city's Human Resources Administrator, Jule M. Sugarman.

The New Jersey Supreme Court has handed down a ruling that has a certain logic and justice in it and yet seems on balance to be neither completely logical nor altogether just. SAN DIEGO, July 30 (Reuters) -- Two light planes collided over La Jolla today killing two brothers and the pilot they had hired to help them scatter their grandfather's ashes at sea.

The high level of residential building has pushed the total value of construction contracts to a record figure of $8,477,640,000 in June, the F. W. Dodge division of McGraw Hill Information Systems Company reported over the weekend.

The evangelist Shirley Caesar belted gospel hymns and danced in the front-row aisle of Alice Tully Hall yesterday in an exuberant service that marked the midway point of "Soul at the Center," the twoweek black arts festival at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

CAIRO, July 30 -- President Anwar el-Sadat will fly to Libya tomorrow to face yet another crisis -- the request of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, for an Immediate merger of their two countries.
The city has a new plan to confound graffiti artists -- coating public buildings with a special spray or paint-on surface that is easily wiped clean.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Price Commission plans to exempt from profit-margin restrictions companies that agree to roll back any price increase since last year's freeze and refund the difference to customers.
LONG POND, Pa., July 30 -Roger McCluskey, leading all but 50 miles of the way, easily won the Pennsylvania 500 stock-car race today with a 10mile margin over the runner-up, Butch Hartman.
