New Yorkers of European birth or parentage declined in number precipitously in the nineteen-sixties, while those of foreign descent from the Caribbean and South America more than doubled.

Don Johnston has been named an executive vice president of J. Walter Thompson and put in charge of its international operation -34 offices with billings of $355-million. He replaces Tom Sutton who had the job for seven years and who at his own request has been named chief executive officer of JWT-Japan.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -Senator Frank E. Moss said today that the Federal Trade Commission had revealed a "widespread and flagrant" absence of adequate documentation for many claims by advertisers.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 30 -- Biologists of the Alaska Fish and Game Department here are puzzled by the death of 53 caribou found clustered in a valley about four miles south of Fort Greely, the former site of a chemical, biological, and radiological laboratory and test center of the United States Army.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board disclosed over the weekend that it had invited applications from mutual, that is, depositor-owned, savings and loan associations to convert to state-chartered capital stock associations.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 30 (AP) -- Saratoga's 103d meeting opens tomorrow and Riva Ridge, Numbered Account, Key To The Mint and Executioner are among the big-name horses scheduled to race during the 24-day meet, which ends Aug. 26.
LANCASTER, Pa., July 30 (AP) -- Two policemen were hit by rocks anti 15 persons were arrested today in a disturbance at a rock concert here, the police said.

STOCKHOLM -- A young Swedish-speaking Finnish girl selects a wrench from the bench by her side. She turns to the automobile engine on a stand nearby and tightens a nut. "There," she says, "that should do it."

VIENNA, Va., July 30 -- Tradition, which is at the root of most of the songs performed at the National Folk Festival, was briefly shunted aside yesterday during the festival's third day at Wolf Trap Farm Park to allow the voices of women's liberation to be heard.

PEKING, July 30 (Agence France-Presse) -- Chen Po-ta, the former personal secretary of Chairman Mao Tse-tung and former head of the Cultural Revolution Directing Group, was implicated with the late Lin Piao in a plot to seize power from Chairman Mao, according to information from ranking Chinese officials here.

LOUISVILLE, Ky. July 30 (AP) -- Arthur Ashe defeated top - seeded John Newcombe, 6-4, 6-4, and Mark Cox downed Cliff Drysdale, 7-5, 6-0, today to advance to the final of the $50,000 First National tennis tourney.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) -- Senate Republican leader Hugh Scott said today that Republican chances of taking control of the Senate have been hurt by the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s decision to stay neutral in the Presidential election and concentrate on electing Democrats to Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, yielding to a request from Senator George McGovern, withdrew tonight from his campaign for the Vice-Presidency. He said that he did not wish to "divide the Democratic party" by continuing as its nominee.

BONN, July 31 -- Gerhard Schroder, a leading Opposition politician and chairman of the Foreign Policy Committee of the lower house of Parliament, said here today that the "time was right" for establishment of official ties between Bonn and Peking.
Prices continued to move lower in slow trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market.

Paul-Henri Spaak, the Belgian statesman who was one of the chief architects of European unification and Western solidarity in the postwar era, died of kidney failure yesterday in Brussels. He was 73 years old.

ST. LOUIS, July 31 -- Proud and tense, Senator Thomas F. Eagleton stepped into the hot spotlights of the Miami Beach Convention Center 18 days ago, took a deep breath and dedicated his acceptance speech: "This is for M.D.E."
The Securities Industry Association, a group of 850 investment houses, voiced renewed opposition yesterday to the concept of institutional membership on the nation's stock exchanges.

Steel production for the week ended July 29 reversed the preceding week's decline and posted a gain of 1.6 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry poured a total of 2,356,000 net tons, compared with 2,318,000 tons in the week ended July 22.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The announcement that production will soon begin on a movie called "The Godfather -- Part Two" must surely rank as the most depressing cultural event of 1972.

Raymond R. Corbett, president of the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O., called yesterday for emergency measures to aid 90,000 state residents whose extended unemployment-insurance benefits had just been cut off.

Daniel (Chappie) James Jr., the highest-ranking black officer in the Air Force, was promoted to major general. In a Pentagon ceremony, Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird pinned two silver stars on each of the general's epaulets as his wife and son, Air Force Capt. Daniel James 3d, looked on.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -The Marine Corps commandant, Gen. Robert E. Cushman Jr., today ordered an end to the "voluntary segregation" by race of Marines in living quarters on land and at sea.

Democratic leaders across the country said last night that Senator Thomas F. Eagleton's withdrawal from the Vice-Presidential race, while personally sad, would strengthen the party's chances in the November election.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 31 -Don Maynard arrived in camp last night a full two weeks late, and today the Jets' long-time wide receiver was asked when he would be ready to play. Maynard checked his watch.
LONDON, July 31 (Reuters) -- The free-market price of gold soared today to near $69 an ounce in London, Zurich and Frankfurt, and to just under $70 in Paris.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -Representative Samuel S. Stratton, Democrat of upstate New York, is seeking to block the promotion of a career United States diplomat accused of having helped suppress news of the Mylai killings.

BBDO International, the parent company of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, has acquired Frank J. Corbett, Inc., Chicago, an agency specializing in the health care field. Industry sources believe it to be the largest acquisition in this field. It was done through an exchange of stock.

The Knickerbockers may lead the National Basketball Association next season in at least one department -Rhodes Scholars. Heyward Dotson, a star at Columbia University who spent the last two years at Oxford, yesterday signed to play with the Knicks.

Charges of conspiring to transfer interstate forged and fraudulent motor vehicle registration certificates against Bernard Rosenthal, a Brooklyn merchant, were dismissed in Federal Court yesterday for lack of evidence.

DETROIT, July 31 (UPI) -United States District Judge Stephen J. Roth's desegregation panel recommended today cross-district and cross-county busing of nearly 350,000 children in the nation's most sweeping plan for integrating urban schools.

Yesterday, the Metropolitan Museum's closed day, about 150 people clogged the Hall of Cypriot Antiquities and the Roman Sculpture Room nearby. OTTAWA, July 31 -- The Canadian Government today rejected recent recommendations that it legalize the simple possession of marijuana and hashish. However, under a new policy to be proposed to Parliament, first offenders would be treated far more leniently than in the past.

Five dapper robbers smashed open five safe-deposit boxes at the Plaza Hotel early yesterday, the police said, and escaped with more than $45,000 worth of jewelry belonging to jewelers who had come here for a convention.

Federal Court in Minneapolis announced yesterday that it will reserve judgment until noon today upon Telex Corporation's request for a restraining order to prevent the International Business Machines Corporation from making an introductory announcement Wednesday about two new computers.

PARIS, July 31 -- Inflation, which seems to be the inevitable accompaniment of life in a modern industrial society, is changing the habits and attitudes of Europeans.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -Senator George McGovern proposed today that Congress reject President Nixon's proposal to increase Pentagon spending. He suggested holding the defense budget to last year's level.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- Congressional Democrats began a drive today to raise more than $1-million for the party's Senate and House candidates.

WASHINGTON -- We read a great deal today about unnamed magazines and newspapers facing what is asserted to be a catastrophic situation allegedly caused by recently authorized postal rate increases. Much of the outcry smacks of a carefully contrived campaign by corporate publishers to inject their own business interests into their editorial columns -- identical rhetoric keeps cropping up in "independent" publications across the country.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- The Government today proposed sweeping administrative reforms in Britain's system of socialized medicine to meet growing criticism of bureaucracy and shortcomings in the service.

BAMAKO, Mali, Aug 1 (Agence France-Press) -- Mali's state security court has sentenced the former Premier, Yoro Diakite, to life imprisonment at hard labor for attempting a coup in March, 1971, the Mali radio reported today. He had been an army captain.
BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 1 -- Gov. Edwin Edwards today appointed his wife, Elaine, to fill the unexpired term of Senator Allen J. Ellender, who died July 27 at the age of 81.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Air pollution at the proposed sports complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands would constitute a serious health hazard to its patrons, a former New York City Air Resources Commissioner testifield yesterday.

BOSTON, Aug. 1 -- In one of their best all-around performances of the season, during which they showed unexpected power at the plate and excelled in the field, the New York Yankees defeated the Red Sox, 10-4, tonight in the opener of a four-game stand.
Your July 22 news story on the second quarter economic news was headed: "Gain in economy fastest since '65; G.N.P. rate is 8.9 per cent; Nixon economic chief hails the news as 'best in decade.'"

The Emerson Electric Company announced yesterday an 11.5 per cent increase in June quarter earnings on a sales gain of 14.9 per cent. Its profits for the nine-month period are up 9.6 per cent and sales up 10.3 per cent, all setting records.

WATERFORD, Conn. -- "The O'Neill experience," four weeks of frenetic summer madness that pits young playwrights against the rigorous criticism of actors, critics, other playwrights and, perhaps most cruelly, a live audience, has descended on Waterford again.

OSLO, Norway, Aug. 1 -- The honeymoon is still on for Dave Wottle, but his hopes for an Olympic gold medal may be over.

The Canadian Government is not expected to legalize the use and possession of marijuana, despite a special governmental study recommending this step. It is, however, expected to reduce drastically the penalties associated with marijuana. This movement to liberalize drug laws in Canada comes when a countermovement seems to be gaining headway in the United States.

WOODBRIDGE, N. J., Aug. 1 (UPI) -- The Amerada Hess Corporation, which operates a big refinery in this New Jersey port, was fined $3,050 yesterday after pleading guilty to seven charges of violating the local Air Pollution Code. The town dropped six other charges against the company.

Bill D. Moyers will return to public television this fall with a new Tuesday night half-hour series tentatively titled "One Nation," it was announced yesterday. The program will be seen locally on WNET/Channel 13.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The House Rules Committee bypassed the Judiciary Committee today and sent to the floor for a vote a proposed constitutional amendment prohibiting busing to desegregate the schools. The vote was 9 to 6.

Platinum futures showed some strength yesterday in moderate trading of 515 contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. W. H. Krome George, president of the Aluminum Company of America has been appointed to the new position of chief operating officer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Federal health officials disclosed today that three experimental cancer drugs developed in the Soviet Union would be given trials of effectiveness on American patients starting early next year.

DENVER, Aug. 1 -- B. Jay Becker's four-man New York team, playing faultless bridge, took a commanding lead at the halfway mark in the finals of the Spingold Cup knockout team championship tonight in the Summer Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP] -- Following is the 59-to-33 roll-call vote by which the Senate rejected today a military-weapons-bill amendment by Senator George Mc-Govern to cut future Pentagon spending:

ESSEX, N. C. -- One recent morning in a field near this hamlet, the heat was ascending in withering waves and from time to time the little girl with the coal-black hair would straighten herself from the long green rows of cucumber plants and wipe her moist forehead with the back of her hand.
The alleged swindle that victimized nine persons in the office of Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell probably ran into millions of dollars.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Rod Jenkins returned to the show ring today after serving a three-month suspension and complained that he felt "a little rusty."

MOSCOW, Aug. 2 -- President Nicolae Ceausescu's brief but prominently publicized meeting with the Soviet party leader, Leonid I Brezhnev, was interpreted by Western diplomats today as a sign of a major improvement in Soviet-Rumanian relations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The nation's transportation problem can be simply stated. 80 per cent of the people live on 2 per cent of the land. How can these masses be moved about most efficiently in such congested space?

Things keep getting murkier in the case of the five men arrested June 17 on charges of breaking into Democratic National Committee headquarters in Washington with electronic bugging devices, photographic copying equipment and a substantial amount of money. In one of their more painful slips of a painful season, the New York Mets were beaten by the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-3, last night when the Phillies scored three runs in the ninth inning off Tom Seaver.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 2 -- Like most grandmasters watching the Boris Spassky-Bobby Fischer world championship chess match, Bent Larsen believes that the champion is not playing up to his real standard. Unlike most grandmasters, the Danish player believes it is still too early to count Spas-sky out.
We all went on a summer vacation. At the start of the second day everyone else had begun a program of self-improvement.

DES MOINES, Aug. 2 -- Iowa Democrats voted in near-record numbers in their primary election yesterday, but their candidates for Governor and Senator are still considered underdogs in the November general election.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 2 -- Three hours after they had qualified for the Olympic free-style wrestling team, in the final trials last night. John and Ben Peterson of Cumberland, Wis., were explaining their special mission at the Munich Games.

LYDDA, Israel, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Defense attorneys for two Arab women accused of participation in a hijacking on May 8 today accepted the prosecution's contention that they had been aboard the Sabena airliner, had been linked to a guerrilla group, and had carried explosives that could have blown the plane up.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., -- Smog almost accomplished here recently what snow, rain, heat and gloom of night have never done -- stopped the mailmen from the swift completion of their appointed rounds.

The Coca-Cola Company had the highest earnings for any quarter or any half year in its history in the three and six months ended June 30, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday from the company's Atlanta headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (Reuters) -- Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz said today the United States had no present plans to seek changes in the two-tier system of gold prices, despite rising prices on world markets.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market advanced yesterday for the second consecutive session in stepped-up trading.

Negotiators for private hospitals here and their employes worked into the early morning hours today in an effort to resolve a contract dispute and avert a strike that could affect 35 institutions and more than 5,000 patients.

America's women tennis professionals voted yesterday to discontinue sending 10 per cent of their prize money to the International Lawn Tennis Federation until the I.L.T.F. gives greater weight to United States matches.

With its luck still holding, the New York Philharmonic had another evening of clear weather for the opening in Central Park on Tuesday of its second week of concerts in the city's parks. The audience, not quite as large as the one for the previous Tuesday in the same place, was estimated at 50,000.
PARIS Aug. 2 -- A series of unofficial contacts is talking place here among Communist and non-Communist Vietnamese, alongside the sterile official negotiations.

The performance of the Ukrainian Dance Company at the Metropolitan Opera House was interrupted last night when two young men rushed to the front of the auditorium and threw onto the stage plastic bags apparently containing a mixture of blood and vinegar.

Schwebel, professor of international law at the School of Advanced International Studies of Johns Hopkins University, were married yesterday in Adamsberg, Sweden. LONDON, Aug. 2 (Reuters) -- The dollar had its best day in more than a month today on European foreign-exchange markets, while the free-market price of gold in London, Paris and Zurich remained at the level of $70 an ounce. But there was much less buying of gold than during the last few days.

BOSTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) -- Eight persons, including five children, their mother and grandmother, died before dawn today when a fire swept their converted two-family home in a ghetto section of Boston.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished slightly lower yesterday in slower trading, with the mobile-home issues the biggest losers.

Steel production for the week ended Aug. 5 rose 3.7 per cent to 2,4444,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This compared with 2,356,000 tons poured in the preceding week. The steel production index rose to 100.2 from 96.6 a week earlier.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The Senate overwhelmingly rejected today strong curbs on the sale and possession of all types of firearms, including handguns, rifles and shotguns.

Whitman Knapp and Governor Rockefeller's counsel are scheduled to meet in Albany this morning to discuss the Knapp Commission's proposal for the appointment of a special state prosecutor to deal with corruption in the criminal justice system in the city.

Bruno Maderna, the Italian conductor, heads the list of musical artists who will make first appearances with the New York City Opera during the company's fall season at the New York State Theater, which will open on Aug 30.

New York State's economy was reported yesterday to have "remained stable in the first half of 1972." State Commerce Department experts added that the state generally lagged a bit behind the national recovery just as recessions reached here later.

Donald A. Graham, vice president and general manager of the Remington Rand Office Systems Division of the Sperry Rand Corporation has been appointed president of the Remington Rand Division. Francis V. Bergren, vice president, has been named executive vice president of Remington Rand.

TRENTON, Aug. 7 -- A confidential, federally financed study was reported here today to favor a Meadowlands site in Hudson County for a proposed $100-million short-take-off-and-landing (STOL) airport to serve the New York metropolitan region.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug, 7 (AP) -- Toni Linhart, an Austrian soccer player booted a 9-yard field goal with 9 seconds remaining to give the New Orleans Saints a 13-10 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles tonight in a National Football League exhibition game.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Aug. 7 -- Bowing to widespread public opposition, the Bergen County Planning Board tonight rejected a controversial amendment to the county master plan that would have required the widening of county roads fronting new developments to 70 feet.

DETROIT, Aug. 7 -- The last pending criminal case against three white Detroit policemen, charged in the slayings of three black youths at the Algiers Motel in the 1967 riots here, was apparently ended today.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 (AP) A special three-judge Federal court turned down today a suit by peace activists who challenged the constitutionality of the Vietnam war and sought to cut off funding for it.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 7 -- Dean Matthews of the home club took a 3-point lead in the Area B semifinals of the North American sailing championship for the Clifford D. Mallory Trophy today after the first three races in the five-race round-robin series were completed off Riverside, Y.C.

A work week of three days of 13 hours each is being introduced for branch managers and security personnel of the New York City Off-Track Betting Corporation, aiming to eliminate the need for 255 jobs in the next year.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 7 (Reuters) -- A conferation of southern African black states, composed of African "homelands" in South Africa combined with neighboring independent countries, has been proposed by Chief Kaiser Matanzima of the Transkei homeland.
PARIS, Aug. 7 -- While European diplomats and finance ministers haggle over each new step of the Common Market, European businessmen keep pushing ahead of the politicians.

The Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, which recently completed a massive study of the working woman, has, not surprisingly, included media exposure in its investigation. And, equally unsurprisingly, it concluded that "the big difference between the lady wage earner and the woman who stays at home can be summed up in five words: less television and more print."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Aug 8 (AP) -- American jets wiped out 14 tanks supporting a new Communist drive in Cambodia while, in the northern sector of South Vietnam, Government militiamen repelled waves of enemy infantry that attacked their outposts, the allied commands reported yesterday.
TOKYO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Premier Kakuei Tanaka said today that he would visit China in September for talks on establishing normal relations between Tokyo and Peking.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The Democratic party prepared for the nomination of Sargent Shriver for Vice President tomorrow night by recommending settlement of disputes among party leaders from four states today as to who should be qualified to vote for him.
EAST BERLIN -- A young dropout who runs away from home and is killed in a freakish accident figures as the unlikely hero in a new experimental East German theatrical production.

The General Electric Company has been awarded a total of $209.9-million in Navy contracts, the company announced yesterday. Included in the total is $203.5-million for research, development and production of nuclear ship reactor components.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 7 (UPI) -- Bold Place led all the way today at Monmouth Park and romped home by six lengths to win the $9,000 allowance feature for 3-year-old fillies.

The New York Stock Exchange indicated yesterday that it had incurred a dramatic turnaround in its financial operations in the first half of this year, mainly reflecting the sharply improved fortunes of the securities industry.
A temporary restraining order barring a group of young Puerto Ricans from taking over the offices and disrupting publication of New York Magazine was filed yesterday in State Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Army said today that it would nearly double the size of the Women's Army Corps by 1978, give Wacs almost any type of assignment except combat and maybe put them in pantsuits.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) -- Representative Les Aspin said today that the Navy, fearful of cuts in its fund requests for the fiscal year 1973 if it did not spend $400-million left in its old budget, rushed through millions of dollars of claims payments to defense contractors in June.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The White House threw its public support today behind a compromise proposal by Senator Henry M. Jackson to attach Congressional understandings to the interim agreement with the Soviet Union freezing the number of offensive missiles.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 7 (AP) -- The nation's first commercial type of fast breeder nuclear reactor power plant will be built near Oak Ridge, Tenn.

CAIRO, Aug. 7 (Reuters) -The Soviet Union was reported today to be seeking a highlevel meeting with Egypt to improve their strained relations, but a top Egyptian official said that the request was still under study.
CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (UPI) -- Mayor Richard J. Daley said today that the selection of Sargent Shriver as Vice-Presidential candidate was "a great appointment" that would help the ticket in Illinois.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 7 -Since tomorrow is the day when the 26 clubs in the National Football League must cut their squads to 60 men, there are lots of football players walking around with worried looks.

On the eve of beginning their deliberations in the trial of Patrolman William R. Phillips, the jurors were offered yesterday yet another explanation of the 1968 murders of James Smith and Sharon Stango.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The State Department said today that North Vietnamese forces had deliberately poured shells into columns of South Vietnamese civilian refugees last April 29 and 30, resulting in the deaths of 1,000 to 2,000 civilians.
Interest rates moved narrowly in both directions yesterday as underwriters prepared to market this morning the first of the week's moderate calendar of new issues.
CHERRY HILL, N. J., Aug. 7 -- A key witness in a $1-million international narcotics smuggling case was killed here today when a bomb exploded in his car.

A battle of millionaire clans, harness racing variety, was staged on Saturday night at Brandywine Raceway in Wilmington, Del. In what was billed as the World Family Harness Racing Championship, it was the Canadian Filions against the American Dancers.

The recent announcement at the highest level of the National Institutes of Health of a "commitment" to study acupuncture in surgical anesthesia and in the treatment of pain resulting from chronic disease raises important questions.
A major effort to increase gasoline prices across the country and eliminate price wars in certain sections appears under way.

The Irish Northern Aid Committee was ordered yesterday by a Federal judge to produce its books and records for inspection by the Justice Department.

A Board of Elections official testified yesterday that because of lack of time the board had allowed a Brooklyn printer to determine the order of candidates on the Democratic primary ballot in Brooklyn's 14h Congressional District.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) The Air Transport Association offered rewards totaling $50,000 today for information leading to the arrest and conviction of persons who placed bombs aboard two airliners last March.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (Reuters) -- Congress approved legislation today authorizing United States funds for the operation of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty for another year.

A Federal indictment charged here yesterday that stock manipulators had paid almost $600,000 in bribes to two mutual-fund managers to buy almost $6-million in securities for which the prices had been artificially inflated.

ALBANY, Aug. 7 (AP) -Hollowed-out logs, which brought water to early settlers in this city when it was a Dutch colony, have been discovered beneath a busy downtown street here. Archaeologists say the logs may have been used for the first hydraulic engineering project in the United States.
NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 7 -- Six hundred contestants on the New York Yacht Club's annual cruise tasted the raw green beauty of offshore sailing today in a spray-tossing sprint to this far-out island.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Michael Heseltine, Britain's Aerospace Minister, announced today that British European Airways would buy six Lockheed Tristar jetliners and take an option on six more if Lockheed went ahead with plans to develop an extended-range Tristar.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The Justice Department, in the first action of its kind, filed suits today charging public agencies in the cities of Montgomery, Ala., and Los Angeles with discriminating against racial minorities in filling public jobs.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 7 -- Grandmasters yesterday watched with unbelieving eyes the 11th game of the world championship chess match between Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) -- The House of Representatives passed legislation today to increase pensions of six widows of Supreme Court Justices to $10,000 from $5,000 a year. Under a new contributory system, widows of Justices in the future could qualify for pensions up to $22,500.

GLASGOW, Scotland, Aug. 7 (Reuters) -- A Texas concern's take-over of a bankrupt Glasgow shipyard was cleared tonight when union opposition to a new labor agreement ended just an hour before the entire deal might have been called off.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Britain acknowledged today a "special responsibility for an estimated total of 55,000 Asians threatened with expulsion from Uganda, but made it plain that she would resist the demand from President Idi Amin that she accept them all here within three months.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday what it called "major changes" in its nuclear energy systems organization. SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Aug. 8 (Reuters) -- Two opposition Saigon dailies have folded because of a new government crackdown on the press requiring heavy financial deposits from all newspapers, it was reported today.

BARCELONA, Spain, Aug. 7 -- Stan Smith, the emotion drained out of him at the end, overcame Juan Gisbert, 7,000 Spanish partisans and some questionable line calls today and sent the United States into the Davis Cup final.
Joe Morgan, a crowd-pleaser in his seven seasons with the Houston Astros, said his trade to the Cincinnati Reds this season, "was maybe the best thing that has happened to me."

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- Judge Philip J. Romiti denied a defense motion today for acquittal of Edward V. Hanrahan, Cook County State's Attorney, and 13 other persons on trial on charges of conspiring to obstruct justice in the wake of a police raid on the Black Panthers here Dec. 4, 1969.

GENEVA, Aug. 7 (Reuters) -- A meeting which could determine the future of the world's coffee trade began here today with the world's major coffee producers attempting to formulate strategy for their annual meeting with consumers in London a week later.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The Council on Environmental Quality, in an expurgated edition of its third annual report on the state of the environment, said today that the nation's air was getting cleaner but that its water was growing dirtier.
METROPOLIS, Ill., Aug. 7 -- The glove plant here closed. Other firms laid off workers. Young people left town. Construction dropped. Retail sales declined. Metropolis seemed doomed!

DARIEN, Conn. -- Women or men who don't have the time, talent, interest or inclination to prepare gourmet meals for family or guests are calling upon the services of four Connecticut women who ghost cook for others.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- A Government doctor said today that he had been instructed not to treat men involved in a Federal syphilis experiment in Alabama and when he had insisted on treating them, the men never appeared again.
HARTFORD, Aug. 7 (UPI) -- The union representing a majority of Connecticut state policemen strongly opposed today new proposals to reduce education and age requirements for recruits.

BETHPAGE, L. I., Aug. 7 -The president of the Grumman Aerospace Corporation said today that Grumman had lost the $2.6-billion space shuttle contract largely because its design had been "somewhat more conservative" than that of the winner, the North American Rockwell Corporation.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 -- Fresh from the Hall of Fame, which saluted his achievements of the past. Yogi Berra returned to the realities of the present tonight and watched his New York Mets lose to the St. Louis Cardinals, 3-2, in 13 innings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- President Nixon's campaign treasury took in more than $2.6-million in individual contributions during June and July, about half of it from small donors of $100 or less, a new Republican financial statement disclosed today.

The state cracked down on New York City yesterday by deducting $470,663 in Federal and state welfare payments as a penalty for the city's alleged failure to refer 7,700 employable welfare recipients to the state work-relief program in June.

Viewed in these realistic terms, the third annual report of the Council on Environmental Quality is an unsatisfactory document but its weaknesses are understandable.

What is it about gun controls that brings out the weakness for sophistry in otherwise honest and sincere men? The crossfire resounding through the Senate chamber this week is an insult to the intelligence and conscience of the United States Senate and the constituents its members claim to be serving.

This week's Mostly Mozart Festival concerts at Philharmonic Hall began agreeably on Monday with the New York Chamber Orchestra playing under the direction of David Zinman. The program consisted of Bach's Suite No. 1 in C and the "Brandenburg" Concerto No. 2 and Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 17 and Symphony No. 35.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- A former employe of the United States Public Health Service says that six years ago he questioned the morality of a Federal syphilis study in Alabama. The result, he says, was an internal inquiry and an official decision to take no action.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 8 --Doris Kostrinsky of Willow Ridge posted a 40, 37 -- 77 on the 6,048-yard, par-37, 37 -- 74 course at Round Hill Club today to take a three-stroke lead in the 43d annual Elizabeth Wheeler Memorial Trophy tournament for the women's open championship of Fairfield and Westchester counties.
DETROIT, Aug. 8 -- Michigan voters gave early leads tonight to two incumbent Republican members of Congress who faced challenges from moderates in redrawn districts.

WASHINGTON, Aug 8 -- Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., the Chief of Naval Operations, who has already done away with Navy bans on beards and beer, announced today the lifting of the most time-barnacled prohibition of them all. Women will be allowed to serve aboard warships.
EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Aug. 8 -- Underworld figures are among those speculating in Hackensack Meadowlands real estate, according to law enforcement officials.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -The banking director of the United States Postal Service has been placed on leave without pay pending an inquiry into his action in helping a Washington attorney obtain a $500,000 loan from a New York bank that does more than a billion dollars' worth of business annually with the Postal Service.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Barring an appeal, the big share of the purse from the 1968 Kentucky Derby will go to Forward Pass, who finished second.

The State Human Rights Appeal Board yesterday reversed a 1971 finding by the State Division of Human Rights that The New York Post used discriminatory hiring practices. The board voted 2 to 1 for reversal.

MONTAUK, L. I., Aug. 8 -Benson Huggard, a Nassau County patrolman, pulled the black-rimmed goggles over his eyes, turned and waved to the 35 or so onlookers today, and said: "I'm doing it because it's never been done before."

The American Electric Power Company and Ohio's municipal electric systems announced yesterday that they had resolved their differences with respect to A.E.P.'s proposed acquisition of the Columbus Southern Ohio Electric Company and that they were now jointly urging the Securities and Exchange Commission to approve the transaction.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -The Nixon Administration charged today that the Democratic party platform, even without Senator George McGovern's plan for basic income maintenance, would increase by $144-billion a Federal budget that is already running a sizable deficit.

In a decision of major importance to bank-merger regulation, a Federal court has ruled that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation exceeded its powers in denying a proposed bank merger on the grounds that the combination would violate the F.D.I.C.'s concept of a desirable banking structure.

James Galanos, as usual, rang down the curtain on the fall and winter fashion showings yesterday. Being last to appear is not such a bad idea, particularly this season, when the acts that preceded him -- the European couture showings -- tended to be unexciting.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The split between Republican conservatives and liberals over the issue of convention reform appeared to widen today.
GENEVA, Aug. 8 -- Britain, in an attempt today to advance the stalled disarmament talks here, suggested a two-stage approach to the elimination of chemical weapons.

A new rule tentatively proposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission to govern the safekeeping of customers' securities by brokerage firms has been challenged as possibly inadequate and unworkable by Senator Edward W. Brooke.

The Uniformed Fire Officers Association announced yesterday that its executive board had approved a 30-month contract with the city that would raise the annual base pay of fire lieutenants to $18,590 as of next Jan. 1.

The American Basketball Association's new team, the San Diego Conquistadors, filled its two most important nonplaying positions yesterday by naming K. C. Jones as coach and Alex Groza as general manager.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday record sales and earnings for both the second quarter and first half.

The city's five District Attorneys yesterday denounced the Knapp Commission's recommendation that Governor Rockefeller appoint a special deputy attorney general with sweeping powers to fight corruption among the city's policemen, prosecutors and judges.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Aug. 9 -- South Vietnamese soldiers reportedly fought enemy forces in rubber plantations 17 miles east of Saigon yesterday and early reports from the field said that Government casualties were heavy.

After receiving a brief critique from the Central Intelligence Agency, Harper Row, Inc., has decided to proceed with the publication of a book by a 26-year-old Yale graduate student that charges that the agency is involved in heroin trafficking in south east Asia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The House Education and Labor Committee, the most liberal committee in the House, approved today legislation that would prohibit long - distance busing to desegregate elementary schools.

DETROIT, Aug. 8 --The Ford Motor Company announced today a multimillion-dollar licensing agreement with a Dutch electronics corporation to develop and possibly manufacture a quiet, low-pollution engine.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation had higher earnings in the second quarter and first half of this year, but sales dropped sharply, it was reported yesterday from the company's Burbank, Calif., headquarters.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 8 -- Dean W. Matthews of the host Riverside Yacht Club won the Area B semi-final series of the men's North American sailing championship today and will race for the Clifford D. Mallory Trophy in the final regatta in Los Angeles, starting Aug. 28.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 8 -American symphony orchestras, in case you haven't noticed, are not given to cuddling up with the avantgarde. Because of their nature and history, large orchestras are inherently conservative: They often may be led to the avant-garde water by some resourceful conductor, but it is rare indeed that they really swallow it.

Secretary General Waldheim -- who have taken it upon themselves to publish advice to President Nixon against the bombing of North Vietnam's dike system -- have had to admit that their information came from Hanoi sources and they could not verify that deliberate targeting of the dikes was occurring.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee voted 10 to 4 today to kill legislation that would have barred state and local governments from imposing intangible property taxes on commercial banks. Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin, the committee's ranking Democrat, called the vote "a great victory for state and local governments and a crushing defeat for the banking lobby."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Bangladesh formally applied today for United Nations membership. The prospects for admission were clouded by China's presence on the Security Council.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- William C. Sullivan, who was forced to retire as assistant director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation last October after a feud with the late J. Edgar Hoover, its chief, has been named as director of the National Narcotics Intelligence Center in the Justice Department.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -Some members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee proposed today to add one word to Senator Henry M. Jackson's resolution setting forth Congressional interpretations of the interim agreement with the Soviet Union on offensive missiles.

Edmond J. Safra, the Swiss financier, announced yesterday a formal offer to buy up to 155,423 shares of the King Lafayette Corporation at $40 per share. Mrs. Margaret Truman Daniel said yesterday that she had written a book about her father, former President Harry S. Truman, after being given access to certain unpublished "letters and memoranda written by him."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Fifteen of 35 wealthy Democrats who contributed a total of $1.2 million to the preconvention nominating campaigns of Senators Hubert H. Humphrey and Edmund S. Muskie say that they will give nothing or only token amounts to the Presidential campaign of Senator George McGovern.

IKEJA, Nigeria, Aug. 8 -Although it was during the heat of the day and the traders were lounging in the shade of their Ikeja market stalls, Emanuel Adelaja Adeleye drew a crowd almost at once when he started to talk.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 8 (AP) -Premier Golda Meir today rejected a personal appeal from the spiritual leader of the Greek Catholic community in Israel to permit the return of dispossessed Christian Arabs to Ikrit and Berem, their villages on the Lebanese border.

YONKERS, Aug. 8 -- In a move to bolster Westchester County's financially pressed bus lines, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority gave the county $795,091 today. The price of old-crop soybeans rose sharply yesterday as the price of new-crop beans dropped.

BARRIE, Ontario, Aug. 5 -Willard L. Kinzie, a hearty and aggressive individualist who has made himself rich in the dairy business, is just the sort of man who might typify Canada's bold, independent spirit.

ATLANTA, Aug. 8 -- Senator David H. Gambrell, Harvardeducated scion of a wealthy Georgia family, and Sam Nunn, a young political unknown from the southern part of the state, appeared tonight to be headed for a runoff in their contest for the Democratic Senate nomination.

LONDON -- What makes a national theater? Britain's National Theater, after languishing somewhat last year, has this season turned itself around and up, and currently, at its temporary home at the Old Vic Theater, can offer a very fair reply to that sometimes vexed question. One requirement of a national theater is variety, another is tradition and yet a third is innovation.

The threat of a strike by 25,000 employes of 140 hotels and motels in the city was averted yesterday with agreement on a new three-year pact. The union said that its 435-member citywide strike committee approved the contract at a meeting late yesterday.

ALBANY, Aug. 8 -- The end of a $2.9-billion building program and the beginning of a period of innovation in enrollment patterns were envisioned here today in the State University's master plan for the balance of the nineteen-seventies.

The American Can Company announced yesterday that it would terminate nine obsolete or uneconomical can-making plants and would transfer this business and move production to other facilities. The company also plans to sell three of its pulp and paper plants.

He will "create destruction and chaos to gain his point. WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today changes in its original rule governing the eventual creation of a composite tape or interrogation system to cover transactions in all securities markets.

The head of the State Commission of Investigation and the Queens District Attorney, Thomas J. Mackell, exchanged strong words of criticism yesterday over a commission report that said Mr. Mackell's office, the police, and the courts had been lax toward narcotics traffickers.

The New York Daily News yesterday contributed $10,000 toward the financing of special events for the first Fall Fashion Festival, Sept. 19 to 26, sponsored by the city and all segments of the fashion industry.

MOSCOW, Aug. 14 -- Communists in Lithuania, faced this year by repeated outbursts of strong religious and nationalist feelings, are being admonished not to antagonize believers with crude, antireligious methods of propaganda.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 14 -- Bobby Fischer asked today for a photocopy of the medical certificate that Boris Spassky submitted yesterday in postponing the 14th game of the $250,000 world championship chess match.
There's going to be a big celebration next month in Montreal to mark a big occasion: the 25th anniversary of Seagram's 7 Crown's status as the largest selling liquor brand in the United States.
The New York Islanders, who will need all the help they can get, have received a mixed blessing by being able to stage their first seven National Hockey League games at home.

Robert Streicher's "Narcissus Descending," presented at the American Theater Laboratory Sunday afternoon, was a mildly inconclusive solo with an utterly fascinating set of program acknowledgments. Among those given special thanks were D. H. Lawrence, Simone de Beauvoir and Senator Thomas F. Eagleton.

A $1.3-million fraud conspiracy was charged in a Federal indictment here yesterday against two business executives and a former Better Business Bureau employe who is now a public relations assistant for State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 14 -- John Gardner of Australia began defense of the United States amateur grass-court tennis championship today by winning two matches at the Meadow Club.
The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market managed yesterday to finish with modest gains after increased selling in the afternoon erased some of the earlier advances.
TOKYO, Aug. 14 (UPI) -- One hundred and four tombs in which the ashes of the owners of pets can rest forever with those of their dogs or cats have been offered for sale by a Japanese animal cemetery.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI) -- Jack Anderson, the columnist, gave the Senate Banking Committee what he said were memorandums of the Federal Bureau of Investigation on three political activists, Jane Fonda, Dr. Benjamin M. Spock and Floyd B. McKissick, today to prove that the F.B.I. "has virtually unlimited access to private bank account records."

A proposed secondary offering of 1.2 million shares of common stock of Johnson Johnson was announced yesterday by Kuhn Loeb Co. which will head an underwriting syndicate for the issue in the near future, subject to market conditions.

The spectators who may have needed a scorecard to identify the political newcomers dominating the Democratic National Convention will not need one to identify the Republican delegates from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut as they assemble in Miami Beach this weekend.

The Civil Aeronautics Board said yesterday that a four-day-old investigation at Kennedy International Airport had uncovered "substantial" numbers of travelers flying on illegally discounted trans-Atlantic airline tickets.

A team headed by Jeff Rubens, the victors in the Spingold knockout team championship at the Summer Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League last month, won the four-session Swiss team tournament at the New York Hilton Hotel last weekend, with a score of 168 victory points of a possible 240.
Eighteen restaurants and other food-processing establishments in the city are on the Health Department's latest list of places having health-code violations.

Well, it's too bad, because I wanted to like "The Man Who Loved Cat Dancing" -- wanted, that is, to be able to recommend a crackling good yarn for a lazy August afternoon. But the little gargoyle that hangs on the edge of my imagination just would not stop dripping catcalls and wisecracks and other obstructions to the flight of romantic fancy that Marilyn Durham's first novel demands.

MUNICH, Aug. 14 -- The New York City Ballet ended its four-day visit to Munich tonight with a program of four of George Balanchine's ballets. The company received mixed, but predominantly negative, critical reaction after its two programs on Friday and Saturday.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 14 -- New York Yankee hitters, who had been doing well lately, found themselves overmatched against Bruce Dal Canton and Norm Angelini tonight, and absorbed a 3-0 defeat at the hands of the Kansas City Royals.

These are excerpts from a debate appearing in The New Statesman between Herbert Marcuse, professor of philosophy at the University of California at San Diego, and Raymond Aron, professor of philosophy at the College de France.
MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 14 -- With no uncertainty left about its 1972 convention, the Republican party began drafting today the rules that will govern the selection of its 1976 Presidential nominee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Commerce Secretary Peter G. Peterson said today that he saw "great promise" in the possibility of American companies engaging in joint ventures with Soviet enterprises to exploit the Soviet Union's untapped energy and raw materials, such as natural gas, oil platinum, copper, chrome, zinc and timber.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Monday, Aug. 15 (Agence France-Presse) -- The Laotian Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma and the Pathet Lao leader, Prince Souphanouvong, have agreed on a general cease-fire throughout Laos in a move toward what both call "national compromise," the English-language daily The Bangkok Post reported here today without giving any sources for its information.
Steel production last week totaled 2,418,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was down 1.1 per cent from the 2,444,000 tons poured in the preceding week.
The Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange are investigating recent trading activity in the stock of Liggett Myers, Inc.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy yesterday endorsed the Knapp Commission's recommendation that Governor Rockefeller appoint a special deputy attorney general to prosecute official corruption, while the city's five District Attorneys met with the Governor's counsel to oppose it.
For advertising and agencies there was both good news and bad news in the 1972 report issued yesterday by Daniel Starch Staff on the attitudes and buying habits of the readers of 75 magazines.

When Norman Raben awoke yesterday in his home at Loudonville, N. Y., and opened his mail, he must have been very unhappy. Last Memorial Day, he had sailed his 50-foot sloop La Forza del Destino in the Storm Trysail Club's around-Block Island Race and "won" on corrected time.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- Howard A. Pierson of River Vale (N. J.) Golf Club posted a 36-hole score of 67, 76 -- 143 today and won the medal in sectional qualifying for the United States Amateur golf championship.
The 12 fencers who will represent the United States in the four individual championships in the Olympics were announced yesterday by Alan M. Ruben, captain of the team.

Frontlash, a nonpartisan national coalition of youth and student organizations, is pressing a drive here to register young and old workers who might not otherwise be qualified to vote in the November election.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI) -- The Nixon Administration said today that it opposed a Democratic proposal to authorize $2.2-billion a year for five years in general aid to public schools. At the same time, it reaffirmed support for a proposed tax credit of up to $200 a year for each pupil whose parents pay tuition to a private school.

A Richmond County Family Court judge ruled "most regretfully" yesterday that his court had no jurisdiction over "horrible conditions" at the Willowbrook State School for mental defectives on Staten Island.
MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 14 -- The City Council voted today to grant the use of Flamingo Park as a campsite for young protestors during the Republican National Convention next week.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 14 -- The "Festival of Hope," the weekend rock festival that was supposed to net its sponsors, the Easter Seal Society of Nassau Country, more than $300,000, was apparently a financial disaster that may have to be absorbed by the charitable organization.
Short-term interest rates crept higher yesterday, spurred by the decision of several major New York City banks to advance the rates they officially offer to pay for certificate-of-deposit money.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI) -- The House passed and sent to President Nixon today authority for the Small Business Administration to make disaster relief loans to victims of natural catastrophies dating to Jan. 1, 1971.
HOUSTON, Aug. 14 (UPI) -- Roger Metzger's two-run double and a two-run single by Cesar Cedeno enabled the Houston Astros to overcome a five-run deficit tonight and beat the San Francisco Giants 7-5.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Aug. 15 -- Another South Vietnamese ammunition dump was blown up early yesterday as Communist commando attacks, urban terrorism and shelling continued to increase.

SARAFAND, Israel, Aug. 14 -- Two Arab women guerrillas were sentenced to life imprisonment by a military tribunal here today for their part last May in the hijacking of a Belgian airliner flying to Israel.

Two businessmen shot to death Friday night in an upper East Side restaurant were apparently gunned down by a hired killer who mistook them for members of the Mafia family of Joseph A. Colombo Sr., Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said yesterday.
MANILA, Aug. 14 -- The visible evidence and preliminary calculations make it clear that the damage caused by the floods in central Luzon has been enormous.
One of the five children in a Brooklyn family whose Volkswagen bus was in a head-on collision on the Henry Hudson Parkway on Sunday night was still in critical condition last night.
STUTTGART, West Germany, Aug. 14 (UPI) -- More than 100 black American soldiers clashed with dozens of West German policemen Saturday night after the police arrested a black soldier.

DALLAS, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Coach Tom Landry of Dallas moved a backfield coach, Dan Reeves, into the quarterback role behind Craig Morton today and shuffled Sid Gillman, former head coach, from the research and development department into Reeves's post.

The Chemical New York Corporation announced yesterday that its net operating earnings dropped 24.6 per cent in July to $4.47-million, or 33 cents a share, from $5.9-million or 43 cents a share in the year-earlier month.
LONDON, Aug. 14 -- Transit camps and emergency housing are among the measures being planned here to cope with the threatened influx into Britain of 55,000 Asians from Uganda.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- A spokesman denied today that Secretary General Waldheim had sent a message to Gen. Jean Bedel Bokassa, President of the Central African Republic, protesting beatings that led to the death of some men serving prison terms for theft.

NORTH HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 14 -- A lumber company president, his wife and their daughter were found stabbed to death this morning in their ransacked home in a fashionable section of this New Haven suburb.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 15 (Agence France-Presse) -- Premier Souvanna Phouma today denied a Bangkok newspaper report that he had reached agreement on a general ceasefire with Prince Souphanouvong, head of the Pathet Lao anti-Government forces.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -Senator Henry M. Jackson charged today that the Russians had "lied" to President Nixon at the Moscow summit meeting in May about the number of Soviet missile-launching submarines under construction or deployed.

The recent signing of Derek Sanderson to a $2.6 million contract to play hockey provokes consternation and disbelief. At face value, it appears unjustifiable for a man to command a huge salary because he can shoot a puck 110 miles per hour through a six-foot opening with consistency, as can Bobby Hull, or to hit a tight end with accuracy as does Joe Namath, or to stuff baskets and block shots as does Wilt Chamberlain.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- United States spacecraft have discovered a violent solar storm that may have produced the highest energy radiation ever recorded from the sun, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -Lawrence F. O'Brien, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, citing undisclosed new evidence, said today that the committee's office had been bugged for some time before June 17, the day five men were seized in the office with electronic surveillance equipment.

They are quiet, neat, rather formal men for the most part, and largely of Irish extraction. Leonard Bernstein will be the star of a week-long film festival to be held at Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.

MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 15 -Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird urged Republicans today to adopt a platform that "will reject policies of planned weakness, of white-flag waving, of begging and of abandonment of our nation's role in helping to maintain peace."

Mrs. Indira Gandhi celebrated the 25th anniversary of India's independence yesterday with a renewed pledge to spur social and economic development for 585 million Indians. Her ability to make good on this promise will depend in large measure on her success in fulfilling another anniversary commitment -- "to establish lasting peace between India, Bangladesh and Pakistan."

Things are falling together beautifully for George Follmer, and they couldn't happen to a more deserving driver. In this year's TransAmerican series Follmer has won the manufacturers's championship for Javelin and the personal title for himself; in the Canadian-American Challenge Cup, he has won two of the four races run. Now comes word that Follmer will have a first-class Indianapolis-type car in the California 500 at Ontario oil Sept. 3.

Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts announced yesterday the indictment of two plain-clothes men on charges of kidnapping a 20year-old bantamweight Golden Gloves boxer, beating him, shooting him in the shoulder and thigh and then filing false robbery and assault charges against him.

The Jefferson Airplane couldn't have picked a better time to bestow one of its famous free outdoor concerts upon New York rock fans. After the unfortunate experience of last weekend's poorly attended Festival of Hope in Westbury, L. I., the roller coaster, success-failure pattern that has dominated rock festivals for the last few years seemed to be heading toward the downslope once again.

The anticipated shift of Jewish voters from the Democratic to the Republican party can be explained largely by the defense aid channeled to Israel by the Nixon Administration. This overlooks the pressing social problems of that country's SephardicOriental population and the monopoly over political power in the hands of East European Jews.
Have women chess players got what it takes to reach the level of a Bobby Fischer?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee unanimously approved today a bill that would prevent farmers from feeding DES, a synthetic hormone, to cattle out of fear that DES causes cancer.

Interpretations of the events of that period may differ, but there can be little dispute on the facts or the Nixon Administration's detailed knowledge of them now and then.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Aug. 15 -- Senator George McGovern declined a Presidential invitation to be briefed on the Vietnam situation by Henry A. Kissinger because, he said here today, official White House briefings customarily "go wide of the mark."

BUENOS AIRES, Wednesday, Aug. 16 -- Leftist extremists raided an army-run maximum security prison at Rawson in Southern Argentina yesterday freeing a number of political prisoners and taking at least six of them to Chile in a hijacked airliner, carrying 90 passengers and a crew of six.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A House committee said today that the Nixon Administration encourages pollution of the nation's streams and rivers by not prosecuting vigorously under the Refuse Act of 1899, which is aimed at curbing water pollution.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A Federal judge dissolved today the injunction that has blocked construction of an oil pipeline across Alaska for more than two years.
MADRID, Aug. 15 -- The principal assistant to Juan D. Peron said today that the former Argentine President would return home before the end of the year.

The board of directors of the Sonesta International Hotels Corporation announced yesterday it had authorized the company to purchase in the open market up to 100,000 shares of its previously issued common stock. The company has 2.5 million shares outstanding and 3.5 million authorized. The company

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 -Ramsay Clark said here last night that he had been wrong not to speak out against the Vietnam war when he was Deputy Attorney General and then Attorney General in President Johnson's Cabinet while the war was expanding.

Rosalyn Tureck and Szymon Goldberg play other music, but when one hears their names it is Bach's that comes to mind. The two artists pooled their talents and expertise at Monday night's Mostly Mozart Festival, and made a memorable splash in Bach's Clavier Concerto in D minor.

After a lapse of about two years, as well as the expenditure of a large sum of money, the Knapp Commission finally released its report in which it chose to engage in a "smear" on our courts, the five distinguished District Attorneys of this city and on the rank and file of our Police Department.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -Those who know him well describe Paul Culliton Warnke as "brilliant," "complex" and "tremendously able" -words that might fit dozens of other former high government officials or top-notch corporate lawyers in this city.

REYKJAVIK, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- Chester Fox said today he planned to sue Fischer "for every cent we can lay hands on" because Fischer would not let Mr. Fox, a movie director, film the world championship chess match on closed-circuit television.

CRANFORD, N. J., Aug. 15 -Efforts to unify liberal and regular New Jersey Democrats behind the Presidential candidacy of Senator George McGovern received a sharp setback here tonight when the Democratic State Committee designated Nicholas Caputo, the Essex Sheriff, as New Jersey's fifth Democratic national committeeman.

The State Division of Housing and Community Renewal asserted yesterday that a 40 per cent increase in authorized new construction of apartment units in New York City was largely the result of decontrol of vacant apartments enacted by the Legislature last year.

Senator George McGovern, the Democratic Presidential nominee, and his running mate, Sargent Shriver, received support yesterday from two major unions, the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and the United Automobile Workers.

The Department of Justice has obtained in Federal Court in Brooklyn the dismissal of a two-count espionage indictment against a Soviet citizen who was permitted to return to the Soviet Union last May.

YORK, England, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Roberto, ridden by Braulio Baeza, who saw the colt for the first time just hours before the race, won the $125,000 Benson and Hedges Gold Cup today and foiled Brigadier Gerard's bid for a record-equaling 16 straight victories.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- The House unanimously voted $1.6-billion in disaster relief for victims of the tropical storm Agnes today despite warnings that much of the money might be wasted on fraudulent claims.

NORTH HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 15 -- Detectives today were examining the remnants of a pair of rubber gloves found behind the ransacked house where a wealthy lumber executive, his wife and their daughter were discovered slain yesterday in this New Haven suburb.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- A meeting between undefeated Linda's Chief and the formidable Secretariat will be the big attraction tomorrow, with the 59th running of the Sanford Stakes. There are five others in this six-furlong sprint for 2-year-olds but the big expectation is a duel between this pair.
The Leasco Corporation announced yesterday that it had completed arrangements to borrow $150-million from 46 domestic and international banks.

DETROIT, Aug. 15 -- The United States auto companies, heading into the final weeks of the 1972 model year, sold 196,166 cars in the Aug. 1-10 period, up more than 41,000 units from the year-earlier total of 154,871.
Investors eagerly purchased the bulk of a $106-million New York State bond offering yesterday and lifted a sagging tax-exempt market to small gains for the day.

The White House has called in representatives of the four biggest automobile manufacturers to talk over their proposed price increases on 1973 cars. General Motors, Ford and Chrysler intend to raise prices by $85 to $91 a car -- increases they call necessary to cover the costs of meeting Federal safety and antipollution standards. American Motors wants to lift its prices by $78 to cover these items, plus $68 for other cost increases.

School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner said yesterday that city laws had forced a change in policy on reporting the names of student drug users, and said the rule "may well be inconsistent with current efforts by the schools to fight drug abuse among students."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 15 -- In Yugoslavia's variation of Marxism, which risks being termed credit-card Communism by some wag now that the Diners' Club is enrolling members here, the consumer is king. His needs, tastes and whims guide much of the country's economic activity.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- In a letter to President Nixon, Gen. Idi Amin, President of Uganda, has offered to pay compensation to the families of two Americans killed in Uganda last year.

A broad-based committee of state and city legislators, municipal officials and members of the construction industry was formed yesterday to review the labyrinth of laws that many builders contend prompt bribery in their business.

KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 15 (Reuters) -- Geoffrey Rippon, a special British envoy, had almost two hours of talks today with President Idi Amin, but the Uganda leader said afterward that he stood firm on his 90-day deadline for the expulsion of 50,000 or more Asians.

The other team in town -the Mets -- began a drive last night to recapture their status as New York's No. 1 topic of baseball conversation, whipping Atlanta, 5-0, behind the pitching of Jim McAndrew and Tug McGraw and the hitting of Ed Kranepool and Tommie Agee.

BOSTON, Aug. 15 -- Despite the increasing financial problems in intercollegiate athletics, the National Collegiate Athletic Association's executive committee today issued a favorable income report on some of its championships.

WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 15 (UPI) -- A former Army captain said in an interview yesterday that a 1971 military report estimating that 25 per cent of the lower-ranking enlisted men in Vietnam were addicted to heroin had deliberately been withheld.

TOKYO, Aug. 15 (Reuters) -Japan recorded a surplus of $410-million in its balance of payments for July, the Finance Ministry said in a preliminary report today. This compares with a surplus of $240-million in June and $495-million in July, 1971.

TORONTO, Aug. 15 -- Stacks of Pepsi-Cola were alongside tables laden with slender bottles of sunflower sweet white wine and sharp Mao-tai liqueurs today as China offered a preview of its two-week trade exhibition, which will open here tomorrow.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 15 -"There is a big difference between the reaction of the Government and that of the people" to Japan's overtures to Peking, an electronics manufacturer observed.

President Nixon, nominated Representative Frank T. Bow, Republican of Ohio, to replace Robert M. Sayre as Ambassador to Panama. The 71-year-old Mr. Bow was elected to the House in 1950 and was ranking minority member of its Appropriations Committee before announcing his retirement from Congress.

American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., announced yesterday that an agreement in principle had been reached to sell A.B.C. Films, Inc., its television film syndication subsidiary, to a group of A.B.C. Films executives.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (UPI) -Barnabas F. Sears, special prosecutor in the conspiracy trial of Edward V. Hanrahan, Cook County State's Attorney, told Circuit Court Judge Philip J. Romiti today that Mr. Hanrahan and his brother, William, threatened him as he left the courtroom after a morning session.

New York City has been betrayed by its law-enforcement apparatus. The lawmakers, under the chairmanship of State Senator John H. Hughes of Syracuse, put much of the fault for widespread corruption on the fragmentation and lack of coordination in existing law-enforcement efforts.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Raft-riding in the lower Niagara River's rapids will be suspended for several days, it was disclosed today.

Ever since Billy Martin was a street kid in Oakland, Calif., getting into fights under his square name of Alfred Manuel Pesano, he has been characterized by what Joseph Conrad called "an open, generous, frank, barbarous recklessness."
NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 15 (AP) -- As the thermometer goes down, the number of welfare families being evicted or deprived of utilities will go up, legal-aid spokesmen predict.

MOSCOW, Aug. 15 -- Jewish sources reported tonight that Soviet authorities are instituting a new system of heavy exit fees ranging from $5,000 to $25,000 for educated Jews who want to emigrate to Israel.

Zvi Rosen of the Maccabi soccer team of Tel Aviv, which will meet the New York Cosmos in an exhibition at Hofstra tonight, holds two records in Israel -- he has longer hair and has come here to play more times than any other Israeli player.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Henry Kissinger's trips to Paris are good news and good politics, since they suggest that there is some movement toward peace, but the fact is that even Kissinger does not expect any real change in the Paris talks until late in the election campaign.

City Council investigators opened an unusual challenge to state authority yesterday by subpoenaing the State Commissioner of Social Services after he had declined an invitation to testify on the extent of ineligibility in the city's welfare rolls.

BERLIN, Aug. 15 (AP) -- An explosion aloft preceded the crash yesterday of an East German Interflug charter jet in which all 156 aboard were killed, the official East German press agency, A.D.N., said tonight.

Shielded from the press by club officials since he suffered a separated shoulder last Saturday against Los Angeles, Roger Staubach, the Dallas Cowboys' quarterback, will come home today from Baylor Hospital, where his right shoulder was operated on Sunday.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 15 -- Although the sprained ankle Bob Grim suffered in yesterday's practice stiffened up, the wide receiver worked out with the New York Giants at Monmouth College today but didn't go full blast.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -Two measures of the United States balance of international payments showed improvement in the second quarter of this year, but the underlying payments accounts apparently continued in heavy deficit, the Commerce Department reported today.
It was a free rock concert, a park cleanup, a voter registration drive and a mass picnic all in one.
The New York police yesterday continued their quest to learn the identity and whereabouts of the gunman who killed two businessmen last Friday in the mistaken belief that they were Mafia members.

The F. M. Schaefer Corporation announced yesterday the election of Robert W. Lear as president and chief executive officer, effective Oct. 1. He succeeds R. J. Schaefer, 72 years old, who will retire after forty-eight years of service. Mr. Lear, 55, has for the past five years been president and chief operating officer of Indian Head, Inc., until his resignation on July 25.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I. Aug. 15 -- In the summer the east end of Long Island attracts many writers, artists and actors. Most of them are here for relaxation or for solitary creation and not for theatergoing. As a result, theater has a difficult time surviving.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The charge by Sargent Shriver, the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, that President Nixon "blew" a chance to end the Vietnam war in 1969 has produced a stormy political debate in Washington, but as with many controversies over Vietnam, the historical truth remains murky and subject to many interpretations.

The five-man committee set up to manage the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York spent yesterday meeting with representatives of its medical groups as part of an effort to chart an immediate course of action for the financially troubled organization.

A Long Island real-estate broker was sentenced to a year in prison and fined $2,500 in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday for having submitted false applications and credit information to the Federal Housing Administration. The assistant United States attorney who prosecuted the case, Anthony T. Accetta, said it was the first conviction and sentencing arising from a Federal grand-jury investigation into F.H.A. loan frauds in the metropolitan area.

The stock market has been dancing around in new high ground lately, but many investors do not seem to realize it. Most of them are waiting for the Dow-Jones industrial average to confirm what all the other indicators have been saying.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 8 -- Henry Bunis of Cincinnati, a 19-year-old sophomore at Columbia University, upset the defender, John Gardner of Australia, 4-6, 7-6, 6-3, today in the second round of the United States amateur grass-court tennis championships at the Meadow Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -John N. Mitchell, the former head of President Nixon's re-election organization, said today that Ramsey Clark had been "duped" during a recent visit to North Vietnam and had allowed himself to be used by that country in a propaganda campaign.

Edmond J. Safra, the international financier who is bidding for control of the $244million Kings Lafayette Bank in Brooklyn, got a clean bill of health yesterday from Harry W. Albright Jr., the New York State Superintendent of Banks.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Aug. 16 (AP) -United States B-52 bombers flew heavy raids in the Saigon area early yesterday, striking at enemy positions as close as 24 miles from the capital.

MONTREAL, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- The gross national product will rise 9.7 per cent to $1.15billion this year, with real growth accounting for more than 6 per cent and inflation less than 3.5 per cent of the increase, a survey of 67 economists predicted today.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- How to get young people to go to the theater is said to be a perennial problem, although I personally think it is a problem easily overstressed. In any event, it has clearly been solved by a very vigorous British theater company called the Young Vic.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A bankrupt real estate man, Martin A. Decker, asked a Federal District Judge today for more time to plan the reorganization of his multimillion-dollar financial empire.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The State Department said today that action on a proposal to bar Irish International Airlines from New York airports had been deferred until next year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -Industrial production, partly hampered by the effects of tropical storm Agnes, rose only moderately in July for the third consecutive month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -The Securities and Exchange Commission is looking into the possibility of setting "stiffer disclosure requirements" on companies' "debt maturities and contractual commitments" to try to give more advance warning in situations such as that of the Penn Central, the commission's chairman, William J. Casey, disclosed today.
SAN DIEGO, Aug. 15 -- Sargent Shriver won the support today of Paul Ziffren and Eugene Wyman, who have been two of Southern California's most powerful brokers of Democratic funds.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 15 -- Jerome Barkum, the New York Jets' No. 1 draft pick, worked out with the club today for the first time since officially signing his contract last night and dropped the first two passes from Joe Namath, an indication that Barkum has some familiarizing to do.

Richard Joyce Smith, trustee of the New Haven Railroad, a corporate shell, recommended yesterday to Archibald DeB. Johnson, chairman of the Penn Central Company, that he petition the Federal District Court in Philadelphia for reorganization of the holding company (Penn Central) under Chapter X of the Federal Bankruptcy Act and ask for the appointment of a disinterested trustee.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Aug. 15 -- A delegation of Zippies -- a splinter offshoot of the radical - Yippies -- testified early tonight before one of the subcommittees considering platform proposals for the Republican National Convention.

A ragwood- and poison ivy-choked corner of the George Washington High School campus was the scene of a brief archeological dig yesterday as about 20 students attacked the ground with shovels and hoes in search of buried relics from Fort George Hill's colonial past.
BOSTON (AP) -- Looking for a compromise between full-time housework and fulltime employment?
Don Gullett, the Cincinnati Reds' young pitching sensation last season and a near flop this season, came up with a performance last night that could be considered a morale booster for him.

TORONTO, Aug. 15 (UPI) -Top-seeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania, afflicted with a flu bug, staved off a determined bid by Frew McMillan of South Africa, today and won 6-4, 2-6, 7-6. The victory advanced him to the second round of the Canadian open tennis championships.

The Procter Gamble company, the nation's leading merchandiser of soaps and related lines, completed 20 years of record sales and earnings in the annual period ended June 30, according to results issued yesterday from its Cincinnati headquarters.

WASHINGTON -- The treaty limiting the deployment of antiballistic missile systems and the interim agreement in offensive weapons is an achievement of the greatest significance for the security of the United States and the Soviet Union and the world.
