A musical revue from Israel has been booked into the Palace Theater for a one-week run of 10 performances starting Oct. 2. The youthful cast of "From Israel With Love" is made up of 26 singers, actors and dancers, all former members of the Israeli Army Entertainment Corps.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 -The American Bar Association opposed today proposed Federal legislation that would create a nationwide no-fault system for handling personal injury claims arising out of automobile accidents.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market ended lower yesterday for the first time in six sessions as profit taking weakened both lists.

New evidence that some cases of manic-depressive illness can be inherited through a genetic defect will be reported in Copenhagen today by a team of scientists from the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Federal Government may have paid $380-million in excess Medicare claims to hospitals since 1967, Representative Les Aspin said today.

Mayor Lindsay, breezing through Queens yesterday in what he called a display of "mayoral presence," drew responses that ranged from angry catcalls of housing pickets from Forest Hills to enthusiastic cheers of black youngsters in Rochdale Village.

Stock prices pulled back a bit in profit taking yesterday, after several market indicators rose to record levels on Monday and the Dow-Jones industrial average reached a 44month high.

A member of District 1 Community School Board on the Lower East Side obtained a show cause order yesterday in an effort to bar a meeting tomorrow night that is expected to pass a resolution to eject her from the board.

In yesterday's 14th game of the world championship chess match, Boris Spassky outplayed Bobby Fischer in the middle game, winning a pawn. But the champion from the Soviet Union threw away his winning chances by committing a blunder on his 27th move, permitting the American challenger to equalize.

A major meeting to determine whether the Mafia family of Joseph A. Colombo Sr. should turn to narcotics to increase declining revenues was in the making last Friday night at the Neopolitan Noodle restaurant when a gunman killed two businessmen.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy yesterday modified his apparent endorsement on Monday of the Knapp Commission's recommendation for a special state prosecutor to combat official corruption in New York City.

David T. Dellinger and the Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan announced yesterday that demonstrations at the Republican National Convention in Miami Beach next week would include evidence of dike bombing in North Vietnam and would culminate in a massive sit-down Wednesday outside the convention hall.

The New York Yankees will play at Yankee Stadium for the next 30 years under terms of a lease signed yesterday with the city, which will renovate the venerable Bronx ball park into what Mayor Lindsay called "the most modern sports arena in the country."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UPI) -- Ramsey Clark, at one point holding up a United States "bomblet" given him by Hanoi's Mayor, told a Senate subcommittee today of seeing extensive damage to dikes, homes and hospitals during his visit to North Vietnam.

FREDERICKSBURG, Tex., Aug. 16 -- Former President Lyndon B. Johnson said today that he would support and vote for the entire Democratic ticket, from the courthouse to the White House. He endorsed Senator George McGovern for President in a statement sent to weekly newspapers here, with the request that it be released to the news services.

George C. Wallace, the Governor of Alabama, underwent surgery for the second time in a month to drain an abcess caused by the gunshot wounds that felled him in May. The operation, at the University of Alabama Hospital in Birmingham, was completed "without complications,'' according to a hospital spokesman.
Early advances in wheat and soybeans were trimmed yesterday in late dealings.
Three persons have been arrested and one is being sought in three separate schemes to cash forged state lottery tickets, the Queens District Attorney's office said today.

UTRECHT, the Netherlands, Aug. 16 -- A tall bespectacled Methodist pastor from the British West Indies, garbed in a short-sleeved white sport shirt and gray slacks, mounted the stage of a conference hall here today to address an international gathering of churchmen.

James W. McKee Jr., 50, president and chief operating officer of CPC International, Inc., has been named chief executive officer. He succeeds Howard C. Harder who will continue as chairman of the board and of the executive committee. Mr. Harder said the move was made on his recommendation and that he expects to devote most of his time to the company's public affairs and planning programs.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Housing starts declined in July but remained well above the two-million annual rate level, the Commerce Department reported today.

The utility meter reader is about to ring his last doorbell. In his place there may be aircraft flying overhead, an encoder emplaced behind the meter's dials or an outside jack for a cassette recorder.

If you're thinking of tying in with the nation's forthcoming bicentennial, and you want the blessings of the official agency running the show, forget it. At least until 1974.

Anthony Newman does not so much play music as consume it. The young virtuoso gave a harpsichord, pedal harpsichord and piano concert on Tuesday night at Philharmonic Hall that left one astonished, as in the past, at his tireless fluency and ability to gobble up famously difficult pieces.
The computer chess match in Boston proved one thing: computers have a long way to go before they become international grandmasters. But their game was an interesting experiment nonetheless.

AMITYVILLE, L. I. -- White-haired and garrulous, Mrs. Walter Sharp took advantage of her husband's retirement as head of the English department at Memorial High School in this south shore community on the border of Nassau and Suffolk Counties to go back to school herself in France and strengthen her credentials for a career of her own in cooking.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -Senator George McGovern confirmed today that Pierre Salinger, the former Presidential press secretary, had met with North Vietnamese negotiators in Paris at his request to discuss the prisoner of war situation.

Deputy City Administrator Mark Corrigan said at a United States Department of Transportation hearing yesterday that New York City would have difficulty maintaining its program of reduced transit fares for the elderly without Federal aid.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -The Government, in an unusually candid report on worldwide drug traffic, said today that despite increased enforcement efforts the United States and other countries were able to seize only "a small fraction" of the total illegal flow of heroin.
Bill D. Moyers will serve as commentator for the Public Broadcasting Service gavel-to-gavel telecasts of the Republican National Convention next week, it was announced yesterday.
Over the years Robert William Meserve has acquired a spate of academic and professional honors as well as a propensity for making quips at his own expense and expanse.
Deputy Police Commissioner William P. McCarthy said yesterday that the police would make public the names of some business concerns allegedly dominated by organized crime.

Caught in a cross fire of complaints from Manhattan residents and demands from Bronx residents, the Board of Estimate yesterday approved negotiation of permanent franchise for a Bronx express bus line to Manhattan that uses Fifth Avenue as its main route.
The City Board of Education was accused yesterday of ignoring almost 1,400 Health Code violations in 153 elementary schools in the city, some of which go back to 1969.

The tales of her theatrical forebears already told, Margaret Webster has now finished writing an autobiography on the joys of a life consumed as a Shakespearean scholar and a distinguished director and actress.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -Mention the National Arts Endowment and the response might be at least a nod of recognition; mention the National Humanities Endowment and a puzzled frown is more likely. But this little-known Federal agency, with about $38-million to dispense this year, is alive and, despite some recent internal troubles, apparently well.
Lucy Jarvis, a news producer for the National Broadcasting Company television network, is scheduled to arrive in Peking today to begin filming one or two news documentaries.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 17 (UPI) -- Mrs. Barbara Boddie of Shreveport, La., defeated the defending champion, Laura Baugh of Long Beach, Calif., 6 and 5, in the quarterfinals of the United States Golf Association's national women's amateur tournament today.

Senator George McGovern has decided to visit Wall Street in an attempt to allay some of the fears in the financial community over the economic policies he espoused prior to winning the Democratic nomination for President.
A surprise audit of the books of duPont Glore Forgan, Inc., the Wall Street investment house, gave the company a clean bill of health, it was disclosed here yesterday.
New York got another fulltime jazz club this week when Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, which has been dangling jazz before its customers on Monday nights, expanded to a full week of jazz.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 17 -- The 40,000-strong Ulster Defense Association, a Protestant civiian force organized on military lines, is resuming 24-hour guard duty on streets in Protestant areas of Belfast following a blast in the heart of a Protestant district.
A new audio-visual subsidiary serving the health-care field was announced yesterday by the J. Walter Thompson Company.
The New York Civil Liberties Union asked the Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday to declare unconstitutional a state law barring voter registration through most of September.
The Dreyfus Corporation, which manages the nation's third largest mutual fund, yesterday announced a reshuffling of its management team.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17 (UPI) -- The air in New York and Tokyo is worse on normal days than the smog that enveloped Moscow during the last 10 days while peat bogs and forests burned east of the capital, Moscow's chief public health officer concerned with sanitation said today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 17 (UPI) -- Four Americans were killed and 28 were wounded in the war in Vietnam last week, the United States command reported today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -- From the standpoint of the American international position I believe the very best outcome of this year's U.S. election would be the renewal of Richard Nixon's mandate for another four years in a campaign which allowed Sargent Shriver to gain a national stature sufficient to enable him to run as the principal Democratic candidate in 1976.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 17 -- A pro football season in which New York's two teams would share Shea Stadium was termed "a physical impossibility" today by T. Wellington Mara, president of the Giants.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Aug. 18 -- Henry A. Kissinger and President Nguyen Van Thieu conferred for more than two hours here yesterday. United States sources confirmed that the recent secret talks in Paris between Mr. Kissinger and the North Vietnamese figured in today's discussion.
In response to objections raised by the building industry, Mayor Lindsay yesterday submitted amendments to proposed legislation for fire safety requirements in high-rise office buildings.
Central Harlem's first mental retardation diagnostic and treatment center was opened yesterday at the Sydenham Neighborhood Family Care Center.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The General Motors Corporation, yielding to White House pressure, said today that it was trimming its proposed ,$90 increase in the price of 1973 model passenger ears to $59.

LONDON, Aug. 17 (Reuters) -- Thousands of British dockers voted today to end their three-week-old strike. But the 9,000 men at Liverpool, the second biggest port in the nation, decided to continue the work stoppage.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- One by one, African nations agree to boycott the Olympic Games if athletes representing the "rebel government of Rhodesia" are allowed to compete. Ethiopia, whose runners dominated the distance events in a pre-Olympic track meet in Munich, instructs Mamo Wolde, Shibrov Regassa and their durable countrymen to keep bags packed for a quick return home, and then Kenya becomes the 10th country to announce a pullout.
PARIS, Aug. 18 -- Hanoi's spokesman at the Paris peace talks said today that President Nixon was trying to create an impression of optimism while at the same time intensifying the war in Vietnam.

The Pittsburgh National Corporation, parent company of the $2-billion Pittsburgh National Bank, announced yesterday that it planned to reacquire up to 400,000 of its common shares for use in the exercise of stock options and warrants.

The Federal Reserve System, which has been struggling recently to get monetary expansion back on the track of moderate growth that it achieved in the second quarter, has tightened credit somewhat in the last few weeks.

Senator William Proxmire, a critic of the nation's space program, has become chairman of a subcommittee that has a dominant role in shaping the space budget. Saturday Review, which has split into four monthly magazines published in weekly rotation and covering the arts, education, society and science, announced yesterday that it expected to have more than one million subscribers by the end of this year.

MARCO ISLAND, Fla., Aug. 17 -- The Chrysler Corporation displayed its 1973 model automobiles here today and forecast a sales gain of 185,000 vehicles over the 1,775,000 models sold in the current model year.

Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Federal Trade Commission accused E. J. Korvette, the big discount chain, today of making false representations to sell home improvements and failing to honor guarantees.

William W. Boeschenstein, president of OwensCorning Fiberglas Corporation, has been elected chief executive officer effective Jan. 1, 1973. He will succeed Gen. Lauris Norstad, Former commander of the Atlantic Alliance, who will retire on Jan. 1.

EAST MEADOW, L. I. -- Mrs. Clifford Irving said today she "didn't know" what would happen to her marriage after her husband served a two-and-a-half-year prison sentence following conviction on charges stemming from a fraudulent autobiography of Howard R. Hughes.

Marriage, like politics and religion, is a subject about which everyone has an opinion -- few of which are dispassionate. In our swinging, sex-oriented society it is often maligned as archaic and restrictive of personal freedom. But it also has its defenders, who seek to repel and vanquish the behemoth of youth cult, women's lib detractors, with vicious imprecations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17--North Vietnam, in what it called an "important editorial," seemed today to rebuke both the Soviet Union and China for allowing relations with the United States to weaken their support for Hanoi's cause.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., Aug. 17 -- "Hey, wake up! We've won the race," shouted the crew of La Forza del Destino as she breezed into the harbor at 7:38 this morning.

The International Harvester Company realized increases of 93.9 per cent in earnings and 14 per cent in sales for the third quarter ended July 31, while the gains for the nine-month period were 182.5 per cent and 16 per cent, respectively, according to yesterday's report from Chicago headquarters.

Clark's odds-on Shadow Brook in the Lovely Night Hurdle Handicap on today's program, the annual National Steeplechase Day at the Saratoga meeting. A group of civil rights and political activists yesterday announced the formation of a new coalition to lobby for more construction jobs for blacks and Puerto Ricans.
A Washington Heights couple were arrested yesterday after the police said they had found more than five pounds of cocaine in their refrigerator.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday. Aug. 19 -- Rockets fired by enemy gunners struck the Danang air base and a nearby residential area yesterday, reportedly killing 27 South Vietnamese civilians and one American airman.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 18 -- Two British soldiers were killed by snipers and a young Roman Catholic was assassinated today in one of Belfast's worst flare-ups of violence since the army occupied Catholic enclaves of the city three weeks ago.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 18 (AP) -- The United States women's Olympic swimming team cracked three world relay records tonight as it wound up two weeks of training in the University of Tennessee pool with an exhibition meet.

DETROIT, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- The United Automobile Workers has contributed $75,000 to the campaign of Senator George McGovern as the first part of a "most substantial contribution" to the Democratic ticket, Leonard Woodcock, president of the union, said today.

New regulations prohibiting city policemen from firing warning shots and firing at moving vehicles were described by Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy yesterday as "an attempt to balance the safety of the policeman with the safety of the community."

ALBANY -- If only Samuel Gompers had listened to Morris Hillquit fifty years ago, George Meany would not be in the political bind he is in today. Morris Hillquit, the Intellectual leader of the Socialist party of America from its founding in 1900 until his death in 1933, was a lawyer who represented many of the leading unions in New York.
Venice is a good place to hunt for objects of the thick earthenware called faience because it is a popular item in a group of fine antique shops there.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 18 -- It looked a little like a reunion of graduates of the Cedar bar, the New York pub where artists and critics generated abstract expressionism during the nine-teen-fifties.

Walston Co., Inc., a large member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that the Charleston Investment Company -- a concern formed by Mr. and Mrs. H. Ross Perot -- had invested $5-million in Walston through the purchase of convertible preferred stock and warrants.

In an unusual display of cooperation, guards and prisoners at the Ossining Correctional Facility, better known as "Sing Sing," have teamed up to help fight sickle-cell disease both inside and outside the prison.
The second attempted coup in thirteen months against King Hassan II of Morocco increases the vulnerability of a traditional Arab monarchy which has enjoyed substantial United States support.
LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Robert Carr, the Home Secretary, announced today that the Government was setting up a board to help resettle the Asians with British passports who are being expelled from Uganda.

YONKERS, Aug. 18 -- Any lingering doubt that Armbro Nesbit is the best of this season's crop of 2-year-old pacers vanished tonight at Yonkers Raceway, as Duncan McDonald drove the Bye Bye Byrd-Armbro Impel colt to a three-quarter length victory over Steady Airliner in the first division of the ninth annual Lawrence B. Sheppard Pace.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Although his efforts to reform the delegate selection rules of the Republican National Convention and to insert some liberal planks in the party's platform were unsuccessful, Senator Jacob K. Javits insisted this week that he was not feeling lonely on the left flank of his party.

Intelligence reports indicate that there is a sharp split within the Algerian government over how to deal with expatriate American members of the Black Panther party after a $1-million ransom airline hijacking July 31.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The House voted today to clear the way for 2,000 Japanese-Americans to regain $4.5-million in family savings that the Government confiscated three decades ago.

TORONTO, Aug. 18 -- It's as if an original Michelangelo masterpiece had to prove it's superior to the forged copy. In the hollow quiet of Maple Leaf Gardens, most of the National Hockey League's best players were practicing today, their skates scraping on the milk-white ice, the puck thudding off their sticks, their shouts muffled in the empty arena. Ordinarily, they would be enjoying the last few weeks before reporting to their teams' training camps.

Lincoln Center's mostly successful summertime festival, which closes tonight with a performance of the Mass in B minor of Bach, took measures Thursday night to keep the balances tipped in favor of Mozart. The Caterpillar Tractor Company continued in July the high momentum of the second quarter, with the best sales and earnings for any month in the history of the company, according to a spokesman who commented yesterday on the results.

RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 18 -- Gen. Mohammed Oufkir, the late Defense Minister who was long considered a mainstay of the Moroccan monarchy, was named by the Government tonight as the man who led the assassination attempt against King Hassan II on Wednesday.

MUNICH, West Germany, Aug, 18 -- A group of black American track-and-field athletes denounced Rhodesia's participation in the Olympic Games today and warned that if Rhodesia is allowed to compete, "We will take a united stand with our African brothers."
A man cycles casually up to a United Air Lines jet at the Reno International Airport, boards with an army carbine rifle under his jacket and succeeds in commandeering the plane.

TOKYO, Aug. 18 (UPI) -The Japanese Government, trying to cut back clouds of pollution that blanket urban areas each summer, announced plans today for strict standards on auto emissions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The 10-term Arizona Representative who is chairman of the Republican Platform Committee, John Jacob Rhodes, is described as the perfect choice for the subdued ceremonials in Miami Beach, a man for whom "flamboyant" would be the least appropriate adjective.
HANOVER, N. H. -- President Pompidou is worrying about the French language. He is said to have appointed fifteen special committees to find French alternatives to English words.

SEATTLE, Aug 18 -- A middle-aged man pedaled a bicycle with a rifle across the handlebars into the Reno Municipal Airport this morning, hijacked a jetliner to Seattle by way of Canada, received a $1-million ransom after holding the plane for 13 hours, and then was shot and captured by the F.B.I.

VIENNA, Aug. 18 (AP) -The Czechoslovak Communist party leader, Gustav Husak, said today that "no rigged and unlawful political trials are taking place or are being prepared" in Czechoslovakia.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 18 -- Henry A. Kissinger concluded nearly six hours of talks with President Nguyen Van Thieu and departed for Tokyo today, leaving diplomatic observers as much in the dark as ever about what his trip here had signified.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The White House issued a rebuttal today to charges made by Sargent Shriver, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, that President Nixon "blew" an opportunity to end the Vietnam war in 1969.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- President Nixon has named eight persons from the art, entertainment and television fields to the National Council on the Arts, which advises on the distribution of millions of dollars of Federal funds to encourage and support cultural endeavors in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- The Senate's Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, suggested today that the United States and China cooperate in restoring Prince Norodom Sihanouk to power in Cambodia.

Stock prices rallied modestly yesterday after registering three moderate declines in a row. These declines were regarded by many Wall Street analysts as a normal consolidation process that followed the strong Monday performance carrying several market averages to record levels.

State Supreme Court Justice Murray T. Feiden will be billed for New York cigarette taxes, interest and penalties, as a result of his having ordered cigarettes by mail from North Carolina, a state tax official said last night.

Murphy said yesterday that the police would make a "new effort" against major gangsters by "getting every patrolman to observe and report on the movements of organized-crime figures -- where they live, where they function, where they do business -- on a day-to-day basis.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Longshoremen all over the country today rebuffed attempts by militant shop stewards to prolong the three-week-old national dock strike and voted to resume work.

A FRIEND of mine who is more or less determined to become an actor frequently recites his career as if he had already lived it. It begins extravagantly with instantaneous success in his first film and proceeds from there along a twisting course of scandal, disappointment, alcoholism, emotional bankruptcy, and creative decadence ending with the inevitable suicide and posthumous acclaim.

SHANGHAI -- A full generation after English went out of fashion along Nanking Road, it's back again. Wait for a second wave of carts, and their riders in turn pick up the refrain: "Hello! How are you? Goodby!"

The New York City Opera, slipping up on us before sunburns and August have faded, opens its fall season on Wednesday night with Beverly Sills in the title role of Donizetti's "Maria Stuarda."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (Reuters) -- The Algerian Government today turned over to Delta Air Lines $1-million in ransom recovered from an airliner hijacking this month, State Department officials said.

Long overdue is the first partial solution to the skyjacker phenomenon. In his recent letter, Dr. Martin W. Oster correctly suggests identification of each and every traveler before boarding (I would modify this to make it apply only to those over 18).

KEY BI5CAYNE, Fla., Aug. 23 -- President Nixon signed today legislation increasing the pensions of the widows of Supreme Court Justices from $5,000 to $10,000 annually.

DETROIT, Aug. 23 -- New car dealers reported the mid-August daily car-selling rate jumped 12 per cent from a year ago. And the American Motors Corporation announced that it would add 300 workers and step up its production pace for small cars.
Unemployment in New York State in July totaled 545,000, or 6.5 per cent of the work force, the highest for the month since 1958, the State Department of Labor reported yesterday.

Two Brooklyn teen-agers who were convicted of murder last April have won a new trial because subsequent investigation by a detective prompted District Attorney Eugene Gold to question the "positive" identification by a key prosecution witness.

ROME, Aug. 23 -- Police sources said today that controls over Arab embassies here had been tightened in the last few days on suspicion that some had been involved in illegal activities.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 23 -- Bobby Fischer of the United States and Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union drew the 17th game of the world championship chess match today, and it is still not clear to many observers here whether this was a result of a blunder by Spassky or whether he went for the draw because of dangerous complications.

A car fell onto Penn Central tracks in the Fordham section of the Bronx early yesterday, causing delays and cancellations on the Harlem and New Haven lines.

PARIS, Aug. 23 - French efforts to organize Western Europe against America's international economic policy were pressed today in several forms. Indications were that Paris was meeting stiffening resistance from its European partners.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 23 -- "Never had a back who intercepted as many passes as Chris Farasopoulos does in practice," said an admiring Weeb Ewbank recently. WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -Ralph Nader charged today that the Civil Aeronautics Board was a "racially and sexually secluded bureaucracy" and he called for the resignation of its chairman.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- In a rapid shift on a politically tempestuous issue, the American public now appears to strongly favor full liberalization of laws that restrict abortions.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) -- President Nixon has ordered all Federal Government departments to end any systems of quotas for the hiring of Negroes or other minority group members.
WASHINGTON -- In the Japanese-style living room of the McGovern residence in Washington, 26-year-old Susan McGovern Rowen was bouncing her pixieish 7-month-old son, Matthew, on her lap.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 24 -- City, state and Onondaga County policemen, armed with 55 warrants had arrested 38 men and women by late today in what was described by the District Attorney as the biggest single heroin roundup in the history of the county.
A three-judge constitutional court yesterday rejected a directive by the state's Social Services Commissioner banning Medicaid payments to hospitals for women who elect to undergo abortions.

About four dozen of the 2,700 people who own shares in Nathan's Famous, Inc. -the restaurant company that has grown from a Coney Island hot dog stand to a chain that sells half a million pounds of frogs' legs a year -- met in Times Square yesterday, and several were terribly unhappy.
A merger and a potential acquisition crossed ad alley yesterday, indicating that the summer lull has its moments of activity.

MANILA, Aug. 24 -- President Ferdinand Marcos said today it would be a policy of his government to give "just and fair" compensation to Americans who would be required to abide by a Supreme Court ruling made last week and surrender ownership of land in the Philippines acquired since Philippine independence.
Wall Street was predictably alarmed and apprehensive yesterday over a proposal of a House subcommittee to abolish fixed commission rates on securities transactions.
While the Giants pondered their Game Plan yesterday for Sunday's football meeting with the New England Patriots, the team's Travel Plan glided along smoothly on a trajectory arranged months ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Retail beef and pork prices increased to record highs in July, raising over-all food costs to a new peak. But there were signs that the situation could ease if retailers passed along recent reductions in costs.

The American two-party system, for which there is no constitutional provision, may have to be scrapped. The nomination of George McGovern to oppose Richard M. Nixon for the Presidency proves that the system no longer works to check and balance the major factional forces of our society.

DETROIT, Aug. 24 -- A court-ordered plan to begin busing schoolchildren between Detroit and its suburbs was effectively blocked today when a higher court said that it would not be able to rule on an appeal before schools opened on Sept. 6.

President Nixon's acceptance speech to the Republican National Convention was an extraordinary address for an incumbent to deliver. Instead of expounding the accomplishments of his own Administration and explaining how he plans to extend and improve upon them in the next four years, Mr. Nixon devoted most of his energies to calling upon the electorate to fear Senator McGovern and the Democrats.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 24 (AP) -- South Vietnamese combat deaths reported by Saigon in the 20 weeks of the North Vietnamese offensive exceed 10 per cent of the acknowledged toll for more than a decade of the Indochina war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) -- The baking industry asked the Cost of Living Council today to authorize an immediate increase in bread prices -- even for companies exceeding Federal profit-control guidelines -to offset rising flour costs they attributed to sales of American wheat to the Soviet Union.

The nation's major banks, as anticipated, started yesterday to increase their minimum interest charges on loans to their most credit-worthy customers to 5 1/2 per cent from 5 1/4 per cent effective today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) -- The Kennedy Center canceled its first musical comedy production of the season today in a dispute with the District of Columbia Federation of Musicians.
Stocks backed down along a broad front yesterday on the American Stock Exchange in the sharpest price drop in over a month. Trading volume remained moderate.

The Reynolds Metals Company said yesterday that a shipment of Soviet equipment was en route to a company facility in Sheffield, Ala., for the pouring of aluminum ingot by an electromagnetic process.

Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama was 53 years old yesterday, and celebrated in a party at his office in Montgomery -- his first visit to the state's capitol since being shot down and partly paralyzed at a rally in Maryland in May.

The increase in the prime lending rate of the nation's commercial banks to 5 1/2 per cent from 5 1/4 per cent -- which was kicked off on Thursday by the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York -- started to spread yesterday, as had been anticipated.

The general's battle strategy may determine tonight's outcome of the North American Soccer League championship game between the New York Cosmos and the St. Louis Stars, at Hofstra Field in Hempstead, L. I., at 8 o'clock.

KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 23 -- The 19 puzzling months of President Idi Amin's reign have been marked by the disappearances of about a dozen prominent officials, the murder of two Americans, perilous economic problems, an erratic foreign policy and tribal strife within the Uganda Army that has left thousands of soldiers dead.

WASHINGTON -- The American public is entitled to know what the President's current plan is to end the war in Vietnam. As the election campaign heats up, Henry Kissinger has held highly publicized secret talks in Paris and in Saigon. An impression that real progress toward peace is being made is being created.

All sorts of promising possibilities came apart for the New York Yankees midway through the second game at Yankee Stadium last night, and by splitting a double-header with the Kansas City Royals they wound up losing ground instead of gaining it in the American League's Eastern Division.

Gary Hart, Senator George McGovern's campaign manager, said yesterday that the Democratic Presidential candidate would clarify his economic policies next Tuesday but would make no major modifications of those policies.
Remember that fine old car, the LaSalle 8, that General Motors number that was just one baby step removed from a Cadillac?

LIMA, Peru, Aug. 25 -- In less than three years of association,, the Andean Common Market countries have managed to increase trade among themselves almost twofold, shaking some early skeptics. But this week the five countries really confounded their critics by reaching agreement on how to become a cooperative for industrial development and a sort of international mutual-aid society.

YONKERS, Aug. 25 -- Keystone Pat unleashed an 0:58 4/5 final half and easily captured the $20,000 Atlantic Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The 5-year-old Tar Heel - Pebble Adios bay led through nearly all of the eight furlongs, as John Hayes Jr. steered his father's pacer to a 1 3/4-length victory over Dangerous Wave.

The police captured two AWOL infantrymen charged with holding up a methadone clinic on the East Side yesterday morning, but two other robbers escaped after a wild chase across the Manhattan Bridge and through the Fort Greene housing project in Brooklyn.
The stock market finished lower yesterday for the second consecutive session although the decline was not so sharp as Thursday's.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 25 -- President Nixon turned his attention to the business of the Presidency today after a grueling cross-country political tour that revealed much about the likely tone, techniques and content of his re-election campaign.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Horace Stoneham, president of the San Francisco Giants, said tonight that the pitcher, Juan Marichal, had been "routinely placed on waivers" along with several other players he did not identify.
More than $2-billion of stocks and bonds are known to be lost or stolen, and the real figure more likely may turn out to be $10-billion.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department, at a time when consumers are paying record high prices for groceries, says Americans should hoard food in case of atomic attack.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 25 -- The national titleholders of Japan and Colombia yielded today as Virginia Wade of England and Laurie Fleming of Florida reached the final round of the $15,000 73d annual Pennsylvania lawn-tennis tournament at Merion Cricket club.
Walter J. Rauscher, senior vice president of American Airlines, Inc., has been elected an executive vice president.
One wintry Sunday a few years ago, David T. Smith -- then an executive of an educational materials company -- experienced homeowner's trauma. His heating system whimpered to a halt and died.
BUFFALO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The New York Telephone Company is designing, ordering and installing equipment to bill customers for directory-assistance calls, a company spokesman said today.

DETROIT, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Detroit Edison Company has announced net income of $69,498,000, or $1.94 a share, for the fiscal year ended July 31, up from the $59,885,000, or $1.87 a share, reported for the period a year ago.

The dollar was strong in relation to several key European currencies in quiet preweekend trading in the New York foreign exchange market yesterday. The German mark, the Swiss franc and the Dutch guilder all closed lower in relation to the United States currency, as did the Belgian franc and the Italian lira.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- A spokesman for the Roman Catholic Church challenged as "ambiguous" today a Gallup poll indicating that two-thirds of the public now favored liberalized abortion laws.

Connecticut Blue Cross yesterday was granted a 3.28 per cent rate increase for most direct-payment subscriber policies, less than half the size it had requested. State Insurance Commissioner Paul B. Altermatt said the Blue Cross request for an 8.5 per cent rate increase was excessive.

EASTCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- Cindy and Stephen Ferro of Forest Hill Field Club won the 38th annual metropolitan sister-brother championship of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association by one stroke today with a card of 36, 39 -- 75 in the selected-drive, alternate-stroke event at Leewood Golf Club. Miss Ferro is the New Jersey women's state champion.

Senator McGovern's Presidential campaign is swinging into high gear after a month of post-convention fumbles and floundering, but it would be an exaggeration to pretend that his speeches this week contributed vastly to clarifying major issues.
TRENTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Nine guards were injured, none of them seriously, while breaking up a fight between prisoners in the recreation yard at Trenton State Prison tonight.
A Bronx keypunch repairman has won the first round of his battle against the city for sending him to Rikers Island prison rather than to a civil jail when he could not make an alimony payment.

The recent articles by Linda Charlton and Iver Peterson have performed a much needed public service by pointing out that there is still no licensing by the state for psychotherapists and psychoanalysts. One reason licensing has been so difficult to achieve for these professions is that there is as yet no professional doctoral degree in the field.

A belief is gaining credence in this country -- that a total ban on or extremely stringent control over firearms, particularly handguns, would reduce violent crime. This premise is based on two incorrect assumptions -- that all firearms owners are criminals, that all crimes are committed with legally purchased weapons.

Bob Grim, the former Minnesota Viking's wide-receiver, is now a full-fledged member of the Giants. Although the 6-foot 200-pounder has been in the New York team's camp for almost two weeks, he hadn't been interested in anything Wellington Mara, the president of the Giants, had to offer.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- A bank owned by the United Mine Workers acted to prevent W. A. Boyle, president of the union, from being sent to jail by extending him credit to allow posting of a bond.

MOSCOW, Aug. 25 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, has flown to the virgin lands in Soviet central Asia to spur the crucial grain harvest in Kazakhstan amid reports that Moscow's foreign-grain purchases would be even larger than had been expected.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Aug. 24 -- Not everybody wants to go up in the world, but everybody here at the first international conference on the high-rise building was prepared to examine the consequences of going up.
RENO, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- Robb Heady, 22 years old, was sentenced today to 30 years in prison for hija. cking a New York-to-San Francisco jetliner in Reno June 2 and holding it for $200,000 ransom.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- After a bitter attack on the Soviet Union and India, the Peking Government today cast its first veto in the Security Council to bar Bangladesh from membership in the United Nations.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- When Senator George McGovern of South Dakota stepped from the wings and hurried toward the speaker's rostrum, not one of the more than 4,000 delegates to the American Legion's annual convention applauded.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- Mrs. Virginia H. Knauer, special assistant to the President for consumer affairs, dismissed today a charge by a committee of the American Medical Association that her office has used "pressure tactics" to get cosmetic manufacturers to provide safer products.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 25 -- Indian and Pakistani officials met today and grappled with the issues imperiling the peace agreement the two countries signed on July 3.
The newly installed president of the American Correctional Association spent the better part of her youth in the tiny town of Madison, Ohio, in close association with known criminals.

ALBANY, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- Legislative leaders today named six lawmakers, two conservationists and the head of the state's Offtrack Pari-Mutuel Betting Commission to a newly-created panel to develop a comprehensive energy policy for the state.

Shouting its theme, "Our rights and nothing less!," a Women's March for Equality moved down Fifth Avenue yesterday, swelling steadily to a crowd estimated at 3,000 to 5,000 for a rally that filled 40th Street from Fifth Avenue to the Avenue of the Americas.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The Food and Drug Administration, in a new use of a 10-year-old law, moved today to bring all blood collection and processing centers under Federal control.

Columbia University, under mounting pressure from civil liberties groups, the State Human Rights Division and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, agreed yesterday to extend for 10 days the jobs of the 30 maids who were to have been laid off starting this morning.

MANILA, Aug. 25 -- United States citizens in the Philippines seem assured of having two years in which to transfer to Filipino ownership lands affected by a Supreme Court ruling last week invalidating ownership of commercial and residential land purchased by Americans since the Philippines gained independence in 1946.

The organization described therein is nothing but an "oxymoronic" fraud being perpetrated on a currently divided Democratic party. The correct title should be "New Republicans for Nixon."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- A California engineer has invented a method of playing golf that he says provides for maximum driving and a minimum amount of walk ing. Theodore B. Johnson of Burlingame was granted Patent 3,685,832 this week for what is trademarked Fore and Aft Golf.

In front of City Hall are six trees in concrete tubs dying for lack of water. The patrolman was very sympathetic but helpless. He said it was the Parks Department's job. He told me to write a letter.

Platinum futures prices fluctuated sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. They were up $3.50 an ounce at the opening, dropped $7 below the close of the day before and closed 70 cents to $1.50 an ounce lower.
A Queens jewelry store owner shot and killed a holdup man yesterday as he attempted to flee by taxi with his loot.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 25 -- The unbeaten-skipper list was reduced to six today after 216 boats sailed on the third day of Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's 40th annual Race Week.

Stocks on the American Stock Exchange continued to decline yesterday in slightly lighter trading.

The greening of jazz on the Upper East Side, which has for the most part, been limited so far to an incursion of jazz pianists, has now been broadened to include a cornetled quartet. The cornetist is Ruby Braff, and the group plays the cleanest, most directly communicative type of mainstream jazz.

DETROIT, Aug. 25 -- Cadillac Motor Car Division recalled today 3,878 of its biggest 1972 sedans and commercial vehicles, including ambulances and hearses, to replace axle shafts that could break and cause rear wheels to come off.

The Jet Capital Corporation of New York assumed control yesterday of Texas International Airlines, Inc., as part of a $35-million refinancing and equity program. In line with the move Francisco A. MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 25 -- -- Vice President Agnew received a warm and spirited reception at the Veterans of Foreign Wars Convention here today during a speech devoted solely to the controversy over amnesty for draft evaders.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 30 -- Still playing his cards close to the chest, Weeb Ewbank, the Jets' coach and general manager, announced today the names of the seven players he had cut Monday in order to get down to the league requirement of 49 by yesterday.

The operators of the three Times Square theaters raided on Tuesday for allegedly promoting obscenity defied the police yesterday and were back in action with live and filmed sex shows, just as if nothing had happened.

SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 30 -- Red Cross delegates from North and South Korea agreed today to "make every effort to dissolve the agonies of the families dispersed in the North and the South and thus lay a stepping stone for unification of the fatherland."
The police seized about 400 pounds of marijuana, estimated to be worth $250,000, in Bayside Queens, last night and arrested two Queens residents on charges of possessing narcotics.

Ugly yet ornamental in its fashion, the New York fire escape traditionally is all things to all people, depending on their age and inclination: a sleeping porch, a dining terrace, a sunning deck, a play area.
The central Board of Education yesterday overturned, by a vote of 4 to 1, the recent dismissal of 20 teachers by the Community School Board of District 9 in the Bronx.

The volume of help-wanted advertising rose sharply in July, according to data gathered by The Conference Board. The index on such advertising, as measured by the board, rose last month to 103 per cent of the 1967 base period, a gain of 7 index points over the June level, and 18 points over the level of July, 1971.
MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 30 -- Why does an ordinarily sane man subject his body to the tortures of longdistance running?

Spokesmen for the Police Department and for major retail stores cautioned yesterday that unduly harsh antipeddling laws would do little to discourage the thousands of peddlers who have recently taken to hawking their wares illegally on the streets.

Wilbur Wood, the lefthanded knuckleball pitcher for the Chicago White Sox, was too good yesterday for his own good. "His knuckleball was dancing so much it was moving out of the strike zone," said Manager Chuck Tanner.
Eleven more restaurants and other food establishments were cited by the Health Department yesterday for serious violations of the city Health Code.

C. Schmidt Sons, the nation's 13th largest beer company, is moving its account to Rosenfeld, Sirowitz Lawson from Ted Bates Co. Its billings were less than $3-million last year, but there's talk of an increase to about $3.7-million for 1973.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 30 -- The South Vietnamese Government announced today that issues of three more daily newspapers had been seized for criticizing the Government and that a court had sentenced the alleged perpetrators of 60 other press violations.

SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 30--North Korea's chief delegate to the Red Cross talks is a veteran diplomat who once served as Deputy Foreign Minister. But unlike his South Korean counterpart, he does not have much experience in Red Cross work.
Silver future prices rose markedly yesterday in steppedup trading on the Commodity Exchange here.

Both the principle of scatter-site housing and the proper institutions for urban and suburban development are undergoing a test in Westchester County. Both issues are posed in relatively pure terms which should not be submerged by the pressures to demagoguery of an election campaign.

MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The United States, surviving one of its toughest tests in 36 years of Olympic basketball, turned on the power in the closing minutes tonight to subdue Brazil, 61-54, and remain undefeated in four games here.
A move toward more nonsecurities business and away from public agency activity has been disclosed in a recent survey of brokerage firms, the American Stock Exchange reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -The Association of State Correctional Administrators proposed today uniform prison guidelines that detail procedures for handling disciplinary problems and racial strife and that would give inmates increasing visiting and mail privileges and more access to the news media.

Numbered Account gave a splendid account of herself in the $27,700 Maskette Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. Almost falling forward shortly after a fine start, the handsome filly owned by Ogden Phipps steadied herself and went on to win the one-mile race for older fillies and mares.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- If the Presidential election of 1972 is to have a turning point, Senator George McGovern may have reached it this week. With the conventions over and the traditional Labor Day campaign inaugural at hand, the South Dakota Democrat has given evidence in the last two days that he is ready to begin an affirmative effort to close the long gap between himself and President Nixon.

Winter's winds have convinced me of the need to wear a hat. Summer is something else again. But hats are habit-forming; soon, being without one is akin to being naked. So early this summer I visited a hat store to survey the scene. Out I walked with a glorious white straw boater.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -The Center for Auto Safety accused the General Motors Corporation today of concealing what it termed a "life-anddeath" safety defect in more than 280,000 Cadillacs of the 1959 and 1960 model years.

A huge mural publicizing events in New York City parks was dedicated yesterday in Times Square. The mural, designed by the artist Romare Bearden, covers three sides of a 60-foot tower and a 102-foot by 40foot billboard on the west side of Seventh Avenue near 42d Street.

With Labor Day nearing and reminding them of the capricious weather to come, they stream out of the Manhattan skyscrapers -- thirsting for a final draught of the late summer sun, carrying their lunch in brown paper bags.

WASHINGTON -- Secretary of Agriculture Earl Butz has said that if the organic farming advocates had their way, fifty million Americans would starve. Henry J. Heinz 2d, chairman of H. J. Heinz Company, recently wrote: "We are a nation of nutritional illiterates. Food faddism advocates are persuading thousands to adopt foolish and costly eating habits."

Let's fervently hope that next year the Lincoln Center Community/Street Festival requires diligent rehearsing by every unit in the use of stage microphones -- not a herculean feat -- for simple, outdoor projection.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -The Supreme Court was urged today to decide later this year the dispute between two Democratic factions over which delegates should have represented California at the party's national convention in July.

Clifford Irving was hardly settled at the Federal prison farm in Lewisburg, Pa., when Howard R. Hughes, the billionaire recluse, made one of his rare private appearances. Mr. Irving began a two-andone-half year sentence Monday for his hoax autobiography of Mr. Hughes.

Premier Kakuei Tanaka's meeting with President Nixon in Hawaii in preparation for his visit to Peking next month marks a major turning point in the postwar history of Japan. After a quarter-century of American tutelage and miraculous economic growth, Japan is moving out on the world stage as an independent power.
The stock market broke its four-session losing streak yesterday by registering a small advance in continued dull trading.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz charged a securities firm and its president yesterday with failing to make timely delivery of stock and failing to remit dividends promptly to customers.
Prices slipped again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. It was the seventh straight session in which declines outnumbered advances.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI) -- The Army awarded contracts totaling $153.2-million today to the Boeing Company and Sikorsky Aircraft for development of a new, larger and more reliable troop-carrying helicopter to replace the Huey troop carrier used in Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI) -- Cattlemen, upset at the recent drop in cattle prices, today attributed their troubles in large part to Government meddling.

STRAFFORD, Vt., Aug. 30 -A systematic search of a 1,000-acre wooded area here has failed to find a trace of a retired Harvard professor of surgery who disappeared Monday evening, the state police reported tonight.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Aug. 30 -- State Senator Eugene N. Zeigler launched today his campaign as the Democratic nominee seeking to unseat Senator Strom Thurmond, a Republican, by pledging to unify the South Carolina Democratic party.

SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 30 -- The chief South Korean delegate to the Red Cross talks with North Korea, which opened in Pyongyang today, is a former career diplomat with 10 years of experience as a Red Cross worker.

MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 30 -- In possibly the closest gold-medal finish in Olympic swimming history, Gunnar Larsson of Sweden beat Tim McKee of the United States by two-thousands of a second tonight in the 400-meter individual medley.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -There is about their modest suite of offices a here-today, gone-tomorrow quality, a Spartan air of transience that suggests pragmatism rather than passion.

Midtown motorists guilty of "spillback" blocking intersections and crosswalks -- will get "feedback" from the police in the form of summonses in a new traffic campaign starting Sept. 12. Each summons could result in a $15 fine.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 30 -- A British soldier on foot patrol in the Roman Catholic Lower Falls Road area of Belfast was killed today by a single shot from a sniper.
NEWARK, Aug. 30 -- The United States Attorney's office is trying to pry open a secret bank account in Switzerland by way of Chicago.

In refusing to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate the Watergate break-in and other alleged Republican irregularities in campaign financing, President Nixon has noted that the F.B.I., the Justice Department, the House Banking Committee and the General Accounting Office are already conducting various investigations as are the White House itself, Clark MacGregor, chairman of the Nixon campaign, and Maurice Stans, the Nixon finance chairman.

PACIFIC PALISADES, Aug. 30--Ernie Holtby is usually out early, dragging his metal strainer across the beach, sifting the sand for the treasures left buried by yesterday's crowds. In the mists of morning, dressed all in gray, he looks like some giant sea bird, pecking away in counterpoint to the rhythms of the surf.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Beef cattle prices dropped for the first time in four months, but increases for hogs and other products helped to send over-all farm prices up 1 per cent to another record in the month ended Aug. 15, the Agriculture Department reported today.

The Commonwealth United Corporation, a conglomerate that earlier this year got its stockholders' approval to change the name to Iota Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that $32-million, or about 40 per cent, of its outstanding debentures had been deposited in exchange for securities of Seeburg Industries, Inc.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) -Five women taken hostage during a restaurant holdup were rescued when two of their three abductors were shot to death by the police today after a 120-mile-an-hour chase.

MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The International Amateur Athletic Federation, in another turnabout, banned the Catapole from Olympic pole vault competition today following an official protest by East Germany.
Mrs. Joseph Gregory, better known among the show set as Mamie, has had a variety of dogs over the years, of which many have been champions. "I was brought up in a doggy family," she said.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 20 (AP) -India has told Pakistan again that the 91,000 Pakistanis she is holding as prisoners of war will be returned only with the direct participation and consent of Bangladesh, Swaran Singh, External Affairs Minister, said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- A Government cancer expert said today that a seeming Soviet advance in leukemia research had raised new hope for developing ways to prevent, or improve treatment of, leukemia and certain other malignancies.

MANILA, Aug. 30 -- Shipment of relief goods for victims of the devastating floods that inundated central Luzon last month brought a Chinese Communist and a Chinese Nationalist ship into the port of Manila today at roughly the same time.

MANILA, Aug. 30 -- Shipment of relief goods for victims of the devastating floods that inundated central Luzon last month brought a Chinese Communist and a Chinese Nationalist ship into the port of Manila today at roughly the same time.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 30 (AP) -- A suit was filed in United States District Court here yesterday by former Gov. Winthrop Rockefeller of Arkansas for a $105,115 refund in Federal excise taxes paid by Petit Jean Air Service.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 30 (UPI) -- An extortionist demanded $100,000 and threatened to blow up the terminal at Gen. Billy Mitchell Field today if the money was not paid. "Either pay up or blow up," the extortionist said in a note attached to a device found at the terminal.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 30--Chief Justice George F. Boney of the State Supreme Court drowned in a sailing accident today at Cheri Lake, 50 miles north of here. He was 42 years old.
With the resumption of the 20th game of the world chess championship match, Bobby Fischer was on the defensive.

ATMORE, Ala., Aug. 30 (AP) -- A guard at the exit gate of the Holman maximum -security unity thought he was preparing to let two nuns out of the prison today when he noticed inmate shoes underneath their religious habits.
Thousands of retarded children and adults strolled hand in hand with volunteer companions in what was called a "One to One Festival" on the Sheep Meadow in Central Park yesterday.

NEW LONDON, Aug. 30 -Tomorrow will be the last day of its life, and then the Crocker House will be ready for the wreckers or for the credulous who imagine that an old hotel in the heart of an old town can live again.
A new research report from a brokerage house has just been published that recommends publicly owned advertising agencies in general and a few of them in particular.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -Pentagon sources said today that three small craft, recently modified in such a way that they could conceivably be used to drag mine-clearing gear, had tied up near a 136foot Chinese minesweeper in Haiphong harbor.

Iron bars do not a home make, or something like that, is a concept that inspired Leonard Gruen, a sculptor (who also works as a steamfitter), to create attractive window pieces that keep out intruders.

BERLIN, Aug. 30 -- In a joyful mood of accomplishment, Germans and Americans today celebrated the opening of a new highway formally linking Berlin's tiny exclave of Steinstucken for the first time with the city's American sector.

Labor Day Weekend is a dry run for a nuclear attack. Millions of New Yorkers evacuate the city and attempt to live by their wits in the boondocks. Once they have survived the maniacal traffic, the biggest problem they face is finding a decent place to eat.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 30 -The Brazilian Government has cracked down hard on the single major newspaper in the country that has been consistently defying vague and largely unspecified censorship rules.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -North Vietnam leveled scorn today at President Nixon's latest troop-withdrawal announcement and declared once again that a Vietnam settlement was impossible until the United States ended both its support of the Saigon Government and its military actions against the north.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 30 -Moscow Dynamo, the 10-time soccer champion of the Soviet Union, toyed with the New York Cosmos in the second half here tonight and defeated the North American Soccer League champions, 2-1.

The oppression of Soviet Jews seeking repatriation to Israel has taken a new turn for the worse with the Soviet Government's development of a graduated exit fee seale according to the applicant's educational background. The Soviet Union has in recent years required payment of 900 rubles by each Jew emigrating.
The United States Steel Corporation has appointed J. D. McCall Jr., to the new post of group vice president, with responsibility for the management of five general operating divisions.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Mark Pfeil of Palos Verdes, Calif., and Greg Stuhler of Atlanta carded twounder-par 69's to lead a parade of lesser known players and share the first-round lead of the United States Amateur golf championship today.

BEREM, Israel, Aug. 26 -- The distance between this hilltop and Gush-Halav is a mile or two, down through the valley and up the next hill. But for the people who used to live here, the gap is measured in time, not space, and in the intensity of their sense of loss.
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 30 (UPI) -- President Nixon signed today the Rural Development Act of 1972 but said he regretted that Congress had not passed his special revenue-sharing program instead.
OLATHE, Kan., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Kansas' system of financing elementary and high school education is unconstitutional, Judge Phillip L. Woodworth of the Johnson County District ruled today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 30 -- It has been five months since the North Vietnamese offensive began, and the fighting is now looking increasingly like a draw. The battles ignited by North Vietnam's Easter offensive are still raging, and others are likely before this phase of the war is ended.
A state law depriving unwed mothers of welfare aid if they refuse to name the missing fathers of their children has been declared invalid by Judge Murray I. Gurfein in Federal Court here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -The General Accounting Office, which last week reported finding several "apparent violations" of Federal campaign finance laws by the Committee for the Re-election of the President, said today that it had begun an investigation of Senator George McGovern's campaign finance records.

Parallel suits have been filed in State Supreme Court to stop the use of home-relief recipients in unpaid city jobs to work off their welfare checks. The suits were announced yesterday by the municipal employes' union and the New York Civil Liberties Union.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Aug. 30 -- A 127-foot-high steel pedestal will be tested here this week as space engineers prepare launching facilities for Skylab, the nation's first space station and the next manned space project after Apollo.

After yielding six goals in an intrasquad game, Tony Esposito should be ready for anything Saturday night when Team Canada, the National Hockey League stars, opens its series against the Russians at Montreal. Esposito is to start in goal for the team, whose 35-man roster will be cut to 19 players tomorrow.

At the request of President Nixon, but with considerable reluctance, the state Republican party agreed yesterday to permit the Conservative party to put the President on the Conservative line on the Nov. 7 ballot.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Curt Knight's 24-yard field goal gave the Washington Red-skins a 27-24 victory over the Miami Dolphins in a National Football League preseason game tonight.

The Knicks, looking to the future when their aging, talented front line is phased out, signed Tom Riker, their 22-year-old No. 1 draft choice yesterday. Riker, a high school all-American at St. Dominic's in Oyster Bay, L. I., and a 19.6 scorer last season at South Carolina, received a three-year no-cut contract.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Sept. 1 (AP) -- American air strikes against North Vietnam destroyed a huge ammunition dump Wednesday and set a fuel depot ablaze, the United States command reported yesterday.

UAL, Inc., the parent of United Air Lines, continued its upward climb in earnings with a 24.8 per cent increase in July net to $8,508,000 for its airline subsidiary from $6,817,000 in the year-earlier month, the company reported yesterday.

Recent comments by President Nixon and Senator McGovern revive hope that a bipartisan push for welfare reform may yet achieve success in this Congress. The Republican platform adopted an ambiguous attitude toward welfare reform, praising the President's initiative but denouncing the principle of a guaranteed minimum income which underlies that initiative. Mr. Nixon, however, in his acceptance speech and again in his news conference before departing for Hawaii reasserted his devotion to the basic concept.

DALLAS, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- The Dallas Chapparrals, citing the need for a white face, have dumped two black all-stars, Donnie Freeman and John Brisker, in an attempt to bolster fan support by luring more white customers.

Eugene V. Rostow insists (letter Aug. 22) that the "real issue" about Vietnam in the campaign is that responsible leaders of opinion should not rewrite history. Ironically, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, 1966-69, who served with Secretary of State Rusk, does indeed rewrite history when he contends that the nation committed itself to the Vietnam policy through the SEATO Treaty.

GENEVA, Aug. 31 -- The Swiss Government announced today the resignation of its top arms procurement official in protest over the delay in approving the purchase of American-built fighter-bombers in preference to French ones for the Swiss Air Force.
Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

The construction of the American Press Institute's new building in Reston, Va., is expected to begin this month, the institute announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Spokesmen for President Nixon and Senator George McGovern traded criticisms today on the subject of the Senator's new tax reform and welfare programs, and the Senator challenged the President to debate the issues on network television.

I believe that William V. Shannon's column in the Aug. 17 edition on Nixon wooing the Catholic vote contains a significant misunderstanding. In commenting on the Administration's support for the provision in the Carey-Mills Bill (H.R. 16141) which would provide a tax credit of $200 per pupil for tuition paid to private schools, he states that "a $200 tax credit is not going to save foundering parochial schools."
The New York Urban Coalition announced yesterday the election of Jack John Olivero as its senior vice president.
Regular Penn Central commuters who were forced to find other means of travel last Monday when a power failure cut all service from Grand Central Terminal will be able to get their money back.

Three Jewish organizations announced yesterday that they had filed a formal petition with Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner calling for an investigation of the appointment of Luis Fuente as superintendent of Community School District 1, on the Lower East Side.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass. -- It was late afternoon on a grey November day, with the east wind bringing the smell of wharves and ocean into the Boston streets. I walked southward on Boston Common down the Long Path quartering the sloping fields between Beacon Street and Boylston.
Donald C. Platten was elected president of the Chemical New York Corporation and its principal subsidiary, the Chemical Bank, it was announced yesterday.
Labor Day, the holiday for the nation's gainfully exhausted, beckons just ahead.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- If it were customary to see thousands of people seated on a broad red carpet more than a block long, no one would have been surprised at the opening of "The Old and the New" music festival at Kennedy Center last night.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A Stradivarius violin dating from the 1730's was auctioned here yesterday for $42,000, but its owner thinks the price was too low.

Sally Bowden's current dance interests are in musical interpretation. The impulse is so gut-traditional among dancers and has been ignored for so long that her presentations have an air of welcome revolution. Wednesday evening at the Construction Company Studio, 542 La Guardia Place, she created a playfully rhythmic cluster of dances around thirteen rock and Latin-rock songs.
BELFAST, Aug. 31 -- About 1,000 Roman Catholic families have ended their rent and tax strike In Londonderry, Northern Ireland's second largest city, the Londonderry Development Commission said today.
The last long summer weekend will have millions of metropolitan area drivers facing an assortment of highway problems.

The steep climb in short-term interest rates that dominated capital-market activity in the second half of August slowed to a crawl yesterday in light pre-holiday dealings. Bond rates, meanwhile, halted their more moderate advance.

Many dyed - in - the - wool New Yorkers feel the Labor Day weekend is the best of all possible times to stay in the city. The streets, movies and museums are empty, there is hardly any traffic, and the metropolis takes on the appearance of a small town.

MANILA, Aug. 31 -- Eviction as a flood-prevention measure of more than 100,000 squatters who live in shanties erected over the many waterways of Manila is proving to be a difficult and politically awkward operation for both the city and the national Government.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The campaign debates on the economy and the war sound as if the two sides disagreed about almost everything, but if you look at the human side of these two great questions, the fact is that they agree on a great many disagreeable facts.
Local 144 of the Service Employes Union threatened a sit-down strike by 450 members at 9 A.M. today at Polyclinic Hospital as a result of a representation dispute.
PATERSON, N. J., Aug. 31 -- The Great Falls Festival, a five-day fair, opened today on what, six weeks ago, was a dump covered by 60 feet of debris.

MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Tough Soviet wrestlers won five gold medals in the free-style finals today, but the United States made its best showing in Olympic history with three gold medals, two silvers and a bronze.

A Canadian scientist reported yesterday what was apparently the first evidence of contamination of food by a chemical that has been shown to cause pre-cancerous changes in rats when fed to the animals in levels 50 times higher than that found in some foods.

Mayor Lindsay spent part of the day in the Bronx yesterday, looking into police manpower problems, drug treatment (as exemplified in a small ambulatory center for former addicts) and the plight of elderly people.

George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, is unlikely to remain in his post long after the November election, according to knowledgeable H.U.D. officials. Mr. Romney has said he will stay on to work for the re-election of President Nixon.
ORLANDO, Fla., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Glenn W. Turner said today that he would split his legally embattled "Dare To Be Great" self-motivation concern into 500 companies and give them away if necessary.

In 1970 Chuck Ortleb had been leading a double life -- as a homosexual posing as a heterosexual -- for more than two years. Finally, he couldn't stand the deception any longer. So one evening, after he had attended a Gay Liberation meeting at the University of Kansas, where he was a student, he telephoned his parents long-distance.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- A magazine war is about to start in France. Ostensibly, it is a fight between publishers, but in fact it is an intricate round in the hidden struggle here between the existing power structure and its challengers.

SAIGON, Aug. 31 -- The United States command said today that five Americans were killed in action and three wounded last week, in the lowest casualty toll of any week since record-keeping began on Jan. 1, 1965.

The Illustrated World Encyclopedia, Inc., has made a settlement with Kenneth R. Cunningham and Robert D. Tomlinson, former officers of the Associated American Corporation that was purchased by Illustrated World Encyclopedia in November, 1971.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Department of Labor said today that it was taking steps to correct what its own investigation last year found to be "pervasive and substantial underutilization of minorities and women in the department."

The Natonal Broadcasting Company, which has televised the popular "Today" show" for the last 20 years and "The Tonight Show" for 18 years, plans to introduce a new, one-hour program, "Tomorrow," that will go on the air at 1 A.M., following "The Tonight Show."

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A Thai police lieutenant was arrested today in connection with a June 15 plane explosion over South Vietnam that killed his 7-year-old daughter and 80 other persons. Police spokesmen said that he had heavily insured the child before the flight.

The New York State Banking Board announced yesterday its reversal of two previous denials of acquisitions of two small upstate banks by major New York City bank holding companies. It acted on the recommendation of State Superintendent of Banks Harry W. Albright Jr.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Jewish leaders from more than 10 countries plan to meet in London next Monday to form a united front against the payment of the high fees asked by the Soviet Union for the emigration of educated Jews to Israel, a spokesman for the National Conference on Soviet Jews said today.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 31 (Agence France-Presse) -- India announced the outlawing today of all underground organizations of rebel Naga tribesmen on her northeastern border with Burma.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 31 -- Experts who watched Boris Spassky seal his 41st move tonight felt certain that a new world chess champion would be crowned tomorrow. Bobby Fischer, playing the black pieces in the 21st game of the series, had a very strong edge in the adjourned position, and little hope was offered for Spassky.
HONOLULU, Aug. 31 -- President Nixon and Premier Kakuci Tanaka of Japan began a two-day meeting here today in an effort to revitalize the United States' troubled alliance with Japan.

LELAND, Mich. -- In two previous Vietnam articles on this page, I discussed the options open to President Nixon. Briefly they were: (1) get out of Vietnam, (2) continue stalemate, (3) escalate the war, (4) Vietnamization. After a visit to Vietnam, I discussed Mr. Nixon's adoption of the Vietnamization program.

Exhibiting a trotter, complete with trainer-driver answering questions, distributing shopping bags and awarding lottery prizes was a vulgar appeal to the basest instincts of people who can ill afford to gamble.

MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- Everything about Olga Korbut of the Soviet Union is tiny except her talent as a gymnast, and that was big enough to win her two gold medels and one silver in individual competition at the 20th Olympics tonight.

The New York Yankees -- unseeded and unloved earlier in the summer -- charged out to August yesterday with a 7-0 victory over the Texas Rangers and headed into the homestretch of the baseball season in a four-way race for the American League's Eastern championship.

A three-judge Federal court in Brooklyn has issued a temporary restraining order that will assure continuation of sidewalk voter registration at least until September 15th. Without the judicial reprieve, tomorrow would have been the last day for this convenient form of registering new voters.
HOUSTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Alfred M. Worden, one of the three spacemen involved in the Apollo 15 stamp-cover dispute, has been transferred out of the astronaut office, officials said today.

Every day for the last two weeks Lincoln Center's plaza has been filled with 500 to 1,000 people participating in the free Community/Street Theater Festival. There have been senior citizens basking in the sunshine, young mothers with infants, people in wheelchairs, teen-agers of all descriptions and large groups of black children as young as 5.

With caustic words for American Embassy officials in Britain, whom they accused of failing to help them, some 140 tourists returned to New York yesterday after having been stranded, many without money, at London's Gatwick Airport for four nights.
NEWARK, Aug. 31 -- The Evening News, which announced on Tuesday that it was ceasing to publish, shut its doors today, printing its final afternoon editions after 88 years of publication?
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 31 -- They say that the camera doesn't lie, a fact that Joey Jackson, the sixth-round draft choice of the New York Jets can be thankful for this week.

SAGINAW, Mich., Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Wickes Corporation, a diversified company that has considerable interest in lumber and allied fields, said today it would discontinue manufacture of modular housing units but would continue producing the individual components for sale through its network of 285 lumber and building supply houses across the country.
