MT. KISCO, N. Y. -- Last year, Betty Hawkins earned $23 a day scrubbing other women's floors. Today, she still scrubs many of those same floors, but she's doing much better financially.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- With no agreement in sight on quotas for the coming year, delegates to the International Coffee Council recessed what was supposed to be their final meeting tonight to go into a round of private consultations between producing and consuming countries.
The New York Times will begin publishing a daily New Jersey edition on Sept. 14.
The Navy announced yesterday that it would permit a major revision of its controversial contract with Litton Industries for the construction of $1-billion worth of ships.

ANAHEIM, Aug. 31 (AP) -- California's Nolan Ryan fired his third straight shutout and ninth of the season as he stopped Detroit on three hits, 4-0, tonight and knocked the Tigers out of a first-place tie in the American League East.
DETROIT, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Auto production continued to rise this week as General Motors built up to full strength after a lengthy changeover, Automotive News reported today.
The Lindsay administration presented some high-ranking city officials yesterday in support of its bill to curb graffiti, before a poorly attended session of a 15-member City Council committee.

An agreement reached yesterday between a musicians' union local and the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington will permit "Pippin," the Stephen Schwartz-Roger O. Hirson musical, to open Sept. 20 at the Center's Opera House for a four-week engagement as originally planned.
MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 31 -- Mark Spitz won his fourth and fifth gold medals of the current Olympic Games tonight and equaled the record output for a single athlete in one Olympics.

Billie Jean was intimidating, Evonne was mesmerizing. Chris proved relentless. Rosemary was demoralizing, and Margaret looked overwhelming. That's how the girl-watchers rated the top five women players yesterday at the United States Open tennis championships at Forest Hills, Queens.

Sal (The Barber) Maglie, the former major-league pitching star, was in fair condition yesterday at Mount St. Mary's Hospial in Niagara Falls, N. Y., where he was admitted Wednesday following an apparent heart attack.
Despite an absence of bullish economic developments the stock market yesterday scored its second consecutive modest advance in continued dull trading.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- An Interior Department investigation of a Blacksville, W. Va., coal mine disaster that claimed nine lives places the blame on the mine operator, the Consolidation Coal Company, department sources said today.

ALBANY, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- A recent Gallup poll claiming that 64 per cent of the public is not opposed to legal abortions used an ambiguous question that did not consider the rights of the unborn, a national spokesman for a Roman Catholic group said Wednesday.

Assemblyman Franz S. J. Leichter of Manhattan denied yesterday that the Democratic Legislative Task Force on Housing, which he heads, had failed to invite real estate spokesmen to its hearing last Tuesday.

When President Nixon vetoed the appropriation bill for the Departments of Labor and of Health, Education and Welfare, he inadvertently provided Congress with an opportunity to correct an injustice to millions of American workers.

Frank Howard, one of the leading sluggers in baseball for most of the last 14 years, was sold by the Texas Rangers to the Detroit Tigers yesterday in the latest bit of pennant-maneuvering in the American League.

Another hotel became a target yesterday in the city's drive against prostitution, obscene films, so-called massage parlors and other illegal sex-oriented activities in the Times Square and midtown theater districts.

The idea that a good jazz band is usually also a good dance band has been buried for so many years under the concept of jazz as concert music that attempts to revive the connection between jazz and dancing have, until this summer, been hesitant and unconvincing -- at best, a short medley for dancers tacked on to the end of a "show."

WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 31 -- It was defensive day at the New York Giants' camp today and Coach Alex Webster put in all of his defenses in preparation for Saturday's game against the Philadelphia Eagles in Princeton.

Dr. Marie L. Fetsch, founder and president of the Sands Point Country Day School-Fetsch Academy in Sands Point L. I., was ordered yesterday to appear this month in State Supreme Court in Queens in connection with a $600,000 damage suit involving alleged fraud on the part of the school.

Two bank robbers whose bizarre behavior during a holdup of a Chase Manhattan Bank branch in Brooklyn on Aug. 22 attracted 3,000 onlookers were charged yesterday with stealing more than $213,000 in the robbery.

The manager of the city's Hunts Point Produce Market in the Bronx, whose anticorruption vows were featured this week in a "thieves' market" TV expose, was arrested yesterday on charges that he stole $1,827.75 in toll receipts at the market.
Monetary expansion has continued at a rapid rate in recent weeks, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday, despite a decline in the nation's money supply in the week ended Aug. 23.
PARIS, Aug. 31 -- Delegates to the Vietnam peace talks here blamed each other's sides today for the unending war and agreed to meet again next Thursday.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Vinny Giles, who has finished second three times in recent years, shot a 68 today at the United States Amateur golf championship and took the 36-hole lead at 141.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 31 -- Two weeks after Henry A. Kissinger's surprise visit to Saigon, high-ranking American officials here are talking privately not of a breakthrough in the peace talks, but, rather, of the possibility of unending war.

Kissinger, have been well briefed, they will not overlook the man at Mr. Tanaka's side, Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira, whose silence and sleepy look could be misleading.

MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 31 -- On the fifth day of competition the Olympic Games doping control officials caught their first offender -- an Iranian weight lifter -- and disqualified him retroactively today.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced plans yesterday for a $60-million, 42-story office tower to stand atop four steel columns adjacent to the bank's headquarters in the financial district.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, always unflappable, had a few anxious moments during the running of the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday. His 5-year-old mare, Cold Comfort, odds on in a field of seven fillies and mares competing in the seven-furlong turf event, encountered the sternest and most obstinate opposition from Fred Hooper's Mainzier, the complete outsider in the betting.

The American Jewish Committee, which brought intense pressure on behalf of the recent Presidential proclamation eliminating minority quotas from all Federal hiring, has itself come under pressure to pull back from its initial stand.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- A photographic processor in Miami said today that two men arrested June 17 in the break-in at Democratic party headquarters had asked him to develop pictures of party documents a week before the break-in occurred.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Labor Day marks the traditional opening of intensive campaigning for the Presidency. MILWAUKEE, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Dave May's two-run single sparked a three-run uprising in the second inning tonight as the Milwaukee Brewers recorded a 7-3 victory over the Kansas City Royals.
TOKYO, Aug. 31 (Reuters) -- Japan's external reserves at the end of August rose to a near-record $16.37-billion, the Finance Ministry said today. The yen is currently quoted at about 0.3323 cent.

The Advertising Club of New York wants it known that it approves the concept of one major creative award for advertising, as proposed by the Art Directors Club, the Copy Club of New York and the independent board of directors of the Andy Awards.
The arrest of nine suspects accused of conducting a large gambling operation in the New York suburbs was announced here yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
An American physician has returned to Peking to lay plans for a delegation of 10 Chinese physicians to visit the United States this fall.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Senator George McGovern, who freely admits that he could not have been nominated without a strong media campaign, will open his fall television drive a week before the first Nixon political commercials begin appearing.

In an expanding effort to make the most out of barnyard wastes, two corporations reported this week experimental successes in recycling cattle manure into a high-protein food supplement for livestock.

Mark Spitz, the California swimmer, made more Olympic history at Munich, West Germany, yesterday, winning his fourth and fifth gold medals with his fourth and fifth world records of the current Games. Only one other athlete has ever won five gold medals in a single Olympics. An Italian fencer, Nedo Nadi, did it in 1920 at Antwerp, Belgium.

Joseph F. Crangle, the Democratic state chairman, accused Governor Rockefeller and the state Republican party yesterday of selling out to the "radical right" by agreeing to a Conservative party endorsement of President Nixon.

The three-year contracts between the Board of Higher Education and the faculty and professional staffs of the City University of New York expired last night, with both sides reporting little progress toward a new comprehensive agreement.

Export brokers bought heavily in the corn and soybean pits yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, sending futures for both commodities up sharply. Observers expressed the belief that the exporters were hedging against recent sales to foreign countries, possibly Russia again.

Voter registration in New York State was extended yesterday to Sept. 15. A pair of nationally televised games feature the National Football League's next-to-last weekend of preseason contests. Tonight in Tampa, Fla., the Baltimore Colts play the Detroit Lions, beginning at 8:30 over Channel 4 here.

ROME, Aug. 31 -- A pizza that was a dollar last spring now costs $1.20. Suddenly there is a black market in meat and vegetables. The unseasonable weather wraps the traffic jams in a wet blanket and even the Colosseum is crumbling.

CHICAGO Aug. 31, (AP) -- Claude Osteen checked the Chicago Cubs on seven hits and singled to score what proved to be the winning run today as the Los Angeles Dodgers won a 5-3 National League baseball victory.

The New York Musicians Organization, Inc., a cooperative of more than 500 jazz artists that temporarily coalesced just before the Newport Jazz Festival to produce an "alternate jazz festival" in July, has become a permanent organization.

A 9-year-old girl was drowned by her mother in the kitchen sink of their East Harlem apartment, the police of the East 119th Street station reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell, in a decision that blunted a key Congressional antibusing weapon, refused today to delay a school desegregation plan for Augusta, Ga.
EXETER, N. H., Sept. 1 (AP) -The Wise Shoe Company announced today it was closing Idown its factory here with al loss of about 250 jobs.

Prices edged ahead in light pre-holiday trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-thecounter market.
A panel of five Appellate Division judges yesterday threw out a challenge to a 15 per cent rent increase ordered last May for tenants in 400,000 rent-controlled apartments in the city.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -A nuclear reactor has been designed for the Atomic Energy Commission. Including mechanical attachments, it is about the size of an average man. Carroll B. Mills, a physicist, and Robert L. Brasier, an engineer, at the University of Cali fornia Scientific Laboratory in Los Alamos, N.M., were granted patent 3,687,804 this week.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 31 -Nigeria is making bold moves toward controlling her own economy -- for the first time.

HOUSTON, Sept 1 -- A Federal judge today approved a $1.6-million partial settlement of a civil suit accusing 93 defendants of manipulation of Westec Corporation stock prior to the company's collapse in 1966.

The initial shock of last year's United States open tennis championships came when Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia beat the defending champion, John Newcombe, in the first round. VICTORIA, British Columbia, Aug. 27 -- This Pacific seaport has decided to battle the builders of highways and high-rise apartments, in the face of what it sees as a threat to its graceful mood.

TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 1 (AP) -Greg Landry, Detroit s quarterback, hurled touchdown passes of 9 and 46 yards tonight to lead the Lions to a 24-17 victory over the Baltimore Colts in a National Football League exhibition game.

SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 1 -- A South Korean red Cross official reported today that his organization had begun making lists of divided Korean families in preparation for the second round of North-South Red Cross talks in Seoul on Sept. 3. In the wake of criticism from Mayor Lindsay for allegedly proceeding "too far" with plans to change subway schedules, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority repeated yesterday its earlier assertions that no such changes were imminent.

OTTAWA, Sept. 1 -- Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau tonight called a Canadian general election for Oct. 30. It will give Canadians their first opportunity to vote on Mr. Trudeau's Government since its election in June, 1968.

WASHINGTON, Saturday, Sept. 2 -- The three Americans whose imminent release was announced today were previously known to have been prisoners of war in North Vietnam. all three of them had been seen by American antiwar activists during visits to North Vietnam.

Operations of Interstate Stores, Inc., in the 13 and 26 weeks ended July 30 resulted in deep losses, according to yesterday's report by the 173 retail-store chain.

State Supreme Court Justice Charles R. Rubin yesterday dismissed a suit brought by former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein charging that fraud and voter irregularities were responsible for his loss in the June 20 Democratic primary to Representative John J. Rooney in Brooklyn's 14th Congressional District.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Selective Service announced today that about 15,900 young men holding lottery numbers 95 and below would be drafted during the OctoberDecember period. They may be the last American men conscripted into the armed forces.

ATLANTA, Sept. 1 -- The New York Jets and the Atlanta Falcons are not scheduled to meet in their first "for real" game until next season, but tomorrow afternoon at Georgia Tech's Grant Field, they will come as close as they ever have, meeting in their third preseason contest beginning at 4 P.M. (WNEVT-TV Channel 5, WOR Radio 710).
